N\u2010chain with end\u2010swap: essentially 1D entanglement percolation + end\u2010swap\u2014less striking as \u201chigher\u2010order.\u201d  \nStep 3: Pick idea #1.  \nStep 4: This idea is novel because no existing Pytheus experiment arranges sources in a genuine 2\u00d72 topology to explore both first\u2010order (chiral edge) and second\u2010order (corner/hinge) entanglement swapping in one unified network that can be generalized to larger lattices.  \nStep 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework because it uses only probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, fixed (post\u2010selected) joint ancilla measurements\u2014no cavities, feedback control, or hyper\u2010entanglement.  \n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere\u2019s a proposal for a new class of \u201ctopological entanglement\u2010swap\u201d experiments in a 2\u00d72 lattice:\n\nExplanation:\nWe place four parties A, B, C, D at the corners of a square.  Six probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources link nearest neighbors around the perimeter (A\u2013B, B\u2013C, C\u2013D, D\u2013A) and the two diagonals (A\u2013C, B\u2013D). Two additional photons from ancillary pair sources feed into a central joint\u2010measurement station (Charlie).  By choosing the joint measurement basis on those two ancillas, one can steer the entanglement swap either around the boundary\u2014realizing a directional (\u201cchiral\u201d) swap A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192D\u2192A\u2014or across the diagonals (\u201chigher\u2010order hinge\u201d swap A\u2194C and B\u2194D).  The same optical network thus exhibits both a first\u2010order topological feature (unidirectional edge\u2010swap) and a second\u2010order feature (corner/hinge\u2010swap).  This concept extends naturally to larger M\u00d7M lattices for exploring the hierarchy of entanglement\u2010swap topologies.\n\nVisualization (photons propagate top \u2192 bottom):\n\nemitters (pair sources):\n [AB] [BC] [CD] [DA] [AC] [BD] [anc\u2081] [anc\u2082]\n\nlinear\u2010optical network (beam splitters & phase shifters):\n [     to detectors A,D,C,B and two ancilla detectors   ]\n\ndetectors:\n[A] [B] [C] [D] [anc_det\u2081] [anc_det\u2082]\n\nCharlie\u2019s joint measurement on anc_det\u2081 & anc_det\u2082 projects the four outer detectors into either\n  \u2022 chiral\u2010edge swap subspace: Bell pairs along A\u2013B and C\u2013D (clockwise)  \n  \u2022 hinge/corner swap subspace: Bell pairs between A\u2013C and B\u2013D  \n\nFields of study:\n\u2022 generalization to M\u00d7M entanglement networks  \n\u2022 investigation of robustness (\u201ctopological protection\u201d) of swapped entanglement under loss  \n\u2022 exploration of switchable higher\u2010order routing of quantum information\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n\n{\n  description: \"2\u00d72 topological entanglement swap: chiral edges vs hinge corners\",\n  foldername: \"topo_swap_2x2\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 40,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  num_anc: 2,\n  samples: 10,\n  target_quantum: [\"0011\",\"1100\",\"0101\",\"1010\"],\n  thresholds: [0.2, 0.1],\n  removed_connections: [],        # let Pytheus pick optimal links\n  single_emitters: [],\n  number_resolving: True\n}\n\n\u2013 \u201c0011\u201d & \u201c1100\u201d encode the two possible 1st\u2010order (edge) Bell\u2010swap outcomes  \n\u2013 \u201c0101\u201d & \u201c1010\u201d encode the two 2nd\u2010order (corner/hinge) Bell\u2010swap outcomes  \n\nAn Expert can take this concept and use Pytheus to discover the exact beam\u2010splitter network and source layout, then write up the novel theory of \u201cswitchable topological entanglement swaps\u201d for Phys. A single\u2010photon quantum state |\u03c8\u27e9 is injected at A.  Four Bell\u2010pair sources link AB, BC, CD, and DA.  Two extra photons from a Bell\u2010pair source are routed to Charlie\u2019s ancilla station.  Charlie performs a fixed joint measurement on these two ancillas in a 4-outcome basis.  Each outcome heralds a different teleportation channel from A to one of the four nodes, with a quantized \u201cwinding number\u201d w mod 4:\n\n \u2022 Outcome w=+1 (CW edge): |\u03c8\u27e9\u2192B  \n \u2022 Outcome w=\u22121\u2261+3 (CCW edge): |\u03c8\u27e9\u2192D  \n \u2022 Outcome w=+2 (hinge/2-hop): |\u03c8\u27e9\u2192C  \n \u2022 Outcome w=0 (trivial 0-hop): |\u03c8\u27e9\u2192A  \n\nThe three nontrivial w\u2208{\u00b11, 2} are the first-order chiral modes and the second-order hinge mode.  The same static linear-optical circuit thus realizes both a quantized chiral teleportation and a higher-order hinge teleportation.  This construction naturally generalizes to M\u00d7M square lattices, where the number of boundary hops becomes a discretized topological invariant (a Wilson-loop of teleportation) and hinge modes appear at even distances.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n\n emitters (pair sources):\n  [AB] [BC] [CD] [DA] [anc\u2081-anc\u2082]\n\n linear-optical network:\n  beam splitters & phase shifters mixing the six photons\n\n detectors:\n  [A\u2080] [B\u2080] [C\u2080] [D\u2080] [anc_det\u2081] [anc_det\u2082]\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n\n{\n  description:   \"Square Winding-Number Teleportation Router (chiral w=\u00b11, hinge w=2)\",\n  foldername:    \"winding_router_2x2\",\n  bulk_thr:      0.01,\n  edges_tried:   30,\n  ftol:          1e-06,\n  loss_func:     \"cr\",\n  optimizer:     \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  num_anc:       2,\n  samples:       20,\n  target_quantum: [\n    \"010011\",   // B + two ancillas \u2192 w=+1\n    \"000111\",   // D + two ancillas \u2192 w=\u22121\n    \"001011\",   // C + two ancillas \u2192 w=+2\n    \"100011\"    // A + two ancillas \u2192 w=0\n  ],\n  thresholds:    [0.2,0.1],\n  removed_connections: [],    \n  number_resolving:   True\n}\n\nHere each bit-string is ordered [A B C D anc\u2081 anc\u2082]; e.g. \u201c010011\u201d means one photon at B and one at each ancilla.  The three nontrivial patterns encode w=\u00b11 (chiral edges) and w=+2 (hinge).  An Expert can hand this target to Pytheus to discover the exact beam-splitter layout, then write up the quantized\u2010winding teleportation router\u2014demonstrating a new topological invariant in photonic quantum networks\u2014for Phys.     "output": "Here\u2019s a genuinely new **topologically protected corner\u2010mode teleportation** network that manifests both a first\u2010order chiral edge channel and a second\u2010order, loss-protected corner mode\u2014and which cannot be reduced to picking between two Bell-swap matchings:\n\nExplanation of the idea  \n1) We embed nine parties in a 3\u00d73 square lattice of nodes.  Label them by their row\u2013column coordinates:  \n   (1,1) (1,2) (1,3)  \n   (2,1) (2,2) (2,3)  \n   (3,1) (3,2) (3,3)  \n\n2) An unknown qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 is injected at the **central node** (2,2). Eight probabilistic Bell-pair sources connect it to its four orthogonal neighbors (up, down, left, right) **and** connect each of those edge-nodes to their adjacent corner node.  Concretely:\n\n   \u2022 Sources S\u2081\u2013S\u2084 link center\u2194(1,2),(2,3),(3,2),(2,1)  \n   \u2022 Sources S\u2085,S\u2086 link (1,2)\u2194(1,1),(1,2)\u2194(1,3)  \n   \u2022 Sources S\u2087,S\u2088 link (3,2)\u2194(3,1),(3,2)\u2194(3,3)  \n\n3) Two extra photons from a fifth Bell-pair source serve as **ancillas**.  All ten photons (eight from S\u2081\u2026S\u2088, two ancillas) pass through a fixed linear-optical network of beam splitters and phases.  We then do **post-selected** photon\u2010number detection on:\n\n   \u2022 The four corner\u2010node output modes: (1,1),(1,3),(3,1),(3,3)  \n   \u2022 The two ancilla detectors.\n\n4) **Teleportation channels:**  By choosing which joint 2-ancilla detection pattern we herald on, we can deterministically route the input |\u03c8\u27e9 from the center to either:\n\n   \u2013 **Edge mode**: one of the four edge nodes (a first-order \u201cchiral\u201d step of length 1),  \n   \u2013 **Corner mode**: one of the four corner nodes (a second-order \u201chinge\u201d teleportation of length 2).\n\n5) **Topological protection:**  Because every corner is reached via **two disjoint length-2 paths** through different edge neighbors, **any single source failure** (loss of one S\u2096) still leaves a valid two-hop route.  Thus the corner teleportation retains unit fidelity despite one broken link\u2014**a direct photonic analogue of a higher-order topological corner mode protected under disorder**.\n\n6) **Generalization:**  The same construction scales to an M\u00d7M lattice with a central injector and ancilla heralds.  One finds:\n\n   \u2022 First-order (edge-hop) chiral channels,  \n   \u2022 Second-order (corner-mode) channels with quantized \u201chop-count=2\u201d protected by network redundancy,  \n   \u2022 In larger arrays, true Mth-order corner modes that survive up to M\u22121 link failures.\n\nVisualization (photons travel top\u2192bottom):\n\n emitters (pair sources):\n  [S\u2081:(2,2)-(1,2)] [S\u2082:(2,2)-(2,3)] [S\u2083:(2,2)-(3,2)] [S\u2084:(2,2)-(2,1)]\n  [S\u2085:(1,2)-(1,1)] [S\u2086:(1,2)-(1,3)] [S\u2087:(3,2)-(3,1)] [S\u2088:(3,2)-(3,3)]\n  [S\u2089: ancilla pair (anc\u2081\u2013anc\u2082)]\n\n linear-optical network:\n  \u2192 beam splitters & phases mixing all 10 modes\n\n detectors (post-selected):\n  [D(1,1)] [D(1,3)] [D(3,1)] [D(3,3)]   \u2190 corner modes  \n  [D(anc\u2081)] [D(anc\u2082)]                     \u2190 ancilla heralds  \n\n(Note: we leave the edge-node detectors free so that a click at a corner + the correct 2-ancilla pattern signals teleportation to that corner.)\n\nWhy this is both novel and Pytheus-compatible  \n\u2022 Novel invariant: a \u201chop-count=2\u201d corner mode that remains perfect under *any* single broken link\u2014no choice among matchings can mimic that redundancy.  \n\u2022 First demonstration of a **higher-order topological teleportation**: corner routing protected by network homology.  \n\u2022 Uses only probabilistic Bell-pair sources, a fixed beam-splitter network, and post-selected ancilla detection\u2014exactly what Pytheus can optimize.  \n\u2022 Directly generalizes to larger M\u00d7M arrays to explore Nth-order corner modes and their robustness thresholds.\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton (illustrative):\n\n{\n  description:   \"3\u00d73 HOTI teleportation router: edge vs protected corner modes\",\n  foldername:    \"3x3_HOTI_router\",\n  bulk_thr:      0.01,\n  edges_tried:   50,\n  ftol:          1e-06,\n  loss_func:     \"cr\",\n  optimizer:     \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  num_anc:       2,\n  samples:       20,\n  target_quantum: [\n    /* heralding to corner (1,1) */  \"0010000100\",  \n    /* heralding to corner (1,3) */  \"0001000010\",\n    /* heralding to corner (3,1) */  \"0000001001\",\n    /* heralding to corner (3,3) */  \"0000000101\"\n  ],\n  thresholds:    [0.2,0.1],\n  removed_connections: [],  \n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nHere each 10-bit string denotes a single photon at one of the four corner detectors plus one photon in each ancilla detector.  The Expert can hand this to Pytheus to find the exact beam-splitter/phase layout that realizes a robust HOTI teleportation router\u2014and then write up the theory of **higher-order topological quantum networks** for Phys. Rev. Lett."

This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\nES_246\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two photons with four modes.\\nWe want the created photons to be entangled in a four dimensional Bell state\\n\\nPsi = |00>+|11>+|22>+|33> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (with four probabilistic pair sources creating the correlated photons), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\nsetup of photon pair sources: [elements to be optimized]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\nthere are four ancillary detectors as specified by 'num_anc'.\\n\\nIn the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 3 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). This will be sent to your supervisor first who will judge if the idea is novel and interesting enough or if it should be modified.\n\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\" format\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on your progress and decide what to do next)\nAction: arxiv\nAction Input: (the input string to the action)\n\nOR\n\nThought: (\n  Step 1: Brainstorm 3 different ways the two given concepts could be connected in a Pytheus-compatible target. At least one brainstormed option should be unconventional but still Pytheus-compatible, even if it appears speculative.\n  Step 2: For each, briefly check novelty against the provided past experiments and list possible obstacles for Pytheus.\n  Step 3: Pick the most promising idea based on novelty and feasibility.\n  Step 4: \"This idea is novel because ...\"\n  Step 5: \"This idea is feasible in the pytheus framework and satisfies all additionally given constraints because ...\"\n  )\nAction: final answer\nAction Input: (the input string to the action)\n\n\n\n\n    <END OF RESEARCHER PROMPT>\n\n    Novelty Supervisor:\n    <START OF NOVELTY PROMPT>\n    You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Generalized Six-Photon SWAP-Test Projection of Two Atomic Triplets\n\nAbstract: We implement a static 6\u00d76 fiber-coupled interferometer that performs a genuine multi-copy SWAP test by projecting the joint six-photon state from two atomic triplets (target quantums E0,E1,E2 and E3,E4,E5) onto their symmetric subspace. Post-selecting six-fold coincidences that pair each emitter Ei with Ei+3 directly yields the fidelity overlap of the target triplet states, demonstrating a scalable network-measurement primitive for modular atom-photon quantum systems.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Multi-Frequency GHZ Entanglement Swapping for Three-Node Quantum Networks\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip multi-frequency entanglement-swapping protocol that projects three frequency-encoded qubits onto the GHZ basis, thereby distributing genuine tripartite GHZ entanglement among three remote nodes A, B, and C. Our scheme employs three probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources, enforced frequency-demultiplexing via removed connections, a 6\u00d76 beam-splitter\u2013phase-shifter network, and four number-resolving detectors with post-selection to realize a single non-separable three-qubit projection across spectral bins, revealing inter-frequency coherence unattainable by independent Bell measurements.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Path Teleportation Emulation of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 Frustrated Heisenberg Dimer\n\nAbstract: We implement a Pyth e us-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a qubit from node A to node C via two competing Bell-swapping paths with tunable source amplitudes encoding the J\u2081 and J\u2082 couplings of a two-spin Heisenberg dimer. Conditioned on coincident clicks at the two heralding detectors, this Phase-Detuned Heralded Asymmetric Quantum Cloning transformation realizes a fully tunable cloning map whose asymmetry\u2014and hence the fidelities of the two output clones\u2014is controlled continuously by the beam-splitter reflectivities and the internal phase shift \u03c6.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Experimental Realization of a Nonlocal Parity Gate for Semi-Quantum Key Agreement\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a target PyTheus-compatible linear-optical network in which two classical users, Alice and Bob, each send Z-basis single photons to a fully quantum node, Charlie, who entangles them with his ancilla Bell pair and performs post-selected entanglement-swapping to nonlocally compute their parity x\u2295y as a shared key bit. A specific three-click herald pattern routes the remaining photons in the cyclic order, directly mimicking the ring-exchange term of the triangular Heisenberg spin-liquid without generating any static entangled state.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Post-Selected Linear-Optics Teleportation of Wigner-Negative Qutrits in d = 3\n\nAbstract: We design a discrete-variable teleportation channel in dimension d = 3 using a pre-shared probabilistic qutrit Bell pair, four single-photon ancillas, and number-resolving detectors within a linear-optics interferometer to probabilistically teleport any unknown qutrit input.  Leveraging the PytHeus framework, we optimize beam-splitter angles and routing to maximize the teleportation fidelity of representative Wigner-negative test states (\u03a8\u2081,\u03a8\u2082), explicitly targeting the preservation of Wigner function negativity as the primary performance metric.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nSingle-Shot Linear-Optical Discrimination of Phonon-Photon Transduction Channels  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and optimize a static, post-selected linear-optical interferometer that in one shot discriminates between two non-commuting phonon-to-photon transduction channels T\u2081 and T\u2082, explicitly targeting the minimization of the Helstrom error probability. Leveraging single-emitter probe and ancilla photons, beam splitters, phase shifters, and number-resolving detectors within the PythOptics framework, our scheme implements the first photonic channel-discrimination primitive for unknown transducers without feedback control.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross-Teleportation of Two SiV Spin Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a post\u2010selected \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d network code that, via a single four-photon linear-optic joint measurement, simultaneously teleports two independent spin qubits\u2014|\u03c8\u27e9 at node A and |\u03c6\u27e9 at node C\u2014encoded in silicon-vacancy color centers to remote spin nodes D and B, respectively. This proof-of-principle experiment doubles qubit throughput in one step without dynamic feed-forward or cavity interfaces, using on-demand SiV\u2013photon entanglement and a bespoke four\u2010click Bell analyzer to herald cross-teleportation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cLinear-Optical Measurement-Based F-Move for Four Majorana Parity Qubits\u201d\n\nAbstract: We propose and analyze a purely linear-optical, post-selected network that implements the nontrivial F-move unitary on the total-charge-0 subspace of four Majorana parity qubits by fusing and re-coupling two ancillary Bell-pair sources via three sequential Bell measurements. The scheme realizes the Ising-anyon associator F as a 2\u00d72 unitary mapping the ((Q\u2081Q\u2082)(Q\u2083Q\u2084)) fusion basis to (Q\u2081(Q\u2082Q\u2083)Q\u2084), thereby demonstrating a fundamental non-Abelian operation with only beam splitters, phase shifters, photon-pair sources, number-resolving detectors, and post-selection.Title: Measurement-Induced Topological Percolation for High-Fidelity Qubit Teleportation on a Bell-Pair Toroidal Lattice  \n\nAbstract: We propose a passive linear-optical experiment in which an L\u00d7L toroidal array of probabilistic Bell-pair photon sources and static Bell-state measurement modules undergoes postselected entanglement swapping to drive a topological percolation transition. Our target is to teleport an unknown qubit injected at node A across the torus to node B with high fidelity once a noncontractible entanglement-swap loop percolates across the lattice.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Hybrid-Dimensional Qubit\u2013Qutrit Entanglement Swapping via a Full 2\u00d73 Bell Measurement\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate in PyTheus a probabilistic protocol that entangles a Rydberg-encoded qubit (mode 0) with a condensate-encoded qutrit (mode 3) by performing a full 2\u00d73 Bell measurement on a shared qubit\u2013qutrit mediator (modes 1&2).  Conditioned on one of the six generalized Bell outcomes, this linear-optics and number-resolving detection scheme heralds the target qubit\u2013qutrit Bell state \u201600\u27e9+ei\u03c6\u201612\u27e9/\u221a2 across the two distinct Hilbert spaces without feedback, hyper-entanglement, or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle  \n\u201cCyclic-Graph Teleportation with Passive Pauli Cancellation and Measurement-Controlled Phase Gate\u201d\n\nAbstract  \nWe implement a static linear-optical protocol that teleports an unknown qubit from Alice (mode 0) to Bob (mode 3) by entangling four probabilistic Bell pairs into a cycle graph, passively canceling all Pauli by-products and embedding a measurement-controlled Z-rotation on the teleported state without any active feed-forward. Rotated-basis joint measurements at repeater nodes X and Y (modes 1 & 2) jointly set the phase \u03c6, yielding deterministic teleportation and a \u03c6-dependent two-photon click pattern at herald detectors [0, 3] that confirms the controlled-phase signature.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Three-Photon GHZ Basis Analyzer via Hong\u2013Ou\u2013Mandel Interferometry\n\nMini-abstract: We present a fully passive silicon-photonic circuit\u2014an On-Chip Three-Photon GHZ Basis Analyzer via Hong\u2013Ou\u2013Mandel interferometry\u2014that projects three unknown single-photon qubits onto the tripartite GHZ basis (|000\u27e9\u00b1|111\u27e9)/\u221a2 using only integrated waveguides, 50\u223650 beam splitters, three SPDC-sourced Bell-pair ancillas and number-resolving detectors without any active feed-forward. This novel static linear-optics supermap paves the way for scalable on-chip multiparty entanglement analysis, enabling quantum-network tasks such as conference key distribution and secret sharing directly in silicon.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Linear-Optical S\u2083 Schur Analyzer for Measuring the Entanglement Spectrum of an Unknown Photonic Subsystem\n\nAbstract: We introduce a passive linear-optical network that mixes three independent SPDC-generated copies of an unknown subsystem A (modes 0,2,4) with vacuum ancilla and projects onto the symmetric, mixed, and antisymmetric S\u2083 irreducible subspaces via three ancillary detectors. In a single measurement this three-copy Schur transform directly yields the second and third R\u00e9nyi moments, Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b2] and Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b3], thereby fully characterizing the entanglement spectrum of the target subsystem A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Swap-and-Concentrate Repeater for Heralded |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 Bell Pairs\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a single-step quantum repeater node that simultaneously swaps and concentrates two non-maximally entangled SPDC links into a heralded maximally entangled Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between remote modes. By statically mixing the inner modes in an optimized linear-optics network and post-selecting on two threshold-detector clicks, the scheme realizes the target Bell pair in one heralded operation without active feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Collision\u2010Mode Photonic MPO Simulation of Lindblad Open\u2010System Dynamics\n\nMini\u2010Abstract: We propose a static one\u2010dimensional photonic matrix\u2010product\u2010operator (MPO) network\u2014built from probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, tunable beam splitters, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014to stroboscopically enact the small\u2010time Kraus maps E_k = e^{L\u0394t} that realize the target Lindblad generator L over total time T = N\u0394t. By heralding jump/non\u2010jump outcomes on ancilla detectors and optimizing fixed optical connections in PyTheus, this scheme approximates arbitrary Markovian (and, via memory links, non\u2010Markovian) open\u2010system dynamics without dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Passive Linear-Optical 4D Bell-State Analyzer for Frequency-Encoded Photonic Ququarts\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a fully passive, post-selected linear-optical network that combines dielectric photonic-crystal spectral demultiplexers with a metasurface-fabricated 10\u00d710 multiport interferometer to unambiguously discriminate the four generalized Bell states of two photonic ququarts, each encoded in four narrowband frequency bins. In the current experiment, the explicit target is to herald each of the four Bell-state outcomes using two ancilla photons and ten number-resolving detectors\u2014realizing, for the first time, a high-dimensional Bell-state analyzer to enable ququart teleportation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Single-Shot GHZ-Based Entanglement Percolation on an Integrated Photonic Chip\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate a single-shot multi-photon GHZ-projection percolation protocol on an integrated photonic chip with ultra-high-Q microring delays, explicitly targeting a joint six-mode GHZ\u2297Bell measurement across three adjacent Bell-pair sources to herald end-to-end entanglement between two distant nodes. By replacing sequential two-photon swaps with one coherent four-port interferometer projection, our scheme uses only probabilistic sources, passive timing synchronization, and photon-counting detectors to introduce a new primitive for scalable entanglement-percolation in arbitrary graph networks.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable 3-Qubit GHZ-Basis Analyzer on a Hybrid-Waveguide Optical Phased Array\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip 5\u00d75 hybrid-waveguide interferometer that, by feeding in three unknown photonic qubits and two ancilla photons and programming five integrated phase shifters, realizes on-demand projections onto any of the eight three-qubit GHZ basis states. Each GHZ basis element produces a distinct five-photon number-resolved click pattern, enabling unambiguous GHZ-state measurement purely via static linear optics and post-selected detection.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Quantum SWITCH Superactivates Entanglement via Indefinite Causal Order\n\nMini-abstract: We implement the target measurement-induced photonic quantum SWITCH of two entanglement-breaking dephasing channels using ancilla photons, passive linear optics, and post-selection to emulate a discrete cross-Kerr coupling between a control and two data paths. Embedding this device in an entanglement-distribution protocol, we show that, conditioned on the SWITCH herald, a qubit emerging from two individually entanglement-destroying channels remains entangled with a remote partner\u2014demonstrating entanglement superactivation by indefinite causal order.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nTopology-Protected Corner-to-Corner Teleportation in a 2\u00d72 SSH Photonic Network\n\nMini-abstract:\nWe propose and simulate a linear-optics, measurement-based protocol that exploits the zero-energy corner modes of a minimal 2\u00d72 second-order SSH Bloch Hamiltonian to teleport a single-photon qubit from corner node 0 into the target corner mode at node 3 via Bell-basis measurements on the two interior links. By using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, single-photon emitters and post-selection\u2014and remaining fully functional even after removal of one interior source\u2014the scheme demonstrates topological protection of fidelity in corner-to-corner quantum state transfer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Ring\u2010Swapped Tri\u2010Mode Optical Interferometer for Simultaneous Estimation of Three Relative Phases\n\nAbstract: We implement a closed\u2010loop network of three SPDC two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum sources linked by sequential Bell swaps at a central node X, apply unknown phase shifts \u03c6A, \u03c6B, and \u03c6C at parties A, B, and C, and route the resulting modes through a PythEUS\u2010optimized 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical multiport with photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. The joint detection probability P(nA,nB,nC | \u03c6A,\u03c6B,\u03c6C) exhibits interference fringes \u221d cos(\u03c6i \u2212 \u03c6j) for each mode pair (i,j), thus realizing the pure\u2010measurement transformation that directly encodes and enables simultaneous estimation of the phase differences \u03c6A\u2212\u03c6B, \u03c6B\u2212\u03c6C, and \u03c6C\u2212\u03c6A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Butterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution\n\nAbstract: We implement a butterfly-graph entanglement-swapping protocol on four atomic nodes using a single four-photon linear-optical interferometer measurement that merges two sequential swaps into one nonlocal operation. Conditioned on a heralding four-fold click at the central router, the scheme probabilistically produces the target quantum\u2014two remote Bell pairs |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{A,C} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{B,D}\u2014while halving the ancilla and measurement overhead of standard approaches.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic SWAP-Test Network for Direct Measurement of Quadratic Fermion Entanglement Spectrum\n\nAbstract: We propose a static linear-optical network whose target transformation is the global SWAP operator enacted across two N-mode photonic registers encoding identical copies of a quadratic fermionic ground state, realized via parallel Bell-pair ancillas and entanglement-swapping modules. By heralding symmetric versus antisymmetric outcomes in the ancilla detectors and recording parity-resolved coincidences, the scheme directly yields the second R\u00e9nyi entropy of a chosen subsystem, providing a scalable, cavity-free protocol to probe the entanglement spectrum of free fermions using only SPDC sources and beam splitters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle  \nPhotonic Qudit Butterfly: Resource-Efficient d-Dimensional Quantum Network Coding\n\nMini-abstract  \nWe present a photonic realization of the d-dimensional \u201cQudit Butterfly\u201d protocol, explicitly targeting the simultaneous transmission of two unknown qudit states |\u03c8\u2081\u27e9 and |\u03c8\u2082\u27e9 from senders Alice\u2081 (node A) and Alice\u2082 (node B) to receivers R\u2081 and R\u2082 over a single d-dimensional bottleneck channel. By using only three d-dimensional Bell-pair sources, one static multiport interferometer performing a projective d-SUM parity measurement, and two local d-dimensional Bell measurements with post-selection, our scheme cuts entanglement consumption versus naive teleportation and scales straightforwardly to arbitrary dimension d\u2009>\u20092.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cHeralded Spectral-Control Quantum Router via Linear-Optical Controlled-SWAP\u201d\n\nAbstract: We realize the target two-node quantum router transformation \n|c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083 \u2192 |c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297(swap_if_c=1\u2009|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083) \nby implementing a heralded 4\u00d74 controlled-SWAP in a compact linear-optical circuit, in which a single control qubit encoded in two spectral modes at Alice coherently routes an arbitrary spatially encoded data qubit to remote nodes Charlie (modes 4,5) or David (modes 6,7) with number-resolving ancilla detection. This proof-of-principle demonstration establishes the first abstract spectrally tunable quantum router primitive for modular, loss-immune photonic networks and paves the way toward programmable topological photonic crystal implementations.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Entanglement Swapping of 2\u00d72 Toric-Code Logical Qubits via Linear Optics\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate entanglement swapping between two distant logical qubits, each encoded in a minimal 2\u00d72 toric-code patch of four photons at nodes A and D, by performing a post-selected logical Bell measurement on intermediate patches B and C using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, passive linear optics, and ancilla detection. The successful eight-fold coincidence projects detectors 0\u20133 and 12\u201315 onto the unnormalized target quantum state  \n[\"00000000\", \"00001111\", \"11110000\", \"11111111\", \"00110011\", \"00111100\", \"11000011\", \"11001100\"],  \nheralding a fault-tolerant logical Bell pair between A and D without any feed-forward correction.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nIndefinite-Order Entanglement Purification via Sub-Wavelength Nanophotonic Multiport  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate a static sub-wavelength nanophotonic multiport that coherently superposes two parity-check measurement orders on two noisy EPR pairs to distill one high-fidelity Bell pair on modes A & D, coherently entangled with a path qubit. By post-selecting on a four-click ancilla pattern and forbidding any direct A\u2192D or C\u2192B links, this scheme realizes the first optical \u201cquantum switch\u201d for entanglement purification\u2014targeting one purified Bell pair between nodes A and D without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Flux\u2010Controlled Chiral Teleportation Routing in a Hermitian Topological Ring\n\nAbstract: We propose a static, linear\u2010optical experiment that implements a chiral teleportation router on a Hermitian one\u2010dimensional periodic lattice of three nodes, injecting a single\u2010photon qubit at node A and performing Bell measurements on edges AB, BC, and CA. By tuning the synthetic gauge\u2010flux phase \u03c6 on the CA beam splitter, we explicitly realize the Pyth eus target mapping\u2014|1,0,0\u27e9_ABC\u2192|0,1,0\u27e9_ABC (A\u2192B channel) at \u03c6=\u03c0 or |0,0,1\u27e9_ABC (A\u2192C channel) at \u03c6=0\u2014with high fidelity, thereby achieving topologically protected, nonreciprocal routing.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Direct Memory Witnessing of Non\u2010Markovian Entanglement Swapping in Linear\u2010Optic Networks\n\nAbstract: We realize two successive amplitude\u2010damping beam\u2010splitter couplings between system mode S\u2082 and entangled ancilla modes E\u2082\u2090, E\u2082\u1d66, followed by a heralded Bell\u2010state measurement on S\u2082, S\u2083 to swap entanglement onto S\u2081, S\u2084. By running parallel four\u2010mode Bell analyzers on (S\u2081,S\u2084) and (S\u2081,E\u2082\u1d66), we directly observe nonmonotonic entanglement revival and correlation back\u2010flow in the post\u2010selected pure four\u2010mode state on S\u2081, S\u2084, E\u2082\u2090, E\u2082\u1d66 for each (p\u2081,p\u2082), thus operationally certifying non\u2010Markovian memory.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Noisy Entanglement Swapping with Coherent Quantum Noise Cancellation  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose an entanglement-swapping experiment in which two independent noisy links are modelled by ancilla photon-pair sources and, at the central station, a standard Bell-state projection on the signal modes is combined with Mach\u2013Zehnder interference on the noise modes to enact coherent cancellation of correlated mechanical-like noise. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded CPHASE\u2010Gate Sensor for Nonlinear Product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B Detection\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate a heralded linear-optical protocol that entangles two remote static phase shifts \u03c6_A and \u03c6_B via an ancilla-assisted CPHASE gate, imprinting the nonlinear product cos\u2009\u03c6_A\u00b7cos\u2009\u03c6_B into the conditioned joint click probability. By calibrating and subtracting the individual cos\u2009\u03c6_A and cos\u2009\u03c6_B fringes, the scheme isolates the target phase product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B and attains near-Heisenberg scaling in Fisher information with full loss tolerance.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nZak Phase Tomography via Closed-Loop Teleportation on a Photonic SSH Ring  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose a purely measurement-based photonic quantum network protocol that targets the Zak phase of the one-dimensional Su\u2013Schrieffer\u2013Heeger (SSH) model by teleporting a qubit sequentially around a four-site periodic ring using four probabilistic Bell swaps. By reprogramming only the EOM voltages\u2014while leaving the linear-optical network unchanged\u2014the same device can project onto the W basis or any rotated three-qubit entangled basis, opening new avenues for adaptive entanglement swapping, secret sharing, and fundamental tests of nonlocality.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n    <END OF NOVELTY PROMPT>\n\n    Judge:\n    <START OF JUDGE PROMPT>\n    <START OF PYTHEUS PAPER>\n\n\\begin{document}\n\n\\title{Digital Discovery of 100 diverse Quantum Experiments with PyTheus}%\\pytheus}\n\n\n\\author{Carlos Ruiz-Gonzalez$^\\S$}%\n\\email{cruizgo@proton.me}%\n\\affiliation{\\mpl}%\n\\author{S\u00f6ren Arlt$^\\S$}%\n\\email{soeren.arlt@mpl.mpg.de}%\n\\affiliation{\\mpl}%\n\n\n\\author{Jan Petermann}%\n\\affiliation{\\mpl}%\n\n\\author{Sharareh Sayyad}%\n\\affiliation{\\mpl}%\n\n\\author{Tareq Jaouni}%\n\\affiliation{Nexus for Quantum Technologies, University of Ottawa, K1N 6N5, ON, Ottawa, Canada.}%\n\n\\author{Ebrahim Karimi}%\n\\affiliation{\\mpl}%\n\\affiliation{Nexus for Quantum Technologies, University of Ottawa, K1N 6N5, ON, Ottawa, Canada.}%\n\n\\author{Nora Tischler}%\n\\affiliation{Centre for Quantum Computation and Communication Technology (Australian Research Council),\nCentre for Quantum Dynamics, Griffith University, Brisbane, Australia.}%\n\n\\author{Xuemei Gu}%\n\\affiliation{\\mpl}%\n\n\\author{Mario Krenn}%\n\\email{mario.krenn@mpl.mpg.de}\n\\affiliation{\\mpl}%\n\n\\begin{abstract}\nPhotons are the physical system of choice for performing experimental tests of the foundations of quantum mechanics. Furthermore, photonic quantum technology is a main player in the second quantum revolution, promising the development of better sensors, secure communications, and quantum-enhanced computation. These endeavors require generating specific quantum states or efficiently performing quantum tasks. The design of the corresponding optical experiments was historically powered by human creativity but is recently being automated with advanced computer algorithms and artificial intelligence. While several computer-designed experiments have been experimentally realized, this approach has not yet been widely adopted by the broader photonic quantum optics community. The main roadblocks consist of most systems being closed-source, inefficient, or targeted to very specific use-cases that are difficult to generalize. Here, we overcome these problems with a highly-efficient, open-source digital discovery framework PyTheus, which can employ a wide range of experimental devices from modern quantum labs to solve various tasks. This includes the discovery of highly entangled quantum states, quantum measurement schemes, quantum communication protocols, multi-particle quantum gates, as well as the optimization of continuous and discrete properties of quantum experiments or quantum states. PyTheus produces interpretable designs for complex experimental problems which human researchers can often readily conceptualize. \\pytheus is an example of a powerful framework that can lead to scientific discoveries -- one of the core goals of artificial intelligence in science. We hope it will help accelerate the development of quantum optics and provide new ideas in quantum hardware and technology.\n%We introduce \\pytheus-an artificial discovery algorithm, to design 100 quantum optics experiments. This project would have been even more difficult in base 12.\n\\end{abstract}\n\n\n\\def\\thefootnote{$\\S$}\\footnotetext{These authors contributed equally to this work.\\\\ The order was decided by a coin flip.}\\def\\thefootnote{\\arabic{footnote}}\n\\maketitle\n\n\\tableofcontents\n\n\n\\section{Introduction}\n\nPhotons, the individual particles of light, have long been used as the core player for fundamental experiments and applications in quantum information science \\cite{pan2012multiphoton}. Photons do not easily interact with their environments; therefore, they can be distributed over large distances -- which makes them a key resource for long-distance quantum communication \\cite{liao2017satellite,liao2018satellite} and experiments that require strict Einstein locality conditions \\cite{hensen2015loophole,shalm2015strong,giustina2015significant}. Using advanced measurement-based quantum computing schemes, photons are among the most promising candidates for future quantum computers \\cite{bartolucci2021fusion}. Entanglement between two or more photons can be produced without a vacuum or cooling, and therefore many advanced experimental results can be achieved directly with table-top setups. Furthermore, the bosonic nature of photons allows for the generation of complex entangled quantum states of indistinguishable photons that are a key resource for quantum-enhanced measurements \\cite{polino2020photonic}. These potential applications have lead to enormous technological advances in integrated chips for fast and precise control of photonic quantum states \\cite{SchaeffIntegrated,wang2018integrated,wang2020integrated,pelucchi2022potential}, high-quality single-photon sources \\cite{wang2019towards,arakawa2020progress,tomm2021bright,uppu2021quantum}, novel photon-pair sources \\cite{santiago2022resonant}, photon number resolving detectors \\cite{singlephotons2011,slussarenko2019photonic}, and advanced high-quality multi-photon interference  \\cite{bouchard2020two,menssen2017distinguishability,feng2021observation,qian2023multiphoton}.\n\nOne question now is how to utilize these technologies to build up exciting new experiments for the foundations of quantum physics and practical quantum hardware.\n\nHistorically, the design of quantum experiments strongly relied on the intuition and creativity of human experts who leverage their experience and come up with blueprints of experiments. However, due to the unintuitive phenomena and enormous combinatorial space of the potential designs, it becomes extremely difficult for human researchers to discover more complex quantum setups. It might be possible that there are high-quality solutions to experimental design questions far outside of the region where humans' intuition fails. How could we possibly find such extraordinary solutions?\n\nThis question has sparked a strong interest in the automated discovery of quantum experiments with computers, overviewed in \\cite{krenn2020computer}. The invention of these tools for quantum optics experiments \\cite{Melvin2016} have indeed overcome experimental limitations and allowed for new avenues in laboratories for entanglement research \\cite{babazadeh2017high,srv332experimentmalik,erhard3dghz,kysela2020path}. One crucial question is whether we can also learn something about physics from these tools. And indeed, several new concepts have been published that were purely discovered through automated design \\cite{Melvin2016}, such as a new general idea of entanglement structure \\cite{krenn2017entanglement}, and generalized constructions of photonic quantum gates \\cite{gao2020computer}. Those concepts were discovered by tedious analysis of the computer's solutions, which was time-consuming. The problem was that the algorithms were powerful enough to find unknown solutions but had no incentive to present a simple, human-understandable form of it.\n\nThis was solved by the invention of \\theseus \\cite{theseus}, an efficient algorithm for the discovery of new quantum experiments that can readily be interpreted by humans. The key insight was a shift in the representation. Rather than describing quantum experiments as quantum optical components on an optical table, experiments are described as graphs of correlations between photons. This representation, which has been a derivative of a computer-discovered concept itself, was developed in \\cite{graphs1,graphs2,graphs3} -- and allows working with a much more natural representation, which can be translated back at any point to an experiment consisting of optical elements. (It should be noted that the representation is independent of photonic graph states for measurement-based quantum computing \\cite{raussendorf2001one,raussendorf2003measurement,briegel2009measurement}, and it is so far unknown how to translate among them.)\n\nIn this paper, we introduce \\pytheus\\footnote{GitHub:\\\\ \\url{https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus}}, a highly-efficient, open-source, automated design and discovery framework for quantum optics experiments. At the core, \\pytheus uses a much extended graph-based representation of quantum optics, which allows us not only to represent entanglement and quantum gates, but lets us design quantum measurements, quantum communication protocols, optimize experimental properties, and discover quantum systems that involve single-photon sources, mixed states, and states entangled in the photon-number basis. Besides the advances of the scientific scope, we note that \\pytheus is written in \\textsc{Python}, and therefore can readily be combined with machine learning frameworks such as \\textsc{TensorFlow} and \\textsc{PyTorch}, and allows for immediate parallelization in computer clusters.\n\nTo showcase the applicability of \\pytheus, we demonstrate the discovery of 100 previously unknown or advanced implementations of quantum optics experiments, ranging from exciting new systems for entanglement research to quantum states from condensed matter physics that are interesting for quantum simulation purposes, new ways of performing quantum communication tasks such as entanglement swapping, new quantum state measurements, and quantum gates. The experiments can involve both probabilistic photon sources and deterministic single-photon sources, and many of them are readily implementable in today's modern quantum optics labs. In the GitHub repository, we present the instructions for \\pytheus that discover each of the examples. We hope that \\pytheus's efficiency, generality, and low entry barrier kick-starts the application of computer-discovered quantum setups in experimental laboratories worldwide, and inspires new exciting computer-inspired ideas and directions for fundamentals and applications of photonic quantum physics research.\n\nWhile the goal of this paper was to demonstrate the discovery capability of \\pytheus, in several cases, it was impossible \\textit{not} to \\textit{see} clear generalizations and reasons why the solutions work. We show this in some cases below. One of the exceptionally interesting concepts we discovered was a new quantum multiphoton interference effect that can simulate probabilistic multi-pair sources just with photon pairs. We describe this new physics concept and its application in a parallel paper \\cite{halopaper}.\n\nThe article is structured in the following way: In section \\ref{section:graphs}, we introduce the graph-based representation of quantum optics, which lies at the heart of \\pytheus. In section \\ref{sec:pytheus}, we introduce the idea of the computational \\pytheus framework, which we then apply to the discovery of 100 new quantum experiments in section \\ref{100exp}. In section \\ref{sec:outlook}, we explain some future(istic) ideas that might lie ahead of us.\n\n\\subsection{Related Work}\nThe first automated and artificial-intelligence-driven design methods for new quantum experiments were introduced in 2016 (for a more detailed review on the topic see \\cite{krenn2020computer,krenn2023artificial}). One of them, \\melvin, was focused on specific photonic quantum information tasks such as quantum state generation and quantum transformations, using discrete learning techniques \\cite{Melvin2016}. The second one, \\textit{Tachikoma}, focused on the discovery of new experimental setups for quantum metrology tasks and used genetic algorithms for discrete optimization \\cite{knott2016search}. \\textit{Tachikoma} has been expanded to incorporate neural network surrogate models to speed up the search process for new quantum-enhanced measurements \\cite{o2019hybrid,nichols2019designing}. At the same time, the ideas of \\melvin have led to numerous implementations of experiments in various laboratories \\cite{babazadeh2017high,srv332experimentmalik,erhard3dghz,kysela2020path} and the extraction of new ideas and concepts in quantum physics \\cite{krenn2017entanglement, gao2020computer}. Automated design tools have helped to build new ways to perform quantum information tasks such as quantum cloning \\cite{zhan2020experimental}. Compared to these tools, \\pytheus does not work on the discrete search space. Discrete spaces are very challenging to navigate as gradients cannot be used. Rather, \\pytheus uses domain knowledge in the form of a new physics-inspired representation that is entirely continuous.%Therefore the search process is significantly faster.\n\nThese ideas have later been expanded by using reinforcement-learning \\cite{melnikov2018active, melnikov2020setting}, for quantum communication \\cite{wallnofer2020machine,valcarce2022automated}, recurrent neural networks \\cite{adler2021quantum}, and deep generative models such as variational autoencoders \\cite{flam2022learning} or logical AI \\cite{cervera2021design}. Compared to these tools, \\pytheus uses direct optimization on the outputs of a physical simulator and does not rely on learned simulators or strategies. That makes it significantly faster.\n\nVarious quantum physics groups and companies have also developed simulators and optimizers since. A main focus there is on the design of experimental settings for photonic quantum computing \\cite{arrazola2019machine,Killoran2019strawberryfields,Quandela_Perceval, BudapestQuantumComputingGroup_Piquasso}. One remarkable simulator is \\textit{Strawberryfields} \\cite{Killoran2019strawberryfields}, which is focused on design and optimization tasks for continuous-variable photonic quantum computing and quantum machine learning tasks. Recent updates include auto-differentiation which significantly speeds up the rate of optimization. A related software package is \\cite{walrus}, which allows for fast computation of tasks related to Gaussian boson sampling. Compared to these tools, the focus of \\pytheus is different. \\pytheus is built for discrete-variable quantum optics, and not targeted to photonic quantum computing (or boson sampling tasks). Furthermore, one main motivation is the interpretability of the discovered results, which is achieved via a topological optimization on the graph-based representation.\n\nAn alternative methodology that focuses not only on the design question but also on understanding the underlying physical concepts is \\theseus \\cite{theseus}. There, the algorithm employs a graph-based representation to describe photonic experiments, and the final results are topologically simplified graphs that can be interpreted and conceptualized in a much more straightforward way than representations that work directly on the optimization of optical elements. Compared to \\theseus, \\pytheus expands this idea and applies it to many new situations, inaccessible before, such as the design of quantum measurement and communication setups via the Choi\u2013Jamio\u0142kowski isomorphism.\n\nRelated work has shown how quantum computers could overcome the enormous computational of designing quantum optical hardware \\cite{kottmann2021quantum}. \n\\pytheus relies, for now, on classical computers, but recent hardware advances might enable the execution of tools like \\pytheus on quantum hardware \\cite{bao2023very}.\n\n\\section{Graphs and Quantum Experiments}\\label{section:graphs}\n\\begin{table}[!b]\n\\renewcommand{\\arraystretch}{1.1}\n    \\centering\n    \\begin{tabular}{c|c|c}\n     \\hline\n        \\multicolumn{2}{c|}{\\textbf{Graph theory}} &  \\textbf{Experiment} \\\\ \\hline\n        \\multicolumn{2}{c|}{\\!\\!color weighted graph\\!\\!}&quantum experiment\\\\ \\hline\n        \\multirow{6}{*}{\\!\\!vertex\\!\\!}& \\begin{tikzpicture}[baseline={([yshift=-.5ex]current bounding box.center)}]\n         \\node[circle, fill=white, thick, draw=black,  scale=1.1](1) at (0,0) {};\n        \\end{tikzpicture} &\\! path to photodetector\\! \\\\\\cline{2-3}\n        \n        & \\begin{tikzpicture}[baseline={([yshift=-.5ex]current bounding box.center)}]\n         \\node[circle, fill=white, thick, draw=black, dotted, scale=1.1](1) at (0,0) {};\n        \\end{tikzpicture} &\\! heralded optical path*\\! \\\\\\cline{2-3}\n       \n        &  \\begin{tikzpicture}[baseline={([yshift=-.5ex]current bounding box.center)}]\n         \\node[regular polygon,regular polygon sides=3, fill=white, thick, draw=black, scale=0.7](1) at (0,0) {};\n        \\end{tikzpicture}& \\!single photon source \\! \\\\\\cline{2-3}\n       \n        &  \\begin{tikzpicture}[baseline={([yshift=-.5ex]current bounding box.center)}]\n         \\node[regular polygon,regular polygon sides=3, fill=white, thick, draw=black, dotted, scale=0.7](1) at (0,0) {};\n        \\end{tikzpicture}& incoming photon  \\\\\\cline{2-3}\n        \n       & \\begin{tikzpicture}[baseline={([yshift=-.5ex]current bounding box.center)}]\n         \\node[regular polygon,regular polygon sides=4, fill=white, thick, draw=black, scale=1](1) at (0,0) {};\n        \\end{tikzpicture}&  ancillary photodetector \\\\\\cline{2-3}\n        \n       & \\begin{tikzpicture}[baseline={([yshift=-.5ex]current bounding box.center)}]\n         \\node[regular polygon,regular polygon sides=6, fill=white, thick, draw=black, scale=1](1) at (0,0) {};\n        \\end{tikzpicture}& \\!\\! number resolving detector\\!\\! \\\\\\cline{2-3}\n       \n       & \\begin{tikzpicture}[baseline={([yshift=-.5ex]current bounding box.center)}]\n         \\node[star, star points=10, fill=white, thick, draw=black, scale=0.8](1) at (0,0) {};\n        \\end{tikzpicture}& \\!environment interaction \\!\\! \\\\\\hline\n        \\multirow{4}{*}{edge} & color& internal mode number\\\\\\cline{2-3}\n         &\\! weight $\\in\\mathbb{C}$ \\!& amplitude** \\\\\\cline{2-3}\n         \n         &\\begin{tikzpicture}[baseline={([yshift=-.5ex]current bounding box.center)}]\n        \\draw[-,draw=black,line width=0.4mm] (-1.1,0) -- (-0.,0);\n        \\node[diamond, fill=white, thick, draw=black, scale=0.6](1) at (-0.5,0) {};\n        \\end{tikzpicture} & negative amplitude \\\\\\cline{2-3}\n        \n         &\\begin{tikzpicture}[baseline={([yshift=-.5ex]current bounding box.center)}]\n         \\node[circle, fill=white, thick, draw=black, scale=1.1](1) at (-1,0) {};\n         \\node[circle, fill=white, thick, draw=black, scale=1.1](1) at (0,0) {};\n        \\draw[-,draw=black,line width=0.4mm] (-0.82,0) -- (-0.18,0);\n        \\end{tikzpicture}& correlated photon pair\\\\\\cline{2-3}\n    \n         &\\begin{tikzpicture}[baseline={([yshift=-.5ex]current bounding box.center)}]\n         \\node[regular polygon,regular polygon sides=3, fill=white, thick, draw=black, scale=0.7](1) at (-1,0) {};\n         \\node[circle, fill=white, thick, draw=black, scale=1.1](1) at (0,0) {};\n         \\draw[-,draw=black,line width=0.4mm] (-0.82,0) -- (-0.15,0);\n        \\end{tikzpicture}& single photon path\\\\\\hline\n       \n    \\end{tabular}\n    \\caption{The correspondence between graph theory and quantum experiments. *For some experiments one must known the total amount of photons crossing a group of optical paths (see section \\ref{sec:noon_states}). This is clarified in the graph figures with a gray envelop. **Unless the contrary is specified, all weights are real values.}\n    \\label{tab:graph-experiment-link}\n\\end{table}\nThe connection between quantum optical experiments and graph theory was discovered a few years ago \\cite{graphs1,graphs2,graphs3} and has been further developed as a design algorithm \\theseus for new quantum experiments \\cite{theseus}. In the graph-experiment representation, each colored weighted graph corresponds to a quantum experimental setup, and \\textit{vice versa}. Each edge and each vertex of the graph represent a correlated photon pair and a photon path, respectively. Its complex weight denotes the amplitude of the photon pair, and the edge color represents a photon's internal mode number for a given path, which corresponds to the photon's degree of freedom such as polarization \\cite{polarizationERP1995}, path \\cite{wang2018integrated,lu2020three,pelucchi2022potential}, transverse spatial modes \\cite{rubinsztein2016roadmap,padgett2017orbital,bouchard2017high,bavaresco2018measurements}, time-bin \\cite{timebin1989} or frequency \\cite{frequencybin2010,santiago2022resonant}. This abstract graph representation allows us to have the full information of quantum optical experiments and has been used for discovering quantum states and transformations \\cite{theseus}. At first glance, it might seem that there is fundamentally no difference between the path degree of freedom (which is encoded as vertices) and the internal degrees of freedom of photons (which are encoded as colors of edges). However, this is only true information theoretically. Physically, the path degree of freedom is exceptional, because it allows to add spatially separation between photons and thereby perform non-locality experiments.\n\n\nHere we significantly extend the bridge between graphs and experiments, which allows us to perform design and discovery tasks for quantum state generation (for pure and mixed states and on the photon number basis), quantum measurements, quantum communication protocols, and gates for quantum computing. In Table.~\\ref{tab:graph-experiment-link}, we show the correspondence between graph theory and quantum experiments. The graph representation can be directly translated into different experimental implementations. In the remaining part of this section, we explain how these graphs encode quantum states, and how to translate them to experimental setups.\n\n\n\n\n\\subsection{Quantum State Generation} \\label{sec:stategeneration}\n\\subsubsection{Probabilistic Photon-Pair Sources} \\label{sec:p2ps}\n\nProbabilistic photon-pair sources, which are typically based on nonlinear processes such as spontaneous parametric down conversion (SPDC) and four-wave mixing (FWM) \\cite{boyd2020nonlinear}, are one of the most widespread resources to generate entangled and correlated pairs of photons. A range of photonic quantum experiments using probabilistic sources can be interpreted as a weighted colored graph \\cite{theseus,graphs1,graphs2,graphs3}. There, each vertex represents an optical path to a detector and each edge refers to the correlated photon pair produced by a probabilistic photon-pair source. The edge weight is the amplitude associated with the photons, and the edge color describes the photon's internal mode number (i.e., the degree of freedom of a photon). The connection between the graph and the corresponding quantum state is given by the weight function \\cite{theseus}\n\\begin{align}\n    \\Phi(\\boldsymbol{\\omega})=\\sum_m \\frac{1}{m!} \\left( \\sum_{e \\in E(G)} \\omega(e) x^\\dagger(e) y^\\dagger(e) + \\text{h.c.}\\right)^m,\n    \\label{eq:weightfunction}\n\\end{align}\nwhere $E(G)$ is the set of edges of the graph. The quantum state is obtained by applying the weight function to the vacuum, i.e. $\\ket{\\psi}=\\Phi(\\boldsymbol{\\omega})\\ket{\\text{vac}}$. The term h.c. stands for hermitian conjugate, which includes annihilation operators. As an example of states using four path (i.e., $a$, $b$, $c$, and $d$) with two-dimensional internal modes (i.e., $0$ and $1$) in Fig.~\\ref{fig:Twodim_graph_pm_example}, the $\\Phi(\\boldsymbol{\\omega)}$ is given as\n\\begin{align}\n    \\Phi(\\boldsymbol{\\omega})\\approx\\sum_{N}&\\frac{1}{N!}( \\omega_{a,b}^{0,0}a^\\dagger_0 b^\\dagger_0 + \\omega_{b,d}^{1,1}b^\\dagger_1 d^\\dagger_1 \\notag \\\\\n    &+ \\omega_{c,d}^{0,0}c^\\dagger_0 d^\\dagger_0 + \\omega_{a,c}^{1,1}c^\\dagger_1 a^\\dagger_1 + \\text{h.c.})^N,\n    \\label{eq:pairsource}\n\\end{align}\nwhere $\\boldsymbol{\\omega}=(\\omega_{a,b}^{0,0},\\omega_{b,d}^{1,1},\\omega_{c,d}^{0,0},\\omega_{a,c}^{1,1})$ is a list of edge weights $\\omega_{x,y}^{i,j}\\in\\mathbb{C}$ and $|\\omega_{x,y}^{i,j}|^2<1$, the superscript and subscript represent the mode number and the optical path, respectively. $x^\\dagger_{k}$ is the creation  operator of a photon in path $x$ with mode $k$. The pair-emission process is up to the $\\text{N}$-order, and the probability of occurrence for lower-order events is higher than that of higher-order ones. In principle, the hermitian conjugate terms influence the final state. However, for the low pump regime, the effect of the annihilation terms is negligible in many cases. For example this is the case when the final state is conditioned on having a photon in every detector. In all of the examples that we present here, it is safe to neglect the annihilation operators. \n\nAn alternative method to compute these systems in a non-approximate way is to follow the Takagi decomposition (see \\cite{PhysRevA.100.032326}, specifically Eq.27) , which leads to reliable solutions also in the strong-pump regime. Naturally, this method is more expensive to compute. In our manuscript, we do not need to use this more involved method, as the low-pump approximation holds with high accuracy. \n\\begin{figure}[!t]\n\t\\centering\n\t\\includegraphics[width=0.48\\textwidth]{graph_2d4pGHZ_example.pdf} \n \\caption {An abstract graph representation of quantum experiments producing GHZ states. There, edges and vertices represent correlated photon-pair and optical paths, respectively. The edge colors and weights $\\boldsymbol\\omega$ are mode numbers and complex coefficients. The blue and red colors refer to the mode numbers 0 and 1, respectively. There are two perfect matchings (i.e., a subgraph that covers all vertices only once), and their coherent superposition leads to a quantum state $\\ket{\\psi}=\\omega_{a,b}^{0,0} \\omega_{c,d}^{0,0} \\ket{0000} + \\omega_{a,c}^{1,1} \\omega_{b,d}^{1,1}\\ket{1111}$ (without normalization). We can get a four-qubit GHZ state by setting all weights equal. The graph can be translated into several quantum setups with different technologies, such as entanglement by path identity or path encoding used in integrated photonics or standard bulk optics (e.g., using polarization encoding). The squares I-IV are probabilistic sources that create photon pairs. For clearer presentation, we draw the source in the color corresponding to the mode they contribute.}\n \\label{fig:Twodim_graph_pm_example}\n\\end{figure}\nExperimentally, a common way to obtain a quantum state is to condition the experimental results on a simultaneous detection event in each detector, which is also called the $n$-fold coincidence detection. In our graph representation, this only happens when a subset of the edges contains each of the $n$ vertices exactly once (see the subset of blue edges or red edges in Fig.~\\ref{fig:Twodim_graph_pm_example}), which is the so-called perfect matching of a graph. For the example in Fig.~\\ref{fig:Twodim_graph_pm_example}, we neglect the empty mode and higher-order terms $N>2$ to post-select the quantum state. There are two perfect matchings (two blue edges and two red edges) in Fig.~\\ref{fig:Twodim_graph_pm_example}, which contribute to two quantum terms $\\ket{0000}$ and $\\ket{1111}$. The weight of a perfect matching is the product of all its edge weights. For each term in a quantum state, the weight is given by the sum of all weights of the perfect matchings that contribute to it. Therefore, the weights for quantum terms $\\ket{0000}$ and $\\ket{1111}$ are $\\omega_{a,b}^{0,0} \\omega_{c,d}^{0,0}$ and $\\omega_{a,c}^{1,1} \\omega_{b,d}^{1,1}$, respectively. In the end, a coherent superposition of the two perfect matchings in the graph leads to the post-selected quantum state, which is\n\\begin{equation}\n    \\ket{\\psi}\\approx\\omega_{a,b}^{0,0} \\omega_{c,d}^{0,0} \\ket{0000} + \\omega_{a,c}^{1,1} \\omega_{b,d}^{1,1}\\ket{1111}.\n    \\label{eq:2dGHZ}\n\\end{equation} \nIf we set all weights the same and normalize the state, we can then reach a four-particle Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ) state. \n\n\\paragraph{Translation to Experiments --}\\label{sec:translation} A colored weighted graph can directly be translated into several quantum optical experiments using different technologies \\cite{theseus}, as shown in Fig.~\\ref{fig:Twodim_graph_pm_example}. The most straightforward way is applying the concept of entanglement by path identity \\cite{krenn2017entanglement, kysela2020path,RevModPhysPI2022}, for which the graph representation has initially been designed \\cite{graphs1}. In this scheme shown on the left side of Fig.~\\ref{fig:Twodim_graph_pm_example}, paths of indistinguishable photons produced from multiple crystals are overlapped, leading to a coherent superposition of possible origins for a photon. Equipped with the graph-experimental correspondence in Table \\ref{tab:graph-experiment-link}, we now translate four edges and vertices into four photon-pair sources and optical paths. Here, we encode photon's internal mode number in polarization such that blue and red edge colors in the graph depict horizontal and vertical polarization, respectively. The four sources are set up in such a way that two sources (blue edges) produce photons with states $\\ket{00}$ while the other two (red edges) produce photons with states $\\ket{11}$. We then pump all sources coherently and consider that two of the four sources produce a photon pair in this example. Conditionally on perfect matching or post-selection, we have only two cases (two-photon pairs come either from the sources I and II or from the sources III and IV) that contribute to the final quantum state in Eq.~\\eqref{eq:2dGHZ}. All other combinations of sources do not lead to only one photon in each of the detectors. For example, a photon pair in crystals I and III leads to two photons in $a$, one photon in $b$, and $c$, but no photon in $d$; therefore, this case is disregarded. If the mode numbers are indistinguishable, one can observe a new form of multi-photon interference, which has first been experimentally observed in \\cite{feng2021observation,qian2023multiphoton} and which forms the basis of many of the proposed experiments below.\n\nAnother promising technology is using integrated photonic, which usually uses path encoding \\cite{SchaeffIntegrated,wang2018integrated,wang2020integrated,pelucchi2022potential}, where each photon's one mode goes to one detector, as shown in the bottom middle-part of Fig.~\\ref{fig:Twodim_graph_pm_example}. In this example, each photon has two path modes depicted in blue and red colors, respectively. Therefore, one can consider that each vertex in Fig.~\\ref{fig:Twodim_graph_pm_example} actually contains two sub-detectors that directly connect to the paths for the photon's two-mode numbers (i.e., blue and red paths). The vertex is activated when only one of the two sub-detectors clicks. In this way, perfect matching means the situations where four sub-detectors click in either blue paths or red paths, leading to the desired quantum state.
