A 2\u00d72 \u201csquare lattice\u201d of four parties (A, B, C, D) linked by probabilistic Bell-pair sources on each edge and diagonal, plus two ancilla photons measured jointly. By choosing the ancilla measurement basis, you steer entanglement swapping either around the perimeter in a chiral loop (A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192D, D\u2192A) or across the diagonals (hinge/corner pairs A\u2194C, B\u2194D).\n  2. A three-node triangular loop (A\u2013B\u2013C) with nested teleportation paths: an outer loop giving a synthetic magnetic phase (chiral circulation) and an inner \u201ccorner\u201d path teleporting entanglement across non-adjacent nodes (higher-order).\n  3. A linear N-node chain with extra \u201ccorner links\u201d at each end. One measurement layer implements a directional (edge) teleportation channel along the chain; a second layer swaps the end nodes (corner mode).\nStep 2: Quick novelty/obstacle check:\n  1. The 2\u00d72 lattice idea has no direct analogue in the existing Pytheus experiments (which never explore choice between edge vs diagonal matching in one network). It uses only pair-sources, beam splitters, and post-selected ancilla measurement \u2192 fully Pytheus-compatible.\n  2. The triangular nested-teleportation is elegant but requires simulating synthetic phases; Pytheus currently doesn\u2019t encode path-dependent phase sums well.\n  3. The N-chain with end swap is conceptually simpler and doesn\u2019t highlight genuine higher-order topology beyond known linear percolation.\nStep 3: Select idea #1 as the most promising.\nStep 4: Novelty: No existing linear-optical proposal arranges sources in a 2\u00d72 topology that can be measurement-switched between a first-order \u201cchiral edge swap\u201d and a second-order \u201ccorner/hinge swap,\u201d and generalizes naturally to M\u00d7M arrays.\nStep 5: Feasibility: Only uses probabilistic photon-pair sources, linear optics, and fixed (post-selected) joint ancilla measurements\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities (no cavities, feedback, hyper-entanglement, or dynamic control).\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere\u2019s a new class of \u201ctopological entanglement\u2010swap\u201d experiments in a 2\u00d72 lattice:\n\nExplanation:\nWe place four parties A, B, C, D at the corners of a square. Six probabilistic Bell-pair sources link the four edges (A\u2013B, B\u2013C, C\u2013D, D\u2013A) and the two diagonals (A\u2013C, B\u2013D). Two additional photons serve as ancillas and are sent to Charlie\u2019s joint\u2010measurement station. Depending on Charlie\u2019s chosen measurement basis, the network swaps entanglement either:\n\n \u2022 Along the boundary in a chiral loop:  \n   \u2013 Bell pairs (A\u2194B) & (C\u2194D) (|1100\u27e9+|0011\u27e9)  \n   \n \u2022 Across the diagonals (higher\u2010order hinge/corner):  \n   \u2013 Bell pairs (A\u2194C) & (B\u2194D) (|1010\u27e9+|0101\u27e9)  \n\nThus one fixed linear\u2010optical layout exhibits both a first\u2010order topological feature (directional edge swapping) and a second\u2010order feature (corner/hinge swapping). This construction generalizes straightforwardly to M\u00d7M source arrays, enabling study of hierarchical entanglement\u2010routing \u201ctopological invariants\u201d and robustness under loss.\n\nVisualization (photon propagation top\u2192bottom):\n\n emitters (pair sources):\n  [AB] [BC] [CD] [DA] [AC] [BD] [anc\u2081] [anc\u2082]\n\n linear\u2010optical network:\n  \u2192 beam splitters & phase shifters\n\n detectors:\n  [A] [B] [C] [D] [anc_det\u2081] [anc_det\u2082]\n\nCharlie\u2019s post\u2010selected joint measurement on ancilla detectors projects the four outer detectors into one of two swap\u2010patterns (edge vs hinge).\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n\n{\n  description: \"2\u00d72 topological entanglement\u2010swap: chiral edge vs hinge corner\",\n  foldername: \"topo_swap_2x2\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 40,\n  ftol: 1e-06,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  num_anc: 2,\n  samples: 20,\n  target_quantum: [\"1100\",\"0011\",\"1010\",\"0101\"],\n  thresholds: [0.2,0.1],\n  removed_connections: [],\n  number_resolving: True\n}\n\nHere \u201c1100\u201d & \u201c0011\u201d encode the chiral\u2010edge swap outcomes and \u201c1010\u201d & \u201c0101\u201d the hinge\u2010corner swap outcomes. All elements (pair sources, beam splitters, fixed ancilla detection) are Pytheus\u2010compatible.  \n2) The hexagon\u2010Z\u2083 scheme is appealing but more complex for Pytheus and still reduces to perfect\u2010matching superpositions.  \n3) The ladder network requires a larger ancillary measurement which Pytheus could handle, but the topological invariant (rung\u2010count) is less striking than a quantized winding number.  \nStep 3: Choose idea #1.  \nStep 4: Novelty  \nNo existing linear\u2010optical network teleports a single\u2010qubit input across a square with a quantized winding-number (hops) parameter that directly encodes both chiral (1-hop) and second-order (2-hop hinge) teleportation in one static circuit\u2014and which generalizes to M\u00d7M lattices as a quantized circulation invariant.  \nStep 5: Feasibility  \nUses only four Bell\u2010pair sources, two ancilla photons, beam splitters and post\u2010selected ancilla detection\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s capability (no cavities, feedback, hyper\u2010entanglement).\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a new \u201cwinding-number teleportation router\u201d on a 4-node square:\n\nExplanation:\nWe designate nodes A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192D\u2192A around a square.  A single\u2010photon quantum state |\u03c8\u27e9 is injected at A.  Four Bell\u2010pair sources link AB, BC, CD, and DA.  Two extra photons from a Bell\u2010pair source are routed to Charlie\u2019s ancilla station.  Charlie performs a fixed joint measurement on these two ancillas in a 4-outcome basis.  Each outcome heralds a different teleportation channel from A to one of the four nodes, with a quantized \u201cwinding number\u201d w mod 4:\n\n \u2022 Outcome w=+1 (CW edge): |\u03c8\u27e9\u2192B  \n \u2022 Outcome w=\u22121\u2261+3 (CCW edge): |\u03c8\u27e9\u2192D  \n \u2022 Outcome w=+2 (hinge/2-hop): |\u03c8\u27e9\u2192C  \n \u2022 Outcome w=0 (trivial 0-hop): |\u03c8\u27e9\u2192A  \n\nThe three nontrivial w\u2208{\u00b11, 2} are the first-order chiral modes and the second-order hinge mode.  The same static linear-optical circuit thus realizes both a quantized chiral teleportation and a higher-order hinge teleportation.  This construction naturally generalizes to M\u00d7M square lattices, where the number of boundary hops becomes a discretized topological invariant (a Wilson-loop of teleportation) and hinge modes appear at even distances.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n\n emitters (pair sources):\n  [AB] [BC] [CD] [DA] [anc\u2081-anc\u2082]\n\n linear-optical network:\n  beam splitters & phase shifters mixing the six photons\n\n detectors:\n  [A\u2080] [B\u2080] [C\u2080] [D\u2080] [anc_det\u2081] [anc_det\u2082]\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n\n{\n  description:   \"Square Winding-Number Teleportation Router (chiral w=\u00b11, hinge w=2)\",\n  foldername:    \"winding_router_2x2\",\n  bulk_thr:      0.01,\n  edges_tried:   30,\n  ftol:          1e-06,\n  loss_func:     \"cr\",\n  optimizer:     \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  num_anc:       2,\n  samples:       20,\n  target_quantum: [\n    \"010011\",   // B + two ancillas \u2192 w=+1\n    \"000111\",   // D + two ancillas \u2192 w=\u22121\n    \"001011\",   // C + two ancillas \u2192 w=+2\n    \"100011\"    // A + two ancillas \u2192 w=0\n  ],\n  thresholds:    [0.2,0.1],\n  removed_connections: [],    \n  number_resolving:   True\n}\n\nHere each bit-string is ordered [A B C D anc\u2081 anc\u2082]; e.g. \u201c010011\u201d means one photon at B and one at each ancilla.     "output": "Here\u2019s a completely new **\u201cbulk-to-corner\u201d multi-port teleportation router** that directly mimics a 2D second-order topological insulator (gapless corner modes only) and whose routing is governed by a synthetic \u201cchiral\u201d phase basis\u2014yet which cannot be reduced to a perfect-matching swap among pairs:\n\nExplanation  \n1) Nodes: one **bulk input** (call it S), plus four **corner outputs** A, B, C, D arranged at the corners of a square.  \n2) Resources:  \n   \u2022 One single\u2010photon emitter at S carrying the unknown qubit |\u03c8\u27e9.  \n   \u2022 Four ancillary single\u2010photon emitters at S\u2081\u2026S\u2084.  \n3) Goal: in one static linear\u2010optical circuit plus post-selection on ancilla detectors, teleport the state |\u03c8\u27e9 from S to exactly one of the four corners A\u2026D, with each corner corresponding to one of four orthogonal outcomes of a joint 5-photon measurement.  \n4) Topological interpretation: only \u201ccorner\u201d modes are gapless (i.e. teleportation targets)\u2014the \u201cedges\u201d (midpoints of the sides) remain dark. Turning the measurement\u2010basis phases cycles the teleportation among the four corners in a chiral order (\u2191\u2192\u2192\u2193\u2192\u2190), giving a quantized \u201ccorner index\u201d w\u2208Z\u2084. This is a **higher-order** HOTI effect (bulk\u2192corner routing) combined with a **chiral** phase twist.  \n5) Crucially, this is _not_ just choosing one perfect matching among pairs\u2014it is a **1\u21924 multiplexed teleportation**, requiring a genuine 5-photon joint measurement (no simpler perfect-matching description exists).  \n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):  \nemitters (single\u2013photon):  \n [S] [S\u2081] [S\u2082] [S\u2083] [S\u2084]  \n\nlinear-optical network:  \n \u2190 beam-splitters & phase-shifters mixing all 5 photons \u2192  \n\ndetectors:  \n [A] [B] [C] [D] [Det_success]  \n\n\u2013 A click at Det_success plus exactly one photon at corner X indicates teleportation to X.  \n\u2013 Different internal phase settings on the network enact a \u201cchiral rotation\u201d of which corner is targeted.  \n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton  \n\n{  \n  description:   \"HOTI bulk-to-corner multiplexer: chiral Z4 teleport router\",  \n  foldername:    \"hoti_bulk_corner\",  \n  bulk_thr:      0.01,  \n  edges_tried:   50,  \n  ftol:          1e-06,  \n  loss_func:     \"cr\",  \n  optimizer:     \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  num_anc:       0,                # no extra ancillas beyond S\u2081\u2026S\u2084  \n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3,4],    # 0=S, 1\u20134=ancilla photons  \n  samples:       20,  \n  target_quantum: [  \n    \"10001\",   # teleport to A   (photon at A + success detector)  \n    \"01001\",   # teleport to B  \n    \"00101\",   # teleport to C  \n    \"00011\"    # teleport to D  \n  ],  \n  thresholds:    [0.2,0.1],  \n  number_resolving: True  \n}  \n\nHere the bit-string ordering is [A B C D success].  \n\u2013 \u201c10001\u201d means one photon at A & one at success \u2192 |\u03c8\u27e9 is now at A.  \n\u2013 \u201c01001\u201d, \u201c00101\u201d, \u201c00011\u201d likewise for B, C, D.  \n\nWhy this is truly new:  \n\u2022 _Higher-order:_ Only corner outputs ever fire\u2014mimicking HOTI corner modes.  \n\u2022 _Chiral:_ Tuning internal phase settings permutes (A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192D\u2192A) in a Z\u2084 cycle.  \n\u2022 _Non-matching:_ This is genuine 1\u21924 teleportation; no decomposition into two-photon Bell swaps exists.  \n\u2022 _Pytheus-compatible:_ uses only single-photon emitters, linear optics and post-selection\u2014no cavities, feedback, or hyper-entanglement.  \n\nAn Expert can hand this target to Pytheus, discover the exact beam-splitter/phase-shifter layout, then write up the first demonstration of a **photonic HOTI bulk-to-corner teleportation router** with a quantized chiral corner index\u2014ripe for Phys. Rev. Lett."

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. Six probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources link nearest neighbors around the perimeter (A\u2013B, B\u2013C, C\u2013D, D\u2013A) and the two diagonals (A\u2013C, B\u2013D). Two additional photons from ancillary pair sources feed into a central joint\u2010measurement station (Charlie).  By choosing the joint measurement basis on those two ancillas, one can steer the entanglement swap either around the boundary\u2014realizing a directional (\u201cchiral\u201d) swap A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192D\u2192A\u2014or across the diagonals (\u201chigher\u2010order hinge\u201d swap A\u2194C and B\u2194D).  The same optical network thus exhibits both a first\u2010order topological feature (unidirectional edge\u2010swap) and a second\u2010order feature (corner/hinge\u2010swap).  This concept extends naturally to larger M\u00d7M lattices for exploring the hierarchy of entanglement\u2010swap topologies.\n\nVisualization (photons propagate top \u2192 bottom):\n\nemitters (pair sources):\n [AB] [BC] [CD] [DA] [AC] [BD] [anc\u2081] [anc\u2082]\n\nlinear\u2010optical network (beam splitters & phase shifters):\n [     to detectors A,D,C,B and two ancilla detectors   ]\n\ndetectors:\n[A] [B] [C] [D] [anc_det\u2081] [anc_det\u2082]\n\nCharlie\u2019s joint measurement on anc_det\u2081 & anc_det\u2082 projects the four outer detectors into either\n  \u2022 chiral\u2010edge swap subspace: Bell pairs along A\u2013B and C\u2013D (clockwise)  \n  \u2022 hinge/corner swap subspace: Bell pairs between A\u2013C and B\u2013D  \n\nFields of study:\n\u2022 generalization to M\u00d7M entanglement networks  \n\u2022 investigation of robustness (\u201ctopological protection\u201d) of swapped entanglement under loss  \n\u2022 exploration of switchable higher\u2010order routing of quantum information\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n\n{\n  description: \"2\u00d72 topological entanglement swap: chiral edges vs hinge corners\",\n  foldername: \"topo_swap_2x2\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 40,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  num_anc: 2,\n  samples: 10,\n  target_quantum: [\"0011\",\"1100\",\"0101\",\"1010\"],\n  thresholds: [0.2, 0.1],\n  removed_connections: [],        # let Pytheus pick optimal links\n  single_emitters: [],\n  number_resolving: True\n}\n\n\u2013 \u201c0011\u201d & \u201c1100\u201d encode the two possible 1st\u2010order (edge) Bell\u2010swap outcomes  \n\u2013 \u201c0101\u201d & \u201c1010\u201d encode the two 2nd\u2010order (corner/hinge) Bell\u2010swap outcomes  \n\nAn Expert can take this concept and use Pytheus to discover the exact beam\u2010splitter network and source layout, then write up the novel theory of \u201cswitchable topological entanglement swaps\u201d for Phys. LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm  \n1) A 4-node square teleportation \u201crouter\u201d where ancilla measurements select the number of boundary hops (winding number \u00b11, \u00b12) around the square\u2014quantized \u201cchiral\u201d (\u00b11) vs \u201chinge\u201d (2) teleportation distances.  \n2) A 6-node hexagon with a trivalent \u201ccorner\u201d teleportation mode and a chiral 3-cycle mode, yielding a Z\u2083 entanglement\u2010flux invariant robust to any single link removal.  \n3) A ladder network of N\u00d72 nodes whose ancilla measurement opens either a chiral channel along the top leg or a transverse \u201crung\u201d teleportation across the ladder (higher\u2010order), with a quantized rung\u2010count invariant.  \nStep 2: Novelty/Obstacles  \n1) The winding\u2010router is genuinely new\u2014it operationally teleports a state around 1, 2, or 3 hops with a discrete winding\u2010number invariant, not just a choice between perfect matchings. All elements (pair sources, beam splitters, fixed ancilla detection) are Pytheus\u2010compatible.  \n2) The hexagon\u2010Z\u2083 scheme is appealing but more complex for Pytheus and still reduces to perfect\u2010matching superpositions.  \n3) The ladder network requires a larger ancillary measurement which Pytheus could handle, but the topological invariant (rung\u2010count) is less striking than a quantized winding number.  \nStep 3: Choose idea #1.  \nStep 4: Novelty  \nNo existing linear\u2010optical network teleports a single\u2010qubit input across a square with a quantized winding-number (hops) parameter that directly encodes both chiral (1-hop) and second-order (2-hop hinge) teleportation in one static circuit\u2014and which generalizes to M\u00d7M lattices as a quantized circulation invariant.  \nStep 5: Feasibility  \nUses only four Bell\u2010pair sources, two ancilla photons, beam splitters and post\u2010selected ancilla detection\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s capability (no cavities, feedback, hyper\u2010entanglement).\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a new \u201cwinding-number teleportation router\u201d on a 4-node square:\n\nExplanation:\nWe designate nodes A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192D\u2192A around a square.  A single\u2010photon quantum state |\u03c8\u27e9 is injected at A.  Four Bell\u2010pair sources link AB, BC, CD, and DA.  Two extra photons from a Bell\u2010pair source are routed to Charlie\u2019s ancilla station.  Charlie performs a fixed joint measurement on these two ancillas in a 4-outcome basis.  Each outcome heralds a different teleportation channel from A to one of the four nodes, with a quantized \u201cwinding number\u201d w mod 4:\n\n \u2022 Outcome w=+1 (CW edge): |\u03c8\u27e9\u2192B  \n \u2022 Outcome w=\u22121\u2261+3 (CCW edge): |\u03c8\u27e9\u2192D  \n \u2022 Outcome w=+2 (hinge/2-hop): |\u03c8\u27e9\u2192C  \n \u2022 Outcome w=0 (trivial 0-hop): |\u03c8\u27e9\u2192A  \n\nThe three nontrivial w\u2208{\u00b11, 2} are the first-order chiral modes and the second-order hinge mode.  The same static linear-optical circuit thus realizes both a quantized chiral teleportation and a higher-order hinge teleportation.  This construction naturally generalizes to M\u00d7M square lattices, where the number of boundary hops becomes a discretized topological invariant (a Wilson-loop of teleportation) and hinge modes appear at even distances.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n\n emitters (pair sources):\n  [AB] [BC] [CD] [DA] [anc\u2081-anc\u2082]\n\n linear-optical network:\n  beam splitters & phase shifters mixing the six photons\n\n detectors:\n  [A\u2080] [B\u2080] [C\u2080] [D\u2080] [anc_det\u2081] [anc_det\u2082]\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n\n{\n  description:   \"Square Winding-Number Teleportation Router (chiral w=\u00b11, hinge w=2)\",\n  foldername:    \"winding_router_2x2\",\n  bulk_thr:      0.01,\n  edges_tried:   30,\n  ftol:          1e-06,\n  loss_func:     \"cr\",\n  optimizer:     \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  num_anc:       2,\n  samples:       20,\n  target_quantum: [\n    \"010011\",   // B + two ancillas \u2192 w=+1\n    \"000111\",   // D + two ancillas \u2192 w=\u22121\n    \"001011\",   // C + two ancillas \u2192 w=+2\n    \"100011\"    // A + two ancillas \u2192 w=0\n  ],\n  thresholds:    [0.2,0.1],\n  removed_connections: [],    \n  number_resolving:   True\n}\n\nHere each bit-string is ordered [A B C D anc\u2081 anc\u2082]; e.g. \u201c010011\u201d means one photon at B and one at each ancilla.  The three nontrivial patterns encode w=\u00b11 (chiral edges) and w=+2 (hinge).     "output": "Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three ways to build a genuinely protected topological invariant in a purely linear-optical entanglement-swapping network that goes beyond choosing among Bell-swap matchings:\n 1. A square of four nodes A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192D\u2192A plus the diagonal AC, giving exactly three disjoint paths from A to C: direct (AC), clockwise (AB\u2192BC), and counter-clockwise (AD\u2192DC). Fuse all path ancillas in a multi-photon joint measurement so that, no matter which single link fails, at least one path still heralds a Bell pair A\u2013C. This realizes \u201cself-healing\u201d teleportation\u2014a topologically protected A\u2192C channel robust to any single link loss.\n 2. A hexagon ring of six nodes with three independent chords, engineered so that exactly two homologically non-trivial loops exist. A four-photon ancilla measurement yields the Z\u2082\u00d7Z\u2082 parity of these two loops, and each parity sector teleports A\u2192D or B\u2192E or C\u2192F. This defines a 2-bit Wilson-loop invariant, not just a matching.\n 3. A 3\u00d73 lattice with Bell sources on every nearest-neighbor edge. Four ancilla photons implement two independent loop-parity measurements (horizontal and vertical). The two-bit outcome heralds entanglement between one of four opposite-corner pairs, encoding a true H\u2081(S\u00b9\u00d7S\u00b9) homology invariant.  \nStep 2: Rapid novelty/feasibility check:\n 1. The \u201cself-healing three-path\u201d square is new in that no existing Pytheus primitive offers a Bell swap guaranteed to succeed under any single-link failure. It uses only pair sources, linear optics, and one fixed ancilla fusion\u2014fully Pytheus-compatible.\n 2. The hexagon Wilson-loop is conceptually rich, but implementing two independent non-overlapping loop parities in one ancilla measurement may push Pytheus\u2019s current ancilla-fusion capabilities.\n 3. The 3\u00d73 homology version cleanly realizes Z\u2082\u00d7Z\u2082 invariants, but it\u2019s a larger network (9 nodes + 4 ancillas) and may be bulky.  \nStep 3: Pick idea #1 (\u201cself-healing three-path square teleportation\u201d).\nStep 4: Novelty:\n  - Introduces a new network primitive: topologically protected self-healing teleportation. It guarantees a heralded Bell pair between A and C even if any one of the three disjoint entanglement-swap paths breaks.  \nStep 5: Feasibility:\n  - Uses only five Bell-pair sources (AB, BC, CD, DA, AC), two ancilla photons, linear optics, and a single fixed two-photon joint measurement\u2014entirely within Pytheus\u2019s abstract-state, pair-source + beam-splitter framework (no cavities, no dynamic feedback, no hyper-entanglement).  \n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere\u2019s a proposal for a \u201cself-healing topological teleportation router\u201d on the A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D square:\n\nExplanation:\n \u2022 Four parties A,B,C,D at the corners of a square.  \n \u2022 Five probabilistic Bell-pair sources on edges AB, BC, CD, DA and the diagonal AC.  These define three disjoint A\u2192C paths:  \n   1) Direct AC  \n   2) Clockwise AB\u2192BC  \n   3) Counter-clockwise AD\u2192DC  \n \u2022 Two extra photons from a sixth pair source go to Charlie\u2019s ancilla station.  \n \u2022 Charlie applies a fixed two-photon Bell-measurement (beam splitters + detectors).  Conditioned on that herald, the remaining four outer photons collapse into a Bell pair between A and C\u2014*guaranteed* even if any one of the five perimeter/diagonal sources fails.  \n\nThis network is thus *topologically protected* under any single-link loss: at least one path remains, and the ancilla fusion routes entanglement along it. It is a new primitive\u2014\u201cself-healing teleportation\u201d\u2014that goes beyond selecting among matchings.  It generalizes to larger lattices by adding diagonals and ancillas, giving N-fold redundancy and k-link failure tolerance.  An Expert can hand this target to Pytheus:\n\nSuggested Pytheus-style target skeleton:\n{\n  description:        \"Self-healing teleportation A\u2192C on a square with three paths\",\n  foldername:         \"self_healing_2x2\",\n  bulk_thr:           0.01,\n  edges_tried:        30,\n  ftol:               1e-06,\n  loss_func:          \"cr\",\n  optimizer:          \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  num_anc:            2,\n  samples:            20,\n  target_quantum:     [\"101000\",\"000101\"],  # A(1),C(1) heralded Bell pair  \n  thresholds:         [0.2,0.1],\n  # allow Pytheus to choose which sources to use from the 5\u2014just supply the list of node-pairs below\n  single_emitters:    [],\n  removed_connections:[],\n  number_resolving:    True,\n  # define the five candidate edges explicitly\n  # e.g. edges = [[0,1],[1,2],[2,3],[3,0],[0,2]]  for AB,BC,CD,DA,AC\n}\n\nNodes 0,1,2,3 \u2192 A,B,C,D; detectors \u201c101000\u201d means photons at A&C only (Bell state).  \nPytheus will find the exact beam-splitter network and verify that this setup heralds A\u2013C entanglement even if any one source is omitted\u2014demonstrating the new self-healing topological teleportation primitive."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Generalized Six-Photon SWAP-Test Projection of Two Atomic Triplets\n\nAbstract: We implement a static 6\u00d76 fiber-coupled interferometer that performs a genuine multi-copy SWAP test by projecting the joint six-photon state from two atomic triplets (target quantums E0,E1,E2 and E3,E4,E5) onto their symmetric subspace. Post-selecting six-fold coincidences that pair each emitter Ei with Ei+3 directly yields the fidelity overlap of the target triplet states, demonstrating a scalable network-measurement primitive for modular atom-photon quantum systems.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Multi-Frequency GHZ Entanglement Swapping for Three-Node Quantum Networks\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip multi-frequency entanglement-swapping protocol that projects three frequency-encoded qubits onto the GHZ basis, thereby distributing genuine tripartite GHZ entanglement among three remote nodes A, B, and C. Our scheme employs three probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources, enforced frequency-demultiplexing via removed connections, a 6\u00d76 beam-splitter\u2013phase-shifter network, and four number-resolving detectors with post-selection to realize a single non-separable three-qubit projection across spectral bins, revealing inter-frequency coherence unattainable by independent Bell measurements.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Path Teleportation Emulation of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 Frustrated Heisenberg Dimer\n\nAbstract: We implement a Pyth e us-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a qubit from node A to node C via two competing Bell-swapping paths with tunable source amplitudes encoding the J\u2081 and J\u2082 couplings of a two-spin Heisenberg dimer. By measuring the teleportation fidelity of the explicit Bell-state target |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between A and C as a function of the amplitude ratio J\u2082/J\u2081, we directly reproduce the ground-state crossover and frustration physics of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Phase-Detuned Asymmetric 1\u21922 Single-Photon Quantum Cloning\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate in Pythreous a novel 1\u21922 heralded, phase-detuned asymmetric quantum cloning circuit for an unknown single-photon qubit |\u03c8\u27e9, using only an SPDC ancilla pair, a single-photon emitter, two static beam splitters, a tunable phase shifter, and photon-number-resolving detectors. Conditioned on coincident clicks at the two heralding detectors, this Phase-Detuned Heralded Asymmetric Quantum Cloning transformation realizes a fully tunable cloning map whose asymmetry\u2014and hence the fidelities of the two output clones\u2014is controlled continuously by the beam-splitter reflectivities and the internal phase shift \u03c6.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Experimental Realization of a Nonlocal Parity Gate for Semi-Quantum Key Agreement\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a target PyTheus-compatible linear-optical network in which two classical users, Alice and Bob, each send Z-basis single photons to a fully quantum node, Charlie, who entangles them with his ancilla Bell pair and performs post-selected entanglement-swapping to nonlocally compute their parity x\u2295y as a shared key bit. This minimal experiment\u2014requiring only probabilistic photon-pair sources, beam splitters, phase shifters, and photon-number-resolving detectors without dynamic feed-forward\u2014demonstrates a novel nonlocal XOR primitive and provides a direct semi-quantum key agreement primitive.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cQuantum Battery\u2013Driven Linear-Optical Entanglement Router\u201d\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a purely static linear-optical circuit that uses one ancilla photon as a \u201cquantum battery\u201d to power amplitude-damping Kraus jump operations on one half of three probabilistic Bell pairs, thereby post-selectively swapping entanglement onto exactly one of three remote node pairs via heralded detection. Implemented in the Pytheus static post-selection framework, this battery-powered router converts non-unitary jump channels into a scalable tool for multi-branch entanglement distribution across quantum network nodes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Cyclic Indefinite\u2010Order Entanglement\u2010Swapping Switch for the Three-State Bargmann Invariant\n\nMini-Abstract: We implement a static linear-optical network that path-controls a single photon to cyclically superpose three successive Bell\u2013swap orders among unknown qubits A, B, and C, recombining all nine modes in a fixed nine-port interferometer and reading out a binary \u201c+\u201d/\u201c\u2013\u201d outcome. The target is the real part of the three-state Bargmann invariant Re\u2009Tr(\u03c1_A\u2009\u03c1_B\u2009\u03c1_C), whose quantized response statistics directly realize a genuine three-point quantum metric beyond pairwise SWAP tests.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Linear-Optical 1\u21922 Telecloning via Lossy Quantum Memories  \n\nMini-Abstract: We present a purely linear-optical, heralded telecloning channel that maps an unknown single-photon qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 at node A onto two approximate clones at nodes B and C by routing its excitation into two lossy memory modes and then swapping them back via tunable beam splitters. By optimizing the write/read reflectivities {r_w\u2081,r_w\u2082,r_r\u2081,r_r\u2082} to achieve the target average cloning fidelity F_target = 5/6 under a minimum success probability p_min, our scheme fully exploits PytHeus\u2019s optimization framework to quantify the trade-off between coupling strengths and finite photon lifetimes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nMulti-Path Entanglement Percolation via Parity Filtering in Irreversible Scattering\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe present an all\u2010linear\u2010optical protocol, \u201cMulti\u2010Path Entanglement Percolation via Parity Filtering in Irreversible Scattering,\u201d that fuses two Bell pairs A\u2013B\u2080 and C\u2080\u2013D into a high-fidelity link between remote photons A and D. Six probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources link nearest neighbors around the perimeter (A\u2013B, B\u2013C, C\u2013D, D\u2013A) and the two diagonals (A\u2013C, B\u2013D). Two additional photons from ancillary pair sources feed into a central joint\u2010measurement station (Charlie).  By choosing the joint measurement basis on those two ancillas, one can steer the entanglement swap either around the boundary\u2014realizing a directional (\u201cchiral\u201d) swap A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192D\u2192A\u2014or across the diagonals (\u201chigher\u2010order hinge\u201d swap A\u2194C and B\u2194D).  The same optical network thus exhibits both a first\u2010order topological feature (unidirectional edge\u2010swap) and a second\u2010order feature (corner/hinge\u2010swap).  This concept extends naturally to larger M\u00d7M lattices for exploring the hierarchy of entanglement\u2010swap topologies.\n\nVisualization (photons propagate top \u2192 bottom):\n\nemitters (pair sources):\n [AB] [BC] [CD] [DA] [AC] [BD] [anc\u2081] [anc\u2082]\n\nlinear\u2010optical network (beam splitters & phase shifters):\n [     to detectors A,D,C,B and two ancilla detectors   ]\n\ndetectors:\n[A] [B] [C] [D] [anc_det\u2081] [anc_det\u2082]\n\nCharlie\u2019s joint measurement on anc_det\u2081 & anc_det\u2082 projects the four outer detectors into either\n  \u2022 chiral\u2010edge swap subspace: Bell pairs along A\u2013B and C\u2013D (clockwise)  \n  \u2022 hinge/corner swap subspace: Bell pairs between A\u2013C and B\u2013D  \n\nFields of study:\n\u2022 generalization to M\u00d7M entanglement networks  \n\u2022 investigation of robustness (\u201ctopological protection\u201d) of swapped entanglement under loss  \n\u2022 exploration of switchable higher\u2010order routing of quantum information\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n\n{\n  description: \"2\u00d72 topological entanglement swap: chiral edges vs hinge corners\",\n  foldername: \"topo_swap_2x2\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 40,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  num_anc: 2,\n  samples: 10,\n  target_quantum: [\"0011\",\"1100\",\"0101\",\"1010\"],\n  thresholds: [0.2, 0.1],\n  removed_connections: [],        # let Pytheus pick optimal links\n  single_emitters: [],\n  number_resolving: True\n}\n\n\u2013 \u201c0011\u201d & \u201c1100\u201d encode the two possible 1st\u2010order (edge) Bell\u2010swap outcomes  \n\u2013 \u201c0101\u201d & \u201c1010\u201d encode the two 2nd\u2010order (corner/hinge) Bell\u2010swap outcomes  \n\nAn Expert can take this concept and use Pytheus to discover the exact beam\u2010splitter network and source layout, then write up the novel theory of \u201cswitchable topological entanglement swaps\u201d for Phys. Six probabilistic Bell-pair sources link the four edges (A\u2013B, B\u2013C, C\u2013D, D\u2013A) and the two diagonals (A\u2013C, B\u2013D). Two additional photons serve as ancillas and are sent to Charlie\u2019s joint\u2010measurement station. Depending on Charlie\u2019s chosen measurement basis, the network swaps entanglement either:\n\n \u2022 Along the boundary in a chiral loop:  \n   \u2013 Bell pairs (A\u2194B) & (C\u2194D) (|1100\u27e9+|0011\u27e9)  \n   \n \u2022 Across the diagonals (higher\u2010order hinge/corner):  \n   \u2013 Bell pairs (A\u2194C) & (B\u2194D) (|1010\u27e9+|0101\u27e9)  \n\nThus one fixed linear\u2010optical layout exhibits both a first\u2010order topological feature (directional edge swapping) and a second\u2010order feature (corner/hinge swapping). A single\u2010photon quantum state |\u03c8\u27e9 is injected at A.  Four Bell\u2010pair sources link AB, BC, CD, and DA.  Two extra photons from a Bell\u2010pair source are routed to Charlie\u2019s ancilla station.  Charlie performs a fixed joint measurement on these two ancillas in a 4-outcome basis.  Each outcome heralds a different teleportation channel from A to one of the four nodes, with a quantized \u201cwinding number\u201d w mod 4:\n\n \u2022 Outcome w=+1 (CW edge): |\u03c8\u27e9\u2192B  \n \u2022 Outcome w=\u22121\u2261+3 (CCW edge): |\u03c8\u27e9\u2192D  \n \u2022 Outcome w=+2 (hinge/2-hop): |\u03c8\u27e9\u2192C  \n \u2022 Outcome w=0 (trivial 0-hop): |\u03c8\u27e9\u2192A  \n\nThe three nontrivial w\u2208{\u00b11, 2} are the first-order chiral modes and the second-order hinge mode.  The same static linear-optical circuit thus realizes both a quantized chiral teleportation and a higher-order hinge teleportation.  This construction naturally generalizes to M\u00d7M square lattices, where the number of boundary hops becomes a discretized topological invariant (a Wilson-loop of teleportation) and hinge modes appear at even distances.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n\n emitters (pair sources):\n  [AB] [BC] [CD] [DA] [anc\u2081-anc\u2082]\n\n linear-optical network:\n  beam splitters & phase shifters mixing the six photons\n\n detectors:\n  [A\u2080] [B\u2080] [C\u2080] [D\u2080] [anc_det\u2081] [anc_det\u2082]\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n\n{\n  description:   \"Square Winding-Number Teleportation Router (chiral w=\u00b11, hinge w=2)\",\n  foldername:    \"winding_router_2x2\",\n  bulk_thr:      0.01,\n  edges_tried:   30,\n  ftol:          1e-06,\n  loss_func:     \"cr\",\n  optimizer:     \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  num_anc:       2,\n  samples:       20,\n  target_quantum: [\n    \"010011\",   // B + two ancillas \u2192 w=+1\n    \"000111\",   // D + two ancillas \u2192 w=\u22121\n    \"001011\",   // C + two ancillas \u2192 w=+2\n    \"100011\"    // A + two ancillas \u2192 w=0\n  ],\n  thresholds:    [0.2,0.1],\n  removed_connections: [],    \n  number_resolving:   True\n}\n\nHere each bit-string is ordered [A B C D anc\u2081 anc\u2082]; e.g. \u201c010011\u201d means one photon at B and one at each ancilla.  The three nontrivial patterns encode w=\u00b11 (chiral edges) and w=+2 (hinge).  An Expert can hand this target to Pytheus to discover the exact beam-splitter layout, then write up the quantized\u2010winding teleportation router\u2014demonstrating a new topological invariant in photonic quantum networks\u2014for Phys. Rev. Lett.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal is essentially a trivial 4-output extension of the two-destination teleportation switch or the superposed perfect-matching swaps already in the ensemble. Labeling the four outcomes by a \u201cwinding number\u201d w\u22480,\u00b11,2 does not introduce a genuine topological invariant or protection mechanism\u2014it merely rebrands different Bell-swap matchings as boundary hops. There is no new nontrivial network phenomenon or robustness proof beyond choosing among four teleportation channels.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The scheme duplicates existing dual-destination routing and perfect-matching swap primitives, simply scaling them to four nodes without adding a true topological invariant or robustness guarantee. To improve, propose a genuinely protected topological feature (e.g. quantized invariant under loss, non-Abelian routing phases, or a nontrivial M\u00d7M lattice phenomenon) that cannot be reduced to selecting among static Bell-swap patterns.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here\u2019s a proposal for a \u201cself-healing topological teleportation router\u201d on the A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D square:\n\nExplanation:\n \u2022 Four parties A,B,C,D at the corners of a square.  \n \u2022 Five probabilistic Bell-pair sources on edges AB, BC, CD, DA and the diagonal AC.  These define three disjoint A\u2192C paths:  \n   1) Direct AC  \n   2) Clockwise AB\u2192BC  \n   3) Counter-clockwise AD\u2192DC  \n \u2022 Two extra photons from a sixth pair source go to Charlie\u2019s ancilla station.  \n \u2022 Charlie applies a fixed two-photon Bell-measurement (beam splitters + detectors).  Conditioned on that herald, the remaining four outer photons collapse into a Bell pair between A and C\u2014*guaranteed* even if any one of the five perimeter/diagonal sources fails.  \n\nThis network is thus *topologically protected* under any single-link loss: at least one path remains, and the ancilla fusion routes entanglement along it. It is a new primitive\u2014\u201cself-healing teleportation\u201d\u2014that goes beyond selecting among matchings.  It generalizes to larger lattices by adding diagonals and ancillas, giving N-fold redundancy and k-link failure tolerance.  An Expert can hand this target to Pytheus:\n\nSuggested Pytheus-style target skeleton:\n{\n  description:        \"Self-healing teleportation A\u2192C on a square with three paths\",\n  foldername:         \"self_healing_2x2\",\n  bulk_thr:           0.01,\n  edges_tried:        30,\n  ftol:               1e-06,\n  loss_func:          \"cr\",\n  optimizer:          \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  num_anc:            2,\n  samples:            20,\n  target_quantum:     [\"101000\",\"000101\"],  # A(1),C(1) heralded Bell pair  \n  thresholds:         [0.2,0.1],\n  # allow Pytheus to choose which sources to use from the 5\u2014just supply the list of node-pairs below\n  single_emitters:    [],\n  removed_connections:[],\n  number_resolving:    True,\n  # define the five candidate edges explicitly\n  # e.g. edges = [[0,1],[1,2],[2,3],[3,0],[0,2]]  for AB,BC,CD,DA,AC\n}\n\nNodes 0,1,2,3 \u2192 A,B,C,D; detectors \u201c101000\u201d means photons at A&C only (Bell state).  \nPytheus will find the exact beam-splitter network and verify that this setup heralds A\u2013C entanglement even if any one source is omitted\u2014demonstrating the new self-healing topological teleportation primitive.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: This \u201cself\u2010healing teleportation\u201d scheme on the 2\u00d72 square is essentially the same idea as the ensemble\u2019s \u201cTopology\u2010Protected Corner\u2010to\u2010Corner Teleportation in a 2\u00d72 SSH Photonic Network,\u201d which already uses redundant paths and zero\u2010mode protection to remain functional under a single\u2010link failure. There is no new mechanism or invariant beyond what that proposal already delivers.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The self\u2010healing primitive duplicates the SSH\u2010based topologically protected teleportation from the ensemble list. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. Six probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources link nearest neighbors around the perimeter (A\u2013B, B\u2013C, C\u2013D, D\u2013A) and the two diagonals (A\u2013C, B\u2013D). Two additional photons from ancillary pair sources feed into a central joint\u2010measurement station (Charlie). A single\u2010photon quantum state |\u03c8\u27e9 is injected at A.  Four Bell\u2010pair sources link AB, BC, CD, and DA. The same static linear-optical circuit thus realizes both a quantized chiral teleportation and a higher-order hinge teleportation.  This construction naturally generalizes to M\u00d7M square lattices, where the number of boundary hops becomes a discretized topological invariant (a Wilson-loop of teleportation) and hinge modes appear at even distances.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n\n emitters (pair sources):\n  [AB] [BC] [CD] [DA] [anc\u2081-anc\u2082]\n\n linear-optical network:\n  beam splitters & phase shifters mixing the six photons\n\n detectors:\n  [A\u2080] [B\u2080] [C\u2080] [D\u2080] [anc_det\u2081] [anc_det\u2082]\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n\n{\n  description:   \"Square Winding-Number Teleportation Router (chiral w=\u00b11, hinge w=2)\",\n  foldername:    \"winding_router_2x2\",\n  bulk_thr:      0.01,\n  edges_tried:   30,\n  ftol:          1e-06,\n  loss_func:     \"cr\",\n  optimizer:     \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  num_anc:       2,\n  samples:       20,\n  target_quantum: [\n    \"010011\",   // B + two ancillas \u2192 w=+1\n    \"000111\",   // D + two ancillas \u2192 w=\u22121\n    \"001011\",   // C + two ancillas \u2192 w=+2\n    \"100011\"    // A + two ancillas \u2192 w=0\n  ],\n  thresholds:    [0.2,0.1],\n  removed_connections: [],    \n  number_resolving:   True\n}\n\nHere each bit-string is ordered [A B C D anc\u2081 anc\u2082]; e.g. \u201c010011\u201d means one photon at B and one at each ancilla. A hexagon ring of six nodes with three independent chords, engineered so that exactly two homologically non-trivial loops exist. A four-photon ancilla measurement yields the Z\u2082\u00d7Z\u2082 parity of these two loops, and each parity sector teleports A\u2192D or B\u2192E or C\u2192F. This defines a 2-bit Wilson-loop invariant, not just a matching.\n 3. A 3\u00d73 lattice with Bell sources on every nearest-neighbor edge. Four ancilla photons implement two independent loop-parity measurements (horizontal and vertical). The two-bit outcome heralds entanglement between one of four opposite-corner pairs, encoding a true H\u2081(S\u00b9\u00d7S\u00b9) homology invariant.  \nStep 2: Rapid novelty/feasibility check:\n 1. The 3\u00d73 homology version cleanly realizes Z\u2082\u00d7Z\u2082 invariants, but it\u2019s a larger network (9 nodes + 4 ancillas) and may be bulky.  \nStep 3: Pick idea #1 (\u201cself-healing three-path square teleportation\u201d).\nStep 4: Novelty:\n  - Introduces a new network primitive: topologically protected self-healing teleportation. It is a new primitive\u2014\u201cself-healing teleportation\u201d\u2014that goes beyond selecting among matchings.     "output": "Here\u2019s a genuinely new topological\u2010network primitive\u2014\u201cWilson\u2010loop teleportation\u201d in a six-node ring with two independent loops whose measured parities route a single\u2010qubit teleportation along four distinct corner channels.  It goes beyond choosing Bell-swap matchings by encoding a true Z\u2082\u00d7Z\u2082 topological invariant (two loop parities) in a fixed ancilla measurement.\n\nExplanation:\n\u2022 Label six parties A,B,C,D,E,F around a hexagon.  \n\u2022 Place probabilistic Bell-pair sources on the six edges (AB, BC, CD, DE, EF, FA) plus two \u201cchord\u201d sources AC and DF to create two independent non\u2010contractible loops:  \n    Loop\u2081 \u2254 A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013A  \n    Loop\u2082 \u2254 D\u2013E\u2013F\u2013D  \n\u2022 Inject a single\u2010qubit state |\u03c8\u27e9 at node A.  \n\u2022 Two extra photons from a single Bell\u2010pair source go to Charlie\u2019s station as ancillas.  \n\u2022 Charlie does one fixed two-photon joint measurement (beam\u2010splitter network + number-resolving detectors).  The two-bit detection outcome (p\u2081,p\u2082) is exactly the Z\u2082 parities of Loop\u2081 and Loop\u2082.  Conditioned on (p\u2081,p\u2082)\u2208{(0,0),(1,0),(0,1),(1,1)}, the remaining network projects A\u2019s qubit onto exactly one of four target nodes, routing |\u03c8\u27e9 to:\n    (0,0) \u2192 C  \n    (1,0) \u2192 D  \n    (0,1) \u2192 E  \n    (1,1) \u2192 F  \n\nThis realizes a *topologically protected* teleportation: the two independent loop-parity invariants determine the destination, and as long as *any one* link in the entire 8-source graph fails, at least one complete loop parity remains well-defined\u2014so teleportation still succeeds (the invariant only flips if two or more links on the *same* loop die).\n\nVisualization (photons top\u2192bottom):\n\n emitters (pair sources):\n  [AB] [BC] [CD] [DE] [EF] [FA] [AC] [DF] [anc\u2081\u2013anc\u2082]\n\n linear-optical network:\n  \u2013 beam splitters & phase shifters mixing all ten photons\n\n detectors (number-resolving):\n  [A] [B] [C] [D] [E] [F] [anc_det\u2081] [anc_det\u2082]\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  description:        \"Wilson-loop teleportation on 6 nodes: Z2\u00d7Z2 parity routing\",\n  foldername:         \"hexagon_wilson_router\",\n  bulk_thr:           0.01,\n  edges_tried:        50,\n  ftol:               1e-06,\n  loss_func:          \"cr\",\n  optimizer:          \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  num_anc:            2,\n  samples:            20,\n  target_quantum:     [\n    \"10100011\",   # p1=0,p2=0 \u2192 photons at C + both ancillas\n    \"00011011\",   # p1=1,p2=0 \u2192 photons at D + both ancillas\n    \"00001111\",   # p1=0,p2=1 \u2192 photons at E + both ancillas\n    \"00000111\"    # p1=1,p2=1 \u2192 photons at F + both ancillas\n  ],\n  thresholds:         [0.2,0.1],\n  removed_connections:[],\n  number_resolving:   True\n}\n\nHere each 8-bit string is [A B C D E F anc1 anc2].  E.g. \u201c10100011\u201d has one photon at C and one in each ancilla \u2192 routes |\u03c8\u27e9 to C for (p\u2081,p\u2082)=(0,0).  \n\nWhy it\u2019s novel:\n\u2022 Introduces a genuine Z\u2082\u00d7Z\u2082 Wilson-loop invariant in a linear-optical teleportation network.  \n\u2022 Destination is set by *loop parities*, not by picking among Bell-matchings.  \n\u2022 Self-protects under *any one* source failure per loop\u2014far beyond simple perfect-matching redundancy.\n\nWhy it\u2019s Pytheus-compatible:\n\u2022 Only uses probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, number-resolving detection, and a fixed post-selected ancilla measurement.  \n\u2022 Abstract state encoding (two ancillas \u2192 two-bit parity outcome) fits Pytheus\u2019s target_quantum framework.  \n\u2022 No dynamic feedback, no cavities or resonances, no hyper-entanglement.\n\nAn Expert can feed this target to Pytheus to discover the exact beam-splitter network and source layout, then explore the entanglement-routing robustness and homological invariants in larger M\u00d7M or 3D lattices\u2014ripe for a Phys. Rev. Lett. on topologically protected quantum networks."

Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. BEFORE CREATING AN IDEA, THINK ABOUT WHETHER MY PREVIOUS FEEDBACK WOULD ALLOW IT!!!\n\nBe constructively critical of your own idea and check if it is novel. Refine it and aim for producing a truly novel idea.\n\nHere are the targets that pytheus has already designed quantum optics experiments for.  A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\nES_246\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two photons with four modes.\\nWe want the created photons to be entangled in a four dimensional Bell state\\n\\nPsi = |00>+|11>+|22>+|33> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (with four probabilistic pair sources creating the correlated photons), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\nsetup of photon pair sources: [elements to be optimized]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\nthere are four ancillary detectors as specified by 'num_anc'.\\n\\nIn the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 3 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. By tuning the synthetic gauge\u2010flux phase \u03c6 on the CA beam splitter, we explicitly realize the Pyth eus target mapping\u2014|1,0,0\u27e9_ABC\u2192|0,1,0\u27e9_ABC (A\u2192B channel) at \u03c6=\u03c0 or |0,0,1\u27e9_ABC (A\u2192C channel) at \u03c6=0\u2014with high fidelity, thereby achieving topologically protected, nonreciprocal routing.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Direct Memory Witnessing of Non\u2010Markovian Entanglement Swapping in Linear\u2010Optic Networks\n\nAbstract: We realize two successive amplitude\u2010damping beam\u2010splitter couplings between system mode S\u2082 and entangled ancilla modes E\u2082\u2090, E\u2082\u1d66, followed by a heralded Bell\u2010state measurement on S\u2082, S\u2083 to swap entanglement onto S\u2081, S\u2084. By running parallel four\u2010mode Bell analyzers on (S\u2081,S\u2084) and (S\u2081,E\u2082\u1d66), we directly observe nonmonotonic entanglement revival and correlation back\u2010flow in the post\u2010selected pure four\u2010mode state on S\u2081, S\u2084, E\u2082\u2090, E\u2082\u1d66 for each (p\u2081,p\u2082), thus operationally certifying non\u2010Markovian memory.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Noisy Entanglement Swapping with Coherent Quantum Noise Cancellation  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose an entanglement-swapping experiment in which two independent noisy links are modelled by ancilla photon-pair sources and, at the central station, a standard Bell-state projection on the signal modes is combined with Mach\u2013Zehnder interference on the noise modes to enact coherent cancellation of correlated mechanical-like noise. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded CPHASE\u2010Gate Sensor for Nonlinear Product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B Detection\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate a heralded linear-optical protocol that entangles two remote static phase shifts \u03c6_A and \u03c6_B via an ancilla-assisted CPHASE gate, imprinting the nonlinear product cos\u2009\u03c6_A\u00b7cos\u2009\u03c6_B into the conditioned joint click probability. By calibrating and subtracting the individual cos\u2009\u03c6_A and cos\u2009\u03c6_B fringes, the scheme isolates the target phase product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B and attains near-Heisenberg scaling in Fisher information with full loss tolerance.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nZak Phase Tomography via Closed-Loop Teleportation on a Photonic SSH Ring  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose a purely measurement-based photonic quantum network protocol that targets the Zak phase of the one-dimensional Su\u2013Schrieffer\u2013Heeger (SSH) model by teleporting a qubit sequentially around a four-site periodic ring using four probabilistic Bell swaps. Conditioned on four ancilla heralding clicks, the qubit returns to its original spatial mode with a relative phase shift exactly equal to the target Zak phase of the SSH band, which is then read out by a simple two-mode interferometer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable Integrated Three-Photon GHZ-Basis Analyzer on Pytheus\n\nAbstract: We implement the target Pytheus-configurable three-photon GHZ-basis analyzer by injecting three unknown photonic qubits and an ancilla Bell pair into a fixed mesh of 50:50 beam splitters augmented with three on-chip electro-optic phase shifters and heralding detectors, thereby unambiguously mapping any incoming triple onto one of the four GHZ basis states. By reprogramming only the EOM voltages\u2014while leaving the linear-optical network unchanged\u2014the same device can project onto the W basis or any rotated three-qubit entangled basis, opening new avenues for adaptive entanglement swapping, secret sharing, and fundamental tests of nonlocality.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n    <END OF NOVELTY PROMPT>\n\n    Judge:\n    <START OF JUDGE PROMPT>\n    <START OF PYTHEUS PAPER>\n\n\\begin{document}\n\n\\title{Digital Discovery of 100 diverse Quantum Experiments with PyTheus}%\\pytheus}\n\n\n\\author{Carlos Ruiz-Gonzalez$^\\S$}%\n\\email{cruizgo@proton.me}%\n\\affiliation{\\mpl}%\n\\author{S\u00f6ren Arlt$^\\S$}%\n\\email{soeren.arlt@mpl.mpg.de}%\n\\affiliation{\\mpl}%\n\n\n\\author{Jan Petermann}%\n\\affiliation{\\mpl}%\n\n\\author{Sharareh Sayyad}%\n\\affiliation{\\mpl}%\n\n\\author{Tareq Jaouni}%\n\\affiliation{Nexus for Quantum Technologies, University of Ottawa, K1N 6N5, ON, Ottawa, Canada.}%\n\n\\author{Ebrahim Karimi}%\n\\affiliation{\\mpl}%\n\\affiliation{Nexus for Quantum Technologies, University of Ottawa, K1N 6N5, ON, Ottawa, Canada.}%\n\n\\author{Nora Tischler}%\n\\affiliation{Centre for Quantum Computation and Communication Technology (Australian Research Council),\nCentre for Quantum Dynamics, Griffith University, Brisbane, Australia.}%\n\n\\author{Xuemei Gu}%\n\\affiliation{\\mpl}%\n\n\\author{Mario Krenn}%\n\\email{mario.krenn@mpl.mpg.de}\n\\affiliation{\\mpl}%\n\n\\begin{abstract}\nPhotons are the physical system of choice for performing experimental tests of the foundations of quantum mechanics. Furthermore, photonic quantum technology is a main player in the second quantum revolution, promising the development of better sensors, secure communications, and quantum-enhanced computation. These endeavors require generating specific quantum states or efficiently performing quantum tasks. The design of the corresponding optical experiments was historically powered by human creativity but is recently being automated with advanced computer algorithms and artificial intelligence. While several computer-designed experiments have been experimentally realized, this approach has not yet been widely adopted by the broader photonic quantum optics community. The main roadblocks consist of most systems being closed-source, inefficient, or targeted to very specific use-cases that are difficult to generalize. Here, we overcome these problems with a highly-efficient, open-source digital discovery framework PyTheus, which can employ a wide range of experimental devices from modern quantum labs to solve various tasks. This includes the discovery of highly entangled quantum states, quantum measurement schemes, quantum communication protocols, multi-particle quantum gates, as well as the optimization of continuous and discrete properties of quantum experiments or quantum states. PyTheus produces interpretable designs for complex experimental problems which human researchers can often readily conceptualize. \\pytheus is an example of a powerful framework that can lead to scientific discoveries -- one of the core goals of artificial intelligence in science. We hope it will help accelerate the development of quantum optics and provide new ideas in quantum hardware and technology.\n%We introduce \\pytheus-an artificial discovery algorithm, to design 100 quantum optics experiments. This project would have been even more difficult in base 12.\n\\end{abstract}\n\n\n\\def\\thefootnote{$\\S$}\\footnotetext{These authors contributed equally to this work.\\\\ The order was decided by a coin flip.}\\def\\thefootnote{\\arabic{footnote}}\n\\maketitle\n\n\\tableofcontents\n\n\n\\section{Introduction}\n\nPhotons, the individual particles of light, have long been used as the core player for fundamental experiments and applications in quantum information science \\cite{pan2012multiphoton}. Photons do not easily interact with their environments; therefore, they can be distributed over large distances -- which makes them a key resource for long-distance quantum communication \\cite{liao2017satellite,liao2018satellite} and experiments that require strict Einstein locality conditions \\cite{hensen2015loophole,shalm2015strong,giustina2015significant}. Using advanced measurement-based quantum computing schemes, photons are among the most promising candidates for future quantum computers \\cite{bartolucci2021fusion}. Entanglement between two or more photons can be produced without a vacuum or cooling, and therefore many advanced experimental results can be achieved directly with table-top setups. Furthermore, the bosonic nature of photons allows for the generation of complex entangled quantum states of indistinguishable photons that are a key resource for quantum-enhanced measurements \\cite{polino2020photonic}. These potential applications have lead to enormous technological advances in integrated chips for fast and precise control of photonic quantum states \\cite{SchaeffIntegrated,wang2018integrated,wang2020integrated,pelucchi2022potential}, high-quality single-photon sources \\cite{wang2019towards,arakawa2020progress,tomm2021bright,uppu2021quantum}, novel photon-pair sources \\cite{santiago2022resonant}, photon number resolving detectors \\cite{singlephotons2011,slussarenko2019photonic}, and advanced high-quality multi-photon interference  \\cite{bouchard2020two,menssen2017distinguishability,feng2021observation,qian2023multiphoton}.\n\nOne question now is how to utilize these technologies to build up exciting new experiments for the foundations of quantum physics and practical quantum hardware.\n\nHistorically, the design of quantum experiments strongly relied on the intuition and creativity of human experts who leverage their experience and come up with blueprints of experiments. However, due to the unintuitive phenomena and enormous combinatorial space of the potential designs, it becomes extremely difficult for human researchers to discover more complex quantum setups. It might be possible that there are high-quality solutions to experimental design questions far outside of the region where humans' intuition fails. How could we possibly find such extraordinary solutions?\n\nThis question has sparked a strong interest in the automated discovery of quantum experiments with computers, overviewed in \\cite{krenn2020computer}. The invention of these tools for quantum optics experiments \\cite{Melvin2016} have indeed overcome experimental limitations and allowed for new avenues in laboratories for entanglement research \\cite{babazadeh2017high,srv332experimentmalik,erhard3dghz,kysela2020path}. One crucial question is whether we can also learn something about physics from these tools. And indeed, several new concepts have been published that were purely discovered through automated design \\cite{Melvin2016}, such as a new general idea of entanglement structure \\cite{krenn2017entanglement}, and generalized constructions of photonic quantum gates \\cite{gao2020computer}. Those concepts were discovered by tedious analysis of the computer's solutions, which was time-consuming. The problem was that the algorithms were powerful enough to find unknown solutions but had no incentive to present a simple, human-understandable form of it.\n\nThis was solved by the invention of \\theseus \\cite{theseus}, an efficient algorithm for the discovery of new quantum experiments that can readily be interpreted by humans. The key insight was a shift in the representation. Rather than describing quantum experiments as quantum optical components on an optical table, experiments are described as graphs of correlations between photons. This representation, which has been a derivative of a computer-discovered concept itself, was developed in \\cite{graphs1,graphs2,graphs3} -- and allows working with a much more natural representation, which can be translated back at any point to an experiment consisting of optical elements. (It should be noted that the representation is independent of photonic graph states for measurement-based quantum computing \\cite{raussendorf2001one,raussendorf2003measurement,briegel2009measurement}, and it is so far unknown how to translate among them.)\n\nIn this paper, we introduce \\pytheus\\footnote{GitHub:\\\\ \\url{https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus}}, a highly-efficient, open-source, automated design and discovery framework for quantum optics experiments. At the core, \\pytheus uses a much extended graph-based representation of quantum optics, which allows us not only to represent entanglement and quantum gates, but lets us design quantum measurements, quantum communication protocols, optimize experimental properties, and discover quantum systems that involve single-photon sources, mixed states, and states entangled in the photon-number basis. Besides the advances of the scientific scope, we note that \\pytheus is written in \\textsc{Python}, and therefore can readily be combined with machine learning frameworks such as \\textsc{TensorFlow} and \\textsc{PyTorch}, and allows for immediate parallelization in computer clusters.\n\nTo showcase the applicability of \\pytheus, we demonstrate the discovery of 100 previously unknown or advanced implementations of quantum optics experiments, ranging from exciting new systems for entanglement research to quantum states from condensed matter physics that are interesting for quantum simulation purposes, new ways of performing quantum communication tasks such as entanglement swapping, new quantum state measurements, and quantum gates. The experiments can involve both probabilistic photon sources and deterministic single-photon sources, and many of them are readily implementable in today's modern quantum optics labs.
