\\ket{10100} - \\ket{01010} \\notag\\\\\n & - \\ket{00101} - \\ket{10010} - \\ket{01001} - \\ket{11110} \\notag\\\\\n & - \\ket{01111} - \\ket{10111} - \\ket{11011} - \\ket{11101},\\\\\n\\ket{1_L^{(5)}} & = X^{\\otimes 5} \\ket{0_L^{(5)}} = X_L \\ket{0_L^{(5)}}. \n\\end{align}\nThese two logical qubits constitute the smallest error-correcting code resilient to arbitrary single qubit errors \\cite{min_error_correct}.\n\n\\begin{figure}[!t]\n\t\\centering\n\t\\subfloat[$|0_L^{(5)}\\rangle$]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_Laflamme.pdf}}\\\\%{Graphs/ErrorCorrection/laflamme_code.pdf}}\\\\\n \\vspace{-5mm}\n\t\\subfloat[$|0_L^{(7)}\\rangle$]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_Steane.pdf}}\\!\\!%{Graphs/ErrorCorrection/steane_code.pdf}}\\!\\!\n\t\\subfloat[$|0_L^{(9)}\\rangle$]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_Shor.pdf}}%{Graphs/ErrorCorrection/shor_code.pdf}}\n\t\\caption {Graphs for generating the logical 0 state using 5, 7, and 9 physical qubits (+ ancillas, which are in a fixed state).}\n\t\\label{fig:error_correction}\n\\end{figure}\nFig.~\\ref{fig:error_correction} shows the graphs for producing each of the logical 0 states for 5, 7, and 9 physical qubits. For the Shor code, the second logical qubit state can be obtained by multiplying the weights of every bicolored edge by -1 (or alternatively, taking the 3rd, 6th, and 9th qubits and applying a minus at each red incoming edge). For the other two codes, one can obtain the graphs associated with the logical 1 state by switching the colors blue and red. Such transformation is equivalent to applying the gate $X$ on each qubit, the logical $X_L$.\\newline\n\n\n\\tocless\\subsubsection{Products of W States}\nPrevious work with the graph representation showed how to create W states for an arbitrary even number of qubits without using any ancilla \\cite{graphs3}. On the other hand, to generate a W state with an odd number of qubits, we always needed at least one ancillary detector. Accordingly, if we want to duplicate such odd-qubit states, we can simply duplicate the graph together with the ancillas. However, this straightforward method is not the most efficient, at least for the states $\\ket{W_3}^{\\otimes2}$ and $\\ket{W_5}^{\\otimes2}$. As shown in Fig.~\\ref{fig:w3w3}, these two states can be obtained without using ancillas \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/HighlyEntangledStates/W3W3]{experimentcounter}\\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/HighlyEntangledStates/W5W5]{experimentcounter}.\\newline\n\\begin{figure}[!t]\n\t\\centering\n\t\\includegraphics[width=0.25\\textwidth]{graph_W3W3.pdf}\\hspace{-3mm}%{Graphs/HighlyEntangledStates/w3w3.pdf}\\hspace{-3mm}\n\t\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_W5W5.pdf}%{Graphs/HighlyEntangledStates/w5w5.pdf}\n\t\\caption {Graphs for generating the states $\\ket{W_3}^{\\otimes2}$ and $\\ket{W_5}^{\\otimes2}$ without ancillas.}\n\t\\label{fig:w3w3}\t\n\\end{figure}\n\n\\tocless\\subsubsection{Dicke States}\nThe equal superposition of every $N$-qubit state containing a single $\\ket{1}$ gives us the W states. These states can be generalized, superposing all permutations of $N$ qubits with exactly $k$ $\\ket{1}$s. They are the \\textit{Dicke states}\n\\begin{equation}\n    \\ket{D^k_N}=\\sqrt{\\frac{k!(N-k)!}{N!}}\\sum_{i} P_i( \\ket{0}^{\\otimes N - k} \\ket{1}^{\\otimes k}),\n\\end{equation}\nwhere $\\sum_{i} P_i( \\cdot )$ stands for all possible permutations of $k$ $\\ket{1}$ among $N$ qubits. These states, which have applications in multiparty quantum communication and quantum metrology \\cite{dicke_persistent,dicke_telecloning,dicke_networking,dicke_metrology}, can be produced for an even number of qubits with a general graph introduced in previous works \\cite{graphs3}. Here we produce a pair of Dicke states with an odd number of qubits and two excitations \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/HighlyEntangledStates/dicke52]{experimentcounter}\\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/HighlyEntangledStates/dicke72]{experimentcounter} (see Fig.~\\ref{fig:odddicke}).\n\\begin{figure}[!h]\n\t\\centering\n    \\subfloat[$\\ket{D^2_5}$]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_dicke52.pdf}}\\!\\!%{Graphs/Dicke/dicke52.pdf}}\\!\\!\n\t\\subfloat[$\\ket{D^2_7}$]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_dicke72.pdf}}%{Graphs/Dicke/dicke72.pdf}}\n    \\caption{Dicke states with two $\\ket{1}$ for five and seven qubits.}\n\t\\label{fig:odddicke}\t\n\\end{figure}\n\nMoreover, there exists a generalization of Dicke states for higher dimensions \\cite{dicke_qudit}. Given a set of integers $\\{k_i\\}$, such that $\\sum_i k_i=N$, we describe its corresponding d-dimensional Dicke state as\n\\begin{align}\n    \\ket{D(N,\\{k_i\\})} = \\sqrt{\\frac{\\prod_i k_i!}{N!}}\\sum_i P_i &(\\ket{0}^{\\otimes k_0}\\ket{1}^{\\otimes k_1} \\notag \\\\\n    &\\dots\\ket{d-1}^{\\otimes k_{d-1}} )\n\\end{align}\nwhere $\\sum_{i} P_i( \\cdot )$ stands for all possible permutations of the $N$ qudits. In Fig.~\\ref{fig:symm} we plot the graphs that produce the 3-dimensional Dicke state with three particles \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/HighlyEntangledStates/dicke33]{experimentcounter}\n\\begin{align}\n    \\ket{D(3,(1,1,1)} &= \\ket{012} + \\ket{021} + \\ket{102} \\notag\\\\ \n    & +\\ket{120} + \\ket{201} + \\ket{210},\n\\end{align}\nand with 4 particles (with uneven coefficients $\\{k_i\\}$) \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/HighlyEntangledStates/dicke43]{experimentcounter}\n\\begin{align}\n    \\ket{D(4,(2,1,1))} &= \\ket{0012}+\\ket{1200}+\\ket{1020} \\notag\\\\\n    & + \\ket{0102}+\\ket{1002}+\\ket{0120} \\notag\\\\\n    & + \\ket{0021}+\\ket{2100}+\\ket{2010} \\notag\\\\\n    & + \\ket{0201}+\\ket{2001}+\\ket{0210}.\n\\end{align}\n\nAfter plotting the results found by \\pytheus to generate the last two states, we found a pattern on the graphs that led us to states like $\\ket{D(5,(2,2,1)}$ and $\\ket{D(4,(1,1,1,1))}$: We start taking a fully connected graph of $N$ particles, in which the vertices are connected by 2 bicolored edges, blue-red and red-blue, indicating two modes (the same as in Ref.\\ \\cite{graphs3}). Then one can add ancillas that are connected to the $N$ first particles by bicolored edges, one for each of the $N$ particles. These new edges introduce more modes, leading to the following series of states for an even number of particles, $2k$:\n\\begin{align*}\n    \\text{0 ancillas, 2 modes} &\\rightarrow  \\ket{D(2k,(k,k))}  \\\\\n    \\text{2 anc, 3 modes} &\\rightarrow  \\ket{D(2k,(k,k\\text{ - }1,1))}  \\\\\n    \\text{2 anc, 4 modes} &\\rightarrow  \\ket{D(2k,(k\\text{ - }1,k\\text{ - }1,1,1))}  \\\\\n    & \\cdots\n\\end{align*}\n \\vspace{-7mm}\n\\begin{equation*}\n    \\text{2($k\\text{ - }1$) anc, 2$k$ modes} \\rightarrow  \\ket{D(2k,(1,\\cdots,1))}\n\\end{equation*}\nFor an odd number of particles, $2k\\!+\\!1$, starting with 1 ancilla, we obtain\n\\begin{align*}\n    \\text{1 anc, 3 modes} &\\rightarrow  \\ket{D(2k\\!+\\!1,(k,k,1))}  \\\\\n    \\text{3 anc, 4 modes} &\\rightarrow  \\ket{D(2k\\!+\\!1,(k,k\\text{ - }1,1,1))}  \\\\\n    \\text{3 anc, 5 modes} &\\rightarrow  \\ket{D(2k\\!+\\!1,(k\\text{ - }1,k\\text{ - }1,1,1))}  \\\\\n    & \\cdots \n\\end{align*}\n \\vspace{-7mm}\n\\begin{equation*}\n    \\text{$2k\\text{ - }1$ anc, $2k\\!+\\!1$ modes} \\rightarrow  \\ket{D(2k\\!+\\!1,(1,\\cdots,1))}.\n\\end{equation*}\n\\begin{figure}[!h]\n\t\\centering\n    \\subfloat[$\\ket{D(3,(1,1,1)}$]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_dicke33.pdf}}\\!\\!%{Graphs/Dicke/dicke33.pdf}}\\!\\!\n\t\\subfloat[$\\ket{D(4,(2,1,1))}$]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_dicke43.pdf}}%{Graphs/Dicke/dicke43.pdf}}\n \\\\\n    \\subfloat[$\\ket{D(5,(2,2,1)}$]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_dicke53.pdf}}\\!\\!\n\t\\subfloat[$\\ket{D(4,(1,1,1,1))}$]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_dicke44.pdf}}\n    \\caption{The three-dimensional Dicke states for three and four particles (top) were found by \\pytheus. The 2 graphs in the bottom row were manually produced following the observed pattern.}\n\t\\label{fig:symm}\t\n\\end{figure}\n\n\\tocless\\subsubsection{Yeo-Chua State}\nIn 1993, Bennett et.\\ al.\\ showed how to use Bell states to teleport arbitrary and unknown single-qubit states \\cite{quantum_teleportation_paper}. Going one step further, Yeo and Chua developed a protocol to teleport unknown states of two qubits \\cite{Yeo_2006}, and instead of using Bell states, they employed the Yeo-Chua state\n\\begin{align}\\label{eq:YC}\n\\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/HighlyEntangledStates/YC]{experimentcounter}\\ket{YC}  =& \\ket{0000}-\\ket{0011}-\\ket{0101} \\notag\\\\ \n    &  + \\ket{0110} + \\ket{1001} + \\ket{1001} \\notag\\\\\n    & + \\ket{1100} + \\ket{1111}.\n\\end{align}\nThis highly entangled state can be produced with the graph of Fig.~\\ref{fig:yc_state}.\\newline\n\\begin{figure}[!t]\n\t\\centering\n\t\\includegraphics[width=0.26\\textwidth]{graph_YC.pdf}%{Graphs/HighlyEntangledStates/YCstate.pdf}\n\t\\caption {Graph for generating the Yeo-Chua state.}\n\t\\label{fig:yc_state}\t\n\\end{figure}\n\n\n\\tocless\\subsubsection{Complex Weights as a Resource}\nExploring the applicability range of \\pytheus, we searched for four-qubit states of the form\n\\begin{align}\n    \\ket{\\psi} = c_1 \\ket{0000} + c_2 \\ket{0001} + ... + c_{16}\\ket{1111},\n\\end{align}\nwhere $c_i \\in \\{ 0,1 \\}$. A total of $2^{16}-1 = 65535$ states.\nGraphs with $\\pm1$ weights suffice to produce most of the states, many of them do not even require interference. Yet, some states, such as \n\\begin{align}\\label{eq:4qubitcomplex}\n    \\ket{\\psi} &= \\ket{0011} + \\ket{0100} + \\ket{0111} + \\ket{1000} \\notag\\\\ \n    &+ \\ket{1100} + \\ket{1101} + \\ket{1110},\n\\end{align}\nrequire not only destructive interference between creation terms, but very specific ratios between the weights. In particular, the weights to produce the state \\eqref{eq:4qubitcomplex} make use of the \\textit{Golden Ratio}, since they must fulfill the expression\n\\begin{equation}\\label{eq:golden_ratio}\n    x^2 + x = 1.\n\\end{equation}\nThe graph that employs the golden ratio is shown in Fig~\\ref{fig:complex}, and similar graphs can produce a whole family of 64 states which are equivalent under permutations and bit-flips. However, there is an alternative complex-weighted graph, with less edges, to produce these states. As shown in Fig~\\ref{fig:complex}, the absolute value is the same for all weights and the interference patterns due to the complex phases are shown in Fig~\\ref{fig:compexPMs}. Even thought they are computationally more expensive to obtain, complex-weighted solutions can provide new interesting designs.\\newline\n\\begin{figure}[!t]\n\t\\centering\n    \\subfloat[Real solution]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_golden.pdf}}\\!\\!\n    \\subfloat[Complex solution]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_complex4qubit.pdf}}\n\t\\caption {Graphs for the four-qubit state defined in Eq.~\\eqref{eq:4qubitcomplex}. The left solution employs the golden ratio and the right one complex weights.}\n\t\\label{fig:complex}\n\\end{figure}\n\\begin{figure}[t]\n\t\\centering\n\t\\includegraphics[width=0.49\\textwidth]{graph_complex4qubit_pms.pdf}\n\t\\caption {Perfect matchings of graph shown in Fig.~\\ref{fig:complex} for the state defined in Eq.~\\eqref{eq:4qubitcomplex}. $\\omega=e^{i\\pi/6}$. Each green box contributes one term of the state. The perfect matchings in the orange boxes interfere destructively. It is especially notable that the weights of the two $\\ket{0111}$ perfect matchings (bottom right) are complex conjugates and add to one as $\\omega^2 + \\omega^{-2} = 1$.}\n\t\\label{fig:compexPMs}\n\\end{figure}\n\n\\tocless\\subsubsection{Single Photon Sources for State Creation}\nSignificant progress has been made toward using deterministic single-photon sources in quantum optics experiments during the last years \\cite{wang2019towards,meyer2020single,singlephotons2011}. In this section, we present graphs corresponding to quantum experiments for the creation of several highly entangled states using single-photon sources. Deterministic sources do not suffer from the same trade-off between high fidelity and high count rate as probabilistic sources. When using deterministic sources, the number of photons required can be smaller than with probabilistic sources \\cite{PhysRevA.67.030101,PhysRevA.102.012604}.\n\\paragraph{Post-Selected}\nWe have found graphs for creating different GHZ states with single-photon sources as a resource. One can create a six qubit GHZ from six input photons \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/blob/main/pytheus/graphs/HighlyEntangledStates/ghz_62_sp/graph_ghz_62_sp.pdf]{experimentcounter}, a four qutrit GHZ state from six input photons \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/HighlyEntangledStates/ghz_62_sp]{experimentcounter}, as well as the same four qutrit GHZ state from a combination of two single photon sources and two simultaneous SPDC events \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/blob/main/pytheus/graphs/HighlyEntangledStates/ghz_43_2p2a/graph_ghz_43_2p2a.pdf]{experimentcounter} (see Fig.~\\ref{fig:heralded_sp_ghz}).\n\n\\begin{figure}[!h]\n    \\centering\n \\subfloat[$\\ket{\\text{GHZ}}^2_6$ (s.p.s)]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_ghz_62_sp.pdf}}\\!\\!%{Graphs/HighlyEntangledStates/ghz_62_sp.pdf}}\\!\\!\n \\subfloat[$\\ket{\\text{GHZ}}^3_4$ (s.p.s)]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_ghz_43_sp.pdf}}\\\\%{Graphs/HighlyEntangledStates/ghz_43_sp.pdf}}\\!\\!\n \\subfloat[$\\ket{\\text{GHZ}}^3_4$ (hybrid)]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_ghz_43_2p2a.pdf}}%{Graphs/HighlyEntangledStates/ghz_43_sphybird.pdf}}\n   % \\includegraphics[width=0.48\\textwidth]{Graphs/HighlyEntangledStates/postselected_sp_2.pdf}\n    \\caption{Graphs corresponding to the creation of three-, four- and five-particle GHZ states using single-photon sources.}\n    \\label{fig:heralded_sp_ghz}\n\\end{figure}\n\n\\paragraph{Heralded --}\nThere have been proposals for the creation of multi-particle high-dimensional entangled states from single photon sources using discrete Fourier transform \\cite{paesani2021scheme}. In Fig. \\ref{fig:heralded_sp_2dbell} we show a graph \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/HighlyEntangledStates/heralded_bell_sp]{experimentcounter}, which achieves a heralded Bell state using two ancillary photons without the need for photon-number-resolving detectors with almost perfect fidelity (F = 99\\%) for $w=0.1$. There are cross-term that occur due to the lack of photon- number resolution. We want to acknowledge that the probability of a heralding event is very low for this example (P = 0.08\\%) and it is thus unlikely that this setup is experimentally feasible. As $w$ approaches 0, fidelity approaches $100\\%$ but count-rate approaches 0. The trade-off between high fidelity and high count-rate is interesting to consider.\n\\begin{figure}[!h]\n    \\centering\n    \\includegraphics[width=0.26\\textwidth]{graph_heralded_bell_2d_sp_thr.pdf}\n    \\caption{Graph corresponding to the creation of a heralded two-dimensional Bell state in the outgoing photons (0-1) from four single photon sources (2-5) and two heralding detectors (6-7). The heralding detectors do not require photon-number-resolution. The light edges have weights $w<1$ corresponding to loss in the photon path.\n}\n    \\label{fig:heralded_sp_2dbell}\n\\end{figure}\n\n\n\n\\subsection{Maximizing Entanglement}\\label{sec:max_entanglement}\nWhen a quantum state cannot be expressed as the product of its parts, we call it entangled. However, if one asks \\textit{how} entangled a state is, the answer is not unique, there are multiple measures of entanglement. Here we present some of these metrics, together with states that are known to maximize them. Finally, we choose a particular metric and optimize a graph, not to reach a particular state -- as done so far by maximizing the fidelity -- but to instead maximize the entanglement metric itself. In this way, we will recover some well-known entangled states and also find new ones. \n\n\n\\tocless\\subsubsection{Schmidt Rank Vector}\nMultiparticle entangled states in high dimensions allow for a much deeper structure underlying the potential ways in which the particles can be entangled. These structures can be characterized by the Schmidt Rank Vector (SRV) and give rise to new phenomena that only exist if both the number of particles and the number of dimensions go beyond two \\cite{HuberSRV,HuberSRVentropy, CadneySRV}. Here we consider tripartite states. The rank vector is a list of the ranks of the reduced density matrices. The state $\\text{SRV(A,B,C)}$ refers to a state, where\n\\begin{equation}\n\tA=\\text{rank}(\\rho_{A}), \tB=\\text{rank}(\\rho_{B}), \tC=\\text{rank}(\\rho_{C}),\\nonumber\n\\end{equation}\nand $\\rho_{X}$ is the density matrix of the system with the particle $X$ traced out. In other words, the SRV is a vector of the dimensionalities of entanglement of every bipartition, which shows the dimensionality of entanglement between one particle and the rest of the quantum state. This master-slave-slave configuration is very useful for quantum applications such as layered quantum communication \\cite{LayeredQKD}. Taking a $\\text{SRV(3,3,2)}$ state as an example, we then know that the first two particles are both three-dimensionally entangled with the third particle, whereas the third one is only two-dimensionally entangled with the rest. The dimensionality for each particle cannot be increased with linear operations and classical communication (LOCC).\n\nSearching the $\\text{SRV(A,B,C)}$ states has been investigated with the computer algorithm \\melvin \\cite{Melvin2016} and graph theory \\cite{graphs2, hypergraphs}. Interestingly, it has been shown from graph theory that without using any ancilla particles, there are several $\\text{SRV(A,B,C)}$ states that cannot be created. \\cite{graphs2,hypergraphs}. Here we list these states (up to normalization):\n\\begin{equation}\n\\begin{split}\n\\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/MaxEntanglement/srv_554]{experimentcounter} &\\text{SRV(5,5,4)}:\\\\\n&\\ket{000}+\\ket{111}+\\ket{222}+\\ket{333}+\\ket{443}\\notag\\\\\n\\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/MaxEntanglement/srv_632]{experimentcounter} &\\text{SRV(6,3,2)}:\\\\\n&\\ket{000}+\\ket{101}+\\ket{210}+\\ket{311}\\notag\\\\+&\\ket{420}+\\ket{521}\\notag\\\\\n\\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/MaxEntanglement/srv_655]{experimentcounter}&\\text{SRV(6,5,5)}:\\\\\n&\\ket{000}+\\ket{111}+\\ket{222}+\\ket{334}\\notag\\\\+&\\ket{443}+\\ket{544}\\notag\\\\\n\\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/MaxEntanglement/srv_733]{experimentcounter} &\\text{SRV(7,3,3)}:\\\\\n&\\ket{000}+\\ket{101}+\\ket{210}+\\ket{311}\\notag\\\\+&\\ket{422}+\\ket{520}+\\ket{621}\\notag\n\\end{split}\n\\end{equation}\n\\begin{figure}[!b]\n\t\\centering\n\t\\subfloat[SRV(5,5,4)]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_srv_554.pdf}}%{Graphs/HighlyEntangledStates/srv_554.pdf}}\\!\\!\n\t\\subfloat[SRV(6,3,2)]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_srv_632.pdf}}%{Graphs/HighlyEntangledStates/srv_632.pdf}}\n    \\\\ \\vspace{-2mm}\n\t\\subfloat[SRV(6,5,5)]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_srv_655.pdf}}\\!\\!%{Graphs/HighlyEntangledStates/srv_655.pdf}}\\!\\!\n\t\\subfloat[SRV(7,3,3)]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_srv_733.pdf}}%{Graphs/HighlyEntangledStates/srv_733.pdf}}\n\t\\caption {Graphs for producing $\\text{SRV(A,B,C)}$ states using ancillas.}\n\t\\label{fig:SRVgraphs}\t\n\\end{figure}\nIt has been unknown whether we can experimentally create these states with additional particles, and this challenging question has been open for more than three years. Also, until now, $\\text{SRV(A,B,C)}$ states in high dimensional systems have only been recently demonstrated for $\\text{SRV(3,3,2)}$ \\cite{srv332experimentmalik}, $\\text{SRV(3,3,3)}$ \\cite{erhard3dghz}, and $\\text{SRV(4,4,2)}$ \\cite{srv442experimenthu}. By using PyTheus, one can learn how to generate much more complex SRV states of high dimensions and more particles, such as the impossible states described in \\cite{graphs2,hypergraphs}. We show the results in Fig.~\\ref{fig:SRVgraphs}.\n\n\n\n\n\n\\tocless\\subsubsection{Hyperdeterminant}\nExpanding the definition of determinant to tensors of arbitrary dimensions, we obtain \\textit{Hyperdeterminants} \\cite{hyperdeterminant}, which can also be used as an entanglement metric. In particular, the hyperdeterminant of a tensor $2\\times2\\times2\\times2$ characterizes the entanglement of a 4 qubit state, which is maximal for the state (up to normalization) \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/MaxEntanglement/HD]{experimentcounter}\n\\begin{equation}\n    \\ket{\\text{HD}} = \\ket{\\Psi^+00}+\\ket{00\\Psi^+} + \\ket{1111},\n\\end{equation}\nwhere $\\sqrt{2}\\ket{\\Psi^+}=\\ket{01}+\\ket{10}$, and whose associated graph is shown in Fig.~\\ref{fig:hyperdeterminant}.\\newline\n\\begin{figure}[!h]\n\t\\centering\n\t\\includegraphics[width=0.26\\textwidth]{graph_HD.pdf}%{Graphs/HighlyEntangledStates/HDstate.pdf}\n\t\\caption {Graph to generate the state $\\ket{\\text{HD}}$, which maximizes the hyperdeterminant.}\n\t\\label{fig:hyperdeterminant}\t\n\\end{figure}\n\n\\tocless\\subsubsection{Negative Partial Trace}\nGiven a state $\\rho_{AB}$, its \\textit{partial transpose} with respect to the subsystem $A$ is\n\\begin{equation}\n    (\\rho^{T_A})_{ab,mn} = \\rho_{mb,an}.\n\\end{equation}\nAs shown by Peres, it is a necessary condition for the separability of $A$ and $B$ that none of the eigenvalues of $\\rho^{T_A}$ are negative \\cite{peres_separability}. Moreover, it is also a sufficient condition for bipartite states of dimensions $2\\times2$ and $2\\times3$ \\cite{horodecki2001}. \n\nAiming for highly entangled states, Brown et.\\ al.\\ looked for states of 2, 3, 4, and 5 qubits, whose partial traces for each bipartition had the lowest possible eigenvalues \\cite{brown05}. They called this metric \\textit{Negative Partial Trace}, and it leads to the following states of 4 and 5 qubits \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/MaxEntanglement/bssb4]{experimentcounter} \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/MaxEntanglement/bssb5]{experimentcounter}\n\\begin{align}\n    \\ket{\\text{BSSB4}} &= \\ket{0000} + \\ket{+011} \\notag\\\\ \n    &+ \\ket{1101} + \\ket{-110} \\\\\n     \\ket{\\text{BSSB5}} &= \\ket{000\\Phi^+} + \\ket{100\\Phi^-} \\notag\\\\\n     & + \\ket{010\\Psi^+}  + \\ket{111\\Psi^-}.\n\\end{align}\nWhere $\\sqrt{2}\\ket{\\pm}=\\ket{0}\\pm\\ket{1}$, $\\sqrt{2}\\ket{\\Phi^\\pm}=\\ket{00}\\pm\\ket{11}$, and $\\sqrt{2}\\ket{\\Psi^\\pm}=\\ket{01}\\pm\\ket{10}$. These states can be produced with the graphs shown in Fig.~\\ref{fig:bssb}.\n\\begin{figure}[!h]\n\t\\centering\n    \\includegraphics[width=0.22\\textwidth]{graph_bssb4.pdf}\\!\\!%{Graphs/HighlyEntangledStates/bssb4real.pdf} \\hspace{-5mm}\n\t\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_bssb5.pdf}%{Graphs/HighlyEntangledStates/bssb5.pdf}\n\t\\caption {Graphs to generate the BSSB states of 4 and 5 qubits, respectively. The latter requires an ancilla.}\n\t\\label{fig:bssb}\t\n\\end{figure}\n\n\\tocless\\subsubsection{R\\'enyi Entropy}\nAmong all the entanglement metrics in this document, as well as the ones that are left out, the \\textit{R\\'enyi Entropy} is one of the most important \\cite{renyi_entropy}. Given a state with $\\rho_{AB}$, the R\\'enyi entropy of order $\\alpha$ between the subsystems $A$ and $B$ is\n\\begin{equation}\n\\label{eq:renyi}\n    \\mathcal{S}_\\alpha (\\rho_A) = \\frac{1}{1-\\alpha} \\log \\Tr (\\rho_A^\\alpha) = \\mathcal{S}_\\alpha(\\rho_B),\n\\end{equation}\nwhere $\\rho_A=\\Tr_B(\\rho_{AB})$ and $\\rho_B=\\Tr_A(\\rho_{AB})$ are reduced density matrices. Similarly, the \\textit{Tsallis entropy} also describes the entanglement between $A$ and $B$\n\\begin{equation}\n \\label{eq:tsallis}\n   \\mathcal{T}_\\alpha (\\rho_A) = \\frac{1}{1-\\alpha} \\left(\\Tr (\\rho_A^\\alpha) - 1\\right) = \\mathcal{T}_\\alpha(\\rho_B).\n\\end{equation}\nNotice that in the limit $\\alpha\\rightarrow1$, both expressions approach the Von Neumann entropy.\n\nA relevant difference between both metrics is that, for $\\alpha>1$, only the Tsallis entropy is convex while the R\\'enyi one is Schur convex \\cite{renyi_concavity}. Taking this difference into account, Gour and Wallach showed that the 4-qubit state $\\ket{L}$ maximizes the average of Tsallis entropies with $\\alpha=2$ for 2-qubit partitions \\cite{Gour_2010}, a metric of entanglement also referred to as the \\textit{Meyer-Wallach measure} \\cite{Brennen03,Meyer2002}. This state, created by the graph shown in Fig.~\\ref{fig:Lstate}, reads \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/MaxEntanglement/Lstate]{experimentcounter}\n\\begin{align}\n    \\ket{\\text{L}} =& (1+\\omega)(\\ket{0000}+\\ket{1111}) \\notag \\\\\n    +& (1-\\omega)(\\ket{0011}+\\ket{1100}) \\notag \\\\ \n    +& \\omega^2(\\ket{0101} + \\ket{0110} + \\ket{1001} + \\ket{1010}),\n\\end{align}\nwhere $\\omega=\\exp(2i\\pi/3)$.\n\\begin{figure}[!h]\n\t\\centering\n\t\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_Lstate.pdf}\n\t\\caption {Graph to generate the 4-qubit L-state. All the weights in the graph are complex.}\n\t\\label{fig:Lstate}\t\n\\end{figure}\n\n\n\\tocless\\subsubsection{R\\'enyi\u2013Ingarden\u2013Urbanik Entropy}\nMinimizing the R\\'enyi entropy over all local unitary transformations $U_{\\text{LOC}}$, Enriquez et.\\ al.\\ described the minimal \\textit{R\\'enyi\u2013Ingarden\u2013Urbanik} entropy \\cite{Enriquez2015}\n\\begin{equation}\n  \\label{eq: RIU-entropy}\n  \\mathcal{S}_\\alpha^{\\text{RIU}}(\\phi) = \\min_{U_{\\text{LOC}}} \\mathcal{S}_\\alpha( p(U_{\\text{LOC}}\\ket{\\phi})),\n\\end{equation}\nwhere $\\mathcal{S}_\\alpha$ is the R\\'enyi entropy of order $\\alpha\\geq0$, and $p$ is a normalized probability vector resulting from expanding the state to a product basis.\n\nTogether with the definition, the authors numerically find two states of three qubits that minimize the entropy for $\\alpha=1$ and $\\alpha=2$ \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/MaxEntanglement/randmax1]{experimentcounter} \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/MaxEntanglement/randmax2]{experimentcounter}\n\\begin{align}\n    \\ket{\\Phi}_{\\alpha=1} &=  0.27 \\ket{000} + 0.377 \\ket{100} + 0.326 \\ket{010}  \\notag\\\\\n        &+ 0.363 \\ket{001} + 0.74 e^{-0.79 \\pi i} \\ket{111}, \\\\\n    \\ket{\\Phi}_{\\alpha=2} &= 0.438 \\ket{000} + 0.29 \\ket{100} + 0.371 \\ket{010} \\notag\\\\\n    & +  0.316 \\ket{001} +  0.698 e^{ -0.826 \\pi i}\\ket{111}. \n\\end{align}\nThese states correspond to the graphs of Fig.~\\ref{fig:maxRIU}.\n\\begin{figure}[!h]\n\t\\centering\n    \\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_randmax1.pdf}\\!\\!%{Graphs/HighlyEntangledStates/randmax1.pdf}\\!\\!\n\t\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_randmax2.pdf}%{Graphs/HighlyEntangledStates/randmax2.pdf}\n\t\\caption {Graphs to generate the states that optimize the RIU entropy for $\\alpha=1$ and $\\alpha=2$.}\n\t\\label{fig:maxRIU}\t\n\\end{figure}\n\n\n\\tocless\\subsubsection{Maximizing Entanglement for Each Partition}\\label{sec:concurrence}\nThe previous states were maximally entangled according to different metrics. Indeed, many of them were found numerically when maximizing such metrics. Similarly, we can use \\pytheus to maximize arbitrary physical properties of the states produced by a graph, which can be immediately translated into experiments. This is a great advantage over previous work, in which an analytically described quantum state may not be experimentally feasible.\n\nWe optimize the graph according to the Tsallis entropy for $\\alpha=2$ (see Eq.~\\eqref{eq:tsallis}) using as loss function\n\\begin{equation}\n\\label{eq:concurrence}\n    \\min_{\\omega} \\mathcal{L}(\\rho(\\omega)) = \\sum_{A}\\Tr\\rho_A^2,\n\\end{equation}\nwhere $\\rho=\\ketbra{\\psi(\\omega)}$ is the state defined by a graph with weights $\\{\\omega\\}$, $\\rho_A$ is the reduced density matrix with respect to a subsystem $A$. A subsystem and its complement $A^c$ are a bipartition of the full system. The loss function is minimized for the sum of all bipartitions. \n\nGiven a bipartition, the entanglement between them is maximal if\n \\begin{equation}\n     \\rho_A = \\Tr_{A^c}(\\rho)= \\frac{1}{D}\\mathbb{I},\n \\end{equation}\nwith $D$ being the dimension of the Hilbert space in which $\\rho_A$ is defined, and $\\mathbb{I}$ the identity matrix. Accordingly, multipartite states with maximal entanglement for every bipartition are called \\textit{Absolutely Maximally Entangled} (AME); such kinds of states have applications in quantum protocols like threshold secret sharing or open-destination teleportation \\cite{AME_definitions_and_application}. On the other hand, given a state of $N$ qudits, $\\rho\\in\\mathcal{H}_d^{\\otimes N}$, we call it \\textit{k-uniform} when the entanglement is maximal for all bipartitions of $k$ qudits \\cite{k-uniform-paper}. GHZ states of N-qudits (see Eq.~\\eqref{eq:ghz}) are examples of 1-uniform states. \n\nWith \\pytheus we can pick types of bipartitions the entanglement is to be maximized. Choosing all bipartitions targets the production of an AME state, bipartitions of size $|A| = k$ target k-uniform states. A mathematical result of entanglement theory is that AMEs only exist for certain combinations of $N$ and $d$ (see table \\ref{tab: AME_overview}). In such situations we choose to optimize for k-uniform states.\n\n\\begin{table}\n\\centering\n\\resizebox{0.45\\textwidth}{!}{%\n\\begin{tabular}{c|ccccccccc}\n\\hline\n\\multirow{2}{*}{\\:\\textbf{Dim}\\:} &\n  \\multicolumn{9}{c}{\\textbf{Number of particles}} \\\\ \\cline{2-10} \n &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\:2\\:} &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\:3\\:} &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\:4\\:} &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\:5\\:} &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\:6\\:} &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\:7\\:} &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\:8\\:} &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\:9\\:} &\n  10 \\\\ \\hline\n2 &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\textcolor{Green}{\\cmark}} &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\textcolor{Green}{\\cmark}} &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\textcolor{red}{\\xmark}} &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\textcolor{Green}{\\cmark}} &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\textcolor{Green}{\\cmark}} &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\textcolor{red}{\\xmark}} &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\textcolor{red}{\\xmark}(3)} &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\textcolor{Green}{\\cmark}(3)} &\n  \\textcolor{red}{\\xmark}(3) \\\\ \\hline\n3 &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\textcolor{Green}{\\cmark}} &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\textcolor{Green}{\\cmark}} &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\textcolor{Green}{\\cmark}} &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\textcolor{Green}{\\cmark}} &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\textcolor{Green}{\\cmark}} &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\textcolor{Green}{\\cmark}} &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\textcolor{red}{\\xmark}(3)} &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\textcolor{Green}{\\cmark}} &\n  \\textcolor{Green}{\\cmark} \\\\ \\hline\n4 &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\textcolor{Green}{\\cmark}} &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\textcolor{Green}{\\cmark}} &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\textcolor{Green}{\\cmark}} &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\textcolor{Green}{\\cmark}} &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\textcolor{Green}{\\cmark}} &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\textcolor{Green}{\\cmark}} &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\textbf{\u00bf?}} &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\textcolor{Green}{\\cmark}} &\n  \\textcolor{Green}{\\cmark} \\\\ \\hline\n5 &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\textcolor{Green}{\\cmark}} &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\textcolor{Green}{\\cmark}} &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\textcolor{Green}{\\cmark}} &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\textcolor{Green}{\\cmark}} &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\textcolor{Green}{\\cmark}} &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\textcolor{Green}{\\cmark}} &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\textcolor{Green}{\\cmark}} &\n  \\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\\textcolor{Green}{\\cmark}} &\n  \\textcolor{Green}{\\cmark} \\\\ \\hline\n\\end{tabular}%\n}\n\\caption{\\textbf{Known AME states up to 10 particles and 5 dimensions.} \\textcolor{red}{\\xmark}: no AME exist for the 2-dimensional systems of 4, 7, 8, and 10 particles, nor for the 3-dimensional system of 8 particles. \\textbf{\u00bf?}: it is unknown whether there is an AME for the 4-dimensional system of 8 particles. \\textcolor{Green}{\\cmark}: there exist an AME state for the rest of systems. For the 2-dimensional systems of 8, 9, and 10 particles, as well as for the 3-dimensional system of 8 particles, there exist a state with maximally entangled partitions of 3 particles \\cite{k-uniform-paper,shi2020constructions}. The existence of some of these state does not imply that they have been (or can be) experimentally realized.}\n\\label{tab: AME_overview}\n\\end{table}\n\n\\paragraph{AME States --} \nSince no AME exist for a system of four qubits (see table \\ref{tab: AME_overview}), we start optimizing the entanglement for all possible partitions for five qubits, obtaining two different AME states \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/MaxEntanglement/ame_5qubit_a]{experimentcounter} \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/MaxEntanglement/ame_5qubit_b]{experimentcounter}\n\\begin{align}\n    \\ket{\\text{AME}(5,2)}_a &= \\ket{00000} + \\ket{01101} + \\ket{01110} \\notag \\\\\n    &+ \\ket{10110} + \\ket{11000} + \\ket{11011} \\notag \\\\\n    &- \\ket{00011} - \\ket{10101}, \\\\\n      \\ket{\\text{AME}(5,2)}_b  &=    \\ket{01011} + \\ket{01100} + \\ket{10110} \\notag \\\\ \n      &+ \\ket{11010} - \\ket{00000} - \\ket{00111} \\notag \\\\\n      &- \\ket{10001} - \\ket{11101}. \n\\label{eq: AME5Qubits}\n\\end{align}\nFor six qubits we found an asymptotic state \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/MaxEntanglement/AMEepsilon6qubits]{experimentcounter}\n\\begin{align}\n    \\ket{\\text{AME}(6,2)} & \\approx \\ket{000010} + \\ket{000100} + \\ket{001001} \\notag\\\\ \n  & + \\ket{010101}  +  \\ket{011000} + \\ket{011110} \\notag\\\\ \n  & + \\ket{101010} + \\ket{110000} +  \\ket{111011} \\notag\\\\ \n  & + \\ket{111101} - \\ket{001111} - \\ket{010011} \\notag\\\\ \n  & - \\ket{100001} - \\ket{100111} - \\ket{101100} \\notag\\\\ \n  & -  \\ket{110110} + \\varepsilon (\\ket{000000} + \\ket{000110} \\notag\\\\ \n  & +  \\ket{010001} + \\ket{010111}  +  \\ket{110010} \\notag\\\\ \n  & + \\ket{110100} + \\ket{111001} + \\ket{111111} ).\n\\end{align}\nThis is not exactly the AME state of eight qubits, it has eight terms which vanish asymptotically as $\\varepsilon$ goes to zero. However, by doing so, we reduce the creation rate of the whole state. The graphs to produce this and the 5-qubits AME states are shown in Fig.~\\ref{fig:AMEs}.\n\\begin{figure}[!t]\n\t\\centering\n\t\\subfloat[$\\ket{\\text{AME}(5,2)}_a$]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_ame_5qubit_a.pdf}}\\!\\!%{Graphs/MaxEntanglement/AME5qubitsA.pdf}}\\!\\!\n\t\\subfloat[$\\ket{\\text{AME}(5,2)}_b$]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_ame_5qubit_b.pdf}}\n  \\vspace{-3mm}%{Graphs/MaxEntanglement/AME5qubitsB.pdf}}\n  \\vspace{-3mm}\n\t\\subfloat[$\\ket{\\text{AME}(6,2)}$]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_AMEepsilon6qubits.pdf}}\\\\%{Graphs/MaxEntanglement/AMEepsilon6qubits.pdf}}\\\\\n\t\\caption {Absolutely Maximally Entangled states with 5 and 6 qubits. The 6-qubit graph produces an asymptotic state.}\n\t\\label{fig:AMEs}\t\n\\end{figure}\n\n\n\\paragraph{k-Uniform States --}\nWhile the AME solution for six qubits was asymptotic, we can generate the exact 2-uniform state of such a system \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/MaxEntanglement/k2uniform6qubits]{experimentcounter}\n\\begin{align}\n      \\ket{\\text{U}2}_6^2 &= \\ket{100011} + \\ket{101110} - \\ket{000000}\\notag \\\\\n &  - \\ket{001101} -  \\ket{010111} - \\ket{011010} \\notag \\\\\n & - \\ket{110100} - \\ket{111001}. \n\\end{align}\nTwelve out of twenty three-qubit bipartitions of the above state are maximally entangled. \n\nSimilarly, we generated a 7-qubit state that maximizes the entanglement between each of the 21 possible $k=2$ partitions except one \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/MaxEntanglement/k2uniform7qubits]{experimentcounter}\n\\begin{align}\n    \\ket{\\sim \\text{U}2}_7^2 &= \\ket{0011110} + \\ket{0101000} + \\ket{0110111}  \\notag \\\\\n & + \\ket{1001101} + \\ket{1010010} + \\ket{1100100}  \\notag \\\\\n & - \\ket{0000001} - \\ket{1111011}.\n\\end{align}\nThe graph to produce this `almost' uniform state and the previous one are shown in Fig.~\\ref{fig:uniforms}.\n\n\n\\begin{figure}[!h]\n\t\\centering\n\t{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_k2uniform6qubits.pdf}}\\!\\!%{Graphs/MaxEntanglement/k2uniform6qubits.pdf}}\\!\\!\n\t{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_k2uniform7qubits.pdf}}%{Graphs/MaxEntanglement/k2uniform7qubits.pdf}}\n\t\\caption {$k$=2 uniform state for 6 qubits and $k$=2 (almost) uniform state for 7 qubits (+ one ancilla).}\n\t\\label{fig:uniforms}\t\n\\end{figure}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Other States --}\nAs we have seen, even when an AME or k-uniform state for a given system of qudits exists, it is not always realizable with linear optics. However, even if not perfect, we have found several highly entangled states which are worth mentioning. We refer to them as\n\\begin{equation}\n    \\ket{\\text{Ent(n,d,k)}},\n\\end{equation} \nwhere $n$ stands for the number of particles, $d$ for their dimensions, and $k$ for the size of the partitions. %We can also have $k=$\\textit{all}, indicating that we maximized over all possible partitions.\n\nFor a system of four qubits, we find two interesting states when maximizing the entanglement (see Eq.~\\eqref{eq:concurrence}) for every 2-qubit partition (see Fig.~\\ref{fig:max4qubits}). We first optimize using real weights \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/MaxEntanglement/k2maximal4qubitsREAL]{experimentcounter}\n\\begin{equation}\n    \\ket{\\text{Ent(4,2,2)}}_{\\mathbb{R}} =   \\ket{1010} + \\ket{1101} -   \\ket{0011} - \\ket{0100},\n\\end{equation}\nobtaining a state which maximizes all possible partitions except one. For the second solution, we extend the weights to the complex domain, finding a local optimal \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/MaxEntanglement/k2maximal4qubitsCOMPLEX]{experimentcounter}\n\\begin{align}\\label{eq:complex4qubitk2} % .02 extracted as global phase\n    \\ket{\\text{Ent(4,2,2)}}_{\\mathbb{C}} &= \\ket{0011} +   e^{ - i 0.54 \\pi } \\ket{0101}  \\notag \\\\\n    & + e^{ - i 0.93\\pi }\\ket{0110} +  e^{ i 0.45 \\pi}\\ket{1001} \\notag \\\\ \n    & + e^{ i 0.71 \\pi}\\ket{1010}  +  e^{ i 0.86 \\pi}\\ket{1100}. \n\\end{align}\nThis state minimizes the sum of partial traces for $k=2$ partitions, following Eq.~\\eqref{eq:concurrence}. However, while the sum its (locally) minimal, and all qubit partitions are equally entangled, they are not maximally entangled for $k=2$. and all are equally  for all $k=1$ partitions and for none of the $k=2$. However, all $k=2$ partitions lead to the same value for the partial trace defined in Eq.~\\eqref{eq:concurrence}. The entanglement seems to be `equally distributed'.\n\\begin{figure}[!h]\n\t\\centering\n\t\\subfloat[$\\ket{\\text{Ent(4,2,2)}}_{\\mathbb{R}}$]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_k2maximal4qubitsREAL.pdf}}\\!\\!%{Graphs/MaxEntanglement/k2maximal4qubitsR.pdf}}\\!\\!\n\t\\subfloat[$\\ket{\\text{Ent(4,2,2)}}_{\\mathbb{C}}$]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_k2maximal4qubitsCOMPLEX.pdf}}%{Graphs/MaxEntanglement/k2maximal4qubitsC.pdf}}\n \\caption {The graphs produced maximally entangled states for single qubit partitions on a 4 qubit system, they also present high entanglement between 2 qubit partitions (even if not maximal). The weights on the left graph are real, and the weights on the right graph are complex (the phase of every edge can be found in the repository).}\n\t\\label{fig:max4qubits}\t\n\\end{figure}\n\nThe complex state in Eq.~\\eqref{eq:complex4qubitk2} gives the same entanglement structure as the Higuchi-Sudbery state presented in \\cite{Higuchi2000}\n\\begin{align}\\label{eq:HSstate}\n    \\ket{\\text{HS}} = \\ket{0011} + \\ket{1100} &+ \\omega(\\ket{1010} + \\ket{0101}) \\notag \\\\\n    &+ \\omega^2(\\ket{1001} + \\ket{0110}),\n\\end{align}\nwhere $\\omega = e^{i2\\pi/3}$.\n\nFinally, for a system of 8 qubits, \\pytheus found a state for which 48 out of 56 total three-qubit bipartitions are maximally entangled. \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/MaxEntanglement/k3maximal8qubits]{experimentcounter}\n\\begin{align}\n        \\ket{\\text{Ent(8,2,3)}} &= \\ket{00010000} + \\ket{00010111} \\notag \\\\\n & + \\ket{01101011} + \\ket{01101100} \\notag \\\\\n & + \\ket{01110001} + \\ket{10100010} \\notag \\\\\n & + \\ket{10100101} + \\ket{10111111} \\notag \\\\\n & + \\ket{11000100} + \\ket{11011001} \\notag \\\\\n & - \\ket{00001010} - \\ket{00001101} \\notag \\\\\n & - \\ket{01110110} - \\ket{10111000} \\notag \\\\\n & - \\ket{11000011} - \\ket{11011110}.\n\\end{align}\n\nThe graph to produce this state is shown in Fig.~\\ref{fig:max8qubits}.\n\nIt would be interesting to extend the maximization of other entanglement measures, such as experimental feasible, strong forms of all-vs-nothing violations \\cite{lawrence2014rotational}, Hardy's version of local realism experiments which goes beyond the violations in Ref. \\cite{hardy1993nonlocality,chen2017experimental} (for example, by involving more particles), or other measures of quantum correlations. Such extensions would contribute to the study of artificial intelligence for the foundations of quantum mechanics \\cite{bharti2020machine}.\n\\begin{figure}[!t]\n\\centering\n\t\\subfloat[$\\ket{\\text{Ent(8,2,3)}}$]{\\includegraphics[width=0.26\\textwidth]{graph_k3maximal8qubits.pdf}}%{Graphs/MaxEntanglement/k3maximal8qubits.pdf}}\n\t\\caption {The state generated by this graph is maximally entangled for 48 of the 56 possible 3-qubit partitions.}\n\t\\label{fig:max8qubits}\t\n\\end{figure}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\\subsection{Generation of Mixed States}\n\\tocless\\subsubsection{Werner State}\nThe Werner state with the density matrix\n\\begin{align}\n    \\rho_\\alpha = \\alpha \\ket{\\Phi^+}\\bra{\\Phi^+} + (1-\\alpha)\\frac{\\mathbb{I}}{4},\n\\end{align}\nhas different properties for different values of $\\alpha$. For $\\alpha < 0.683$, it is known to be Bell-local. For $\\alpha > 0.697$, it is known to be Bell nonlocal \\cite{Bowles2021singlecopy}. This leaves the gap between $0.683$ and $0.697$ open without a mathematical proof of its properties. By creating this state, it could be possible to test the Bell-locality of a state in the middle of the gap, $\\alpha = 0.69$. The graph for the creation of this mixed state is shown in Fig.~\\ref{fig:werner} \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/MixedStates/werner]{experimentcounter}\n.\n\\begin{figure}[!h]\n\t\\centering\n\t\\includegraphics[width=0.25\\textwidth]{graph_werner.pdf}%{Graphs/MixedStates/werner.pdf}\n\t\\caption {Graph for the Werner state with $\\alpha = 0.69$. Information at vertex 0 is to be discarded. Vertex 3 is an ancillary detector}\n\t\\label{fig:werner}\n\\end{figure}\n\n\\tocless\\subsubsection{Counter-Example to the Peres Conjecture}\nRelations between different notions of quantum correlations are studied in quantum information theory. These insights are important to understand the underlying resources of quantum correlations and their applicability in quantum protocols. In 1999, Asher Peres conjectured that the notion of Bell nonlocality and distillability is equivalent \\cite{peres1999all}. Bell nonlocality, as witnessed by a violation of Bell's inequality, says that no local hidden-variable model can explain the correlations observed in an experiment. A state is called distillable if a maximally entangled Bell pair can be extracted from multiple copies. The conjecture was open for 15 years until a counter-example was discovered in 2014, first for a strong version of the conjecture \\cite{moroder2014steering} and shortly after in its full form \\cite{vertesi2014disproving}. These violations are based on the uncovering of a two-particle bound state (a state that cannot be distilled) which can be used for quantum steering and violation of Bell's inequality. The Moroder-Gittsovich-Huber-G\\\"uhne-Vertesi-Brunner (MGHG-VB) state can be written as a mixed state that is an incoherent superposition of four entangled two-qutrit states,\n\\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/MixedStates/peres]{experimentcounter}\n\\begin{align}\n    \\rho = \\sum_{i=1}^4 \\lambda_i \\ket{\\psi_i}\\bra{\\psi_i}\n\\end{align}\nwith $\\lambda=\\left(\\frac{3257}{6884},\\frac{450}{1721},\\frac{450}{1721},\\frac{27}{6884}\\right)$ and\n\\begin{align*}\n    \\ket{\\psi_1}&=\\frac{1}{\\sqrt{2}}\\left(\\ket{00}+\\ket{11} \\right) \\\\\n    \\ket{\\psi_2}&=\\frac{\\sqrt{131}}{12\\sqrt{2}}\\left(\\ket{01}+\\ket{10} \\right)+\\frac{1}{60}\\ket{02}-\\frac{3}{10}\\ket{21}\\\\\n    \\ket{\\psi_3}&=\\frac{\\sqrt{131}}{12\\sqrt{2}}\\left(\\ket{00}-\\ket{11} \\right)+\\frac{1}{60}\\ket{12}-\\frac{3}{10}\\ket{20}\\\\\n    \\ket{\\psi_4}&=\\frac{1}{\\sqrt{3}}\\left(-\\ket{01}+\\ket{10}+\\ket{22} \\right).\n\\end{align*}\n\\begin{figure}[t]\n\t\\centering\n\t\\includegraphics[width=0.25\\textwidth]{graph_peres.pdf}%{Graphs/MixedStates/peres_conjecture.pdf}\n\t\\caption {Graph for the Moroder-Gittsovich-Huber-G\\\"uhne-Vertesi-Brunner (MGHG-VB) state, which is a counter-example to the Peres conjecture. Here, vertex 3 is an ancilla photon and vertex 2 is the environment vertex. Due to the structure of the MGHG-VB state, the edge weights are not simple fractions.}\n\t\\label{fig:PeresGraph}\n\\end{figure}\n\nThe graph that corresponds to this state is shown in Fig.~\\ref{fig:PeresGraph}. It might be interesting to generate this state and show experimentally that the state can violate Bell's inequality and thereby demonstrate an experimental falsification of Peres's conjecture.\n\n\n\n\\subsection{Generation of Entanglement in the Photon-Number Basis}\\label{sec:state_in_fock}\n\\tocless\\subsubsection{N00N States}\\label{sec:noon_states}\n\nThe ability to perform precise measurements is always affected by several limitations, some of them avoidable by careful design of experiments and others of a fundamental nature. Classically, one can estimate a phase parameter more precisely by increasing the number of particles $N$ in the measurement process; the precision is typically limited to $1/\\sqrt{N}$, also known as the standard quantum limit (SQL). With the aid of quantum resources, one can beat the SQL, and the measurement precision can be enhanced to scale as $1/N$, approaching the Heisenberg limit that is governed by the physical law of quantum mechanics. One prominent representative of quantum states with the ability to break the SQL is the well-known N00N states \\cite{giovannetti2004quantum,polino2020photonic}, as described in Eq.~\\eqref{eq:NOON}. \n\nThese N00N states can not only be used to test fundamental physics via violating Bell-type inequalities \\cite{bellviolationNOON} but also play an important role in quantum-enhanced applications, quantum-enhanced microscopes and imaging systems \\cite{SupersensitivePRL,ono2013entanglement,gao2022high,ndagano2022quantum}, super-resolving phase measurements \\cite{mitchell2004super, walther2004broglie,fourNOON2006, sixNOON2007}, and quantum lithography \\cite{dowling2000}, to name a few. Interestingly, as the two-mode N00N states are formed in a superposition of two distinct states $\\ket{N,0}$ and $\\ket{0,N}$, one could consider that the two terms correspond to the ``dead cat\" and ``alive cat\" in the ``Schr\\\"{o}dinger-cat'' form \\cite{afek2010high}. With high-N00N states, we might step closer to a better understanding of macroscopic entanglement envisioned by Schr\\\"{o}dinger \\cite{schrodinger1935gegenwartige}. In the optical regime, achieving an efficient photonic source of N00N states with large $N$ is very challenging. Several schemes and experiments have been toward the direction of generating photonic high-N00N states in different ways, such as by using strong optical nonlinearities \\cite{DowlingPathEPR2007}, by linear optics and feed-forward \\cite{feedforwardNOON}, and by mixing coherent light with SPDC photon-pair sources on a standard beam splitter \\cite{PhysRevLett.100.073601,PhysRevA.76.031806,afek2010high,Afek2012}.\n\n\nAdditionally, interest has also been growing in the simultaneous estimation of multiple parameters using multi-mode quantum states \\cite{zhang2018scalable,hong2021quantum}. Using a multimode N00N state, one can reach the Heisenberg limit with an $O(d)$ advantage over what is obtained with $d$ copies of a two-mode N00N state \\cite{MultiplePhase2013,multiparameter2016}. The generalization of the two-mode N00N states in Eq.~\\eqref{eq:NOON} is given as \\cite{zhang2018scalable,hong2021quantum}\n\\begin{align}\n\\ket{\\text{N00N}}^{N}_{d}:=&\\frac{1}{\\sqrt{d}}(\\ket{N,0,...,0,0}\\pm\\ket{0,N,...,0,0}\\pm...\\\\\\nonumber\n&\\pm\\ket{0,0,...,N,0}\\pm\\ket{0,0,...,0,N})_{1,...,d}.\n\\end{align}\n\nHere we show how to produce perfect N00N states without using any coherent states or feed-forward. We list some examples that might give a different conceptual understanding and new insight. For more path-entangled states, one can directly employ \\pytheus. For the ancillary detectors, we always assume they are reached by single photons, like in previous sections. \n\n\\paragraph{Two Particles --} As we have introduced in section \\ref{fock_basis}, the simplest N00N state is the $\\ket{\\text{N00N}}^{2}_{2}$ state that can be deterministically created via HOM interference when two indistinguishable photons are incident on a standard beam splitter simultaneously \\cite{HOM1987}. From the graph in Fig.~\\ref{fig:HOMeffect}, we can easily generalize the state to an arbitrary number of modes by adding more vertices, each one with a loop. The coherent superposition of a loop being in one of the vertices indicates the resulting multi-mode two-particle N00N states.\n\n\n\\paragraph{Three Particles --} For producing 2-mode 3-photon N00N states $\\ket{\\text{N00N}}^{3}_{2}$, we additionally employ an ancilla particle in the experiment. We show the graph found by \\pytheus in Fig.~\\ref{fig:noon_multimode_all}, which uses only one color, thus corresponding to the standard path-entangled N00N states. The edge can also be in different colors such that we are able to construct graphs for polarization-entangled N00N states \\cite{KimNOON2009,threeNOON2017,KimNOON2011}. We further explore the states in multi-mode cases, as described in Fig.~\\ref{fig:noon_multimode_all} (b), (c) and (d) for 3-, 4-, 5-mode three-photon N00N states. Interestingly, the graphs found by \\pytheus exhibit a nice structure, which may be amenable to generalization, to systematically produce other multi-mode NOON states without any optimization process.\n\\begin{figure}\n    \\centering\n    \\subfloat[(a) $\\ket{\\text{N00N}}^3_2$]{\\includegraphics[width=0.246\\textwidth]{graph_noon2m3ph1anc.pdf}} \\hspace{-4mm}\n    \\subfloat[(b) $\\ket{\\text{N00N}}^3_3$]{\\includegraphics[width=0.246\\textwidth]{graph_noon3m3ph3anc.pdf}}\n    \\\\ \\vspace{-4mm}\n    \\subfloat[(c) $\\ket{\\text{N00N}}^3_4$]{\\includegraphics[width=0.246\\textwidth]{graph_noon4m3ph5anc.pdf}} \\hspace{-4mm}\n    \\subfloat[(d) $\\ket{\\text{N00N}}^3_5$]{\\includegraphics[width=0.246\\textwidth]{graph_noon5m3ph7anc.pdf}}\n    \\caption{Graphs for multi-mode three-particle N00N states $\\ket{\\text{N00N}}^{3}_{d}$ with increasing number of ancillas.}\n    \\label{fig:noon_multimode_all}\n\\end{figure}\n\n\\paragraph{Four Particles --} For the previous N00N states, we optimized the graphs using real weights, finding the states $\\ket{40}-\\ket{04}$ and $\\ket{400}-\\ket{040}-\\ket{004}$ \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/blob/main/pytheus/graphs/FockStates/noon2m4ph2anc]{experimentcounter}\\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/FockStates/noon3m4ph4anc]{experimentcounter}. However, to generate the same N00N states with zero phase difference between the terms we need to, either add a $\\pi/2$ phase on the solitary loops from Fig.~\\ref{fig:noon2m4ph} or, using only real weights, add 2 more ancillas. Additionally, after generating the 4-particle N00N states for 2 and 3 modes, it became obvious how to generate the graphs for an arbitrary number of modes.\n\\begin{figure}[!h]\n    \\centering\n    \\subfloat[(a) $\\ket{40}-\\ket{04}$]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_noon2m4ph2anc.pdf}} \\!\\!\n    \\subfloat[(b) $\\ket{400}-\\ket{040}-\\ket{004}$]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_noon3m4ph4anc.pdf}}\n    \\caption{Graphs with only real weights to generate 4-particle N00N states for 2 and 3 modes. Multiplying the $i$ the loops of the disconnected vertices all the amplitudes of the state's terms become positive. To increase the number of modes, we add a triangular subgraph connected to a loop. The edge connecting the two new ancillas must be negative.} %Notably, these graphs are not path connected, i.e., there is not a path that connects all vertices. Physically, that means these vertices are independent, but surprisingly, here, it leads to entanglement anyway.}\n    \\label{fig:noon2m4ph}\n\\end{figure}\n\nIt is worth noting that given a ket $\\ket{40}$, each combination of non-repeating edges contributes twice as much as one with duplicate edges (assuming equal weights). This is a consequence of the multinomial theorem applied to the creation operators described in Eq.~\\eqref{eq:pairsource}. \n\n\\paragraph{Other Two-Mode States --} For the previous N00N states, the associated graphs have shown some patterns. The more obvious was the increasing need for ancillas, whether we were adding more photons or modes. Moreover, based on a few graphs, we realized how to generate N00N states with 2 and 4 photons for an arbitrary number of modes. In Fig.~\\ref{fig:2mode_noons} we show how to produce the two-mode N00N state for 5, 6, 7, and 8 photons \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/FockStates/noon2m5ph3anc]{experimentcounter}\\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/FockStates/noon2m6ph4anc]{experimentcounter}\\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/FockStates/noon2m7ph5anc]{experimentcounter}\\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/FockStates/noon2m8ph6anc]{experimentcounter}. As with the 3-photon N00N states, it seems to be an underlying pattern in the graphs solutions when increasing the number of photons.\n\\begin{figure}\n    \\centering\n    \\subfloat[(a) $\\ket{\\text{N00N}}^5_2$]{\\includegraphics[width=0.23\\textwidth]{graph_noon2m5ph3anc.pdf}} \\!\\!\n    \\subfloat[(b) $\\ket{\\text{N00N}}^6_2$]{\\includegraphics[width=0.25\\textwidth]{graph_noon2m6ph4anc.pdf}}\n    \\\\ \\vspace{-4mm}\n    \\subfloat[(c) $\\ket{\\text{N00N}}^7_2$]{\\includegraphics[width=0.235\\textwidth]{graph_noon2m7ph5anc.pdf}}\\!\\!\n    \\subfloat[(d) $\\ket{\\text{N00N}}^8_2$]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_noon2m8ph6anc.pdf}}\n    \\caption{Graphs for two-mode N00N states of 5, 6, 7, and 8 photons.}\n    \\label{fig:2mode_noons}\n\\end{figure}\n\n\n\\tocless\\subsubsection{Platonic Solid States}\\label{sec:platonic_state}\nWe have been considering states where all $N$ photons are in the same path, with the other paths empty. However, \\pytheus can produce path-entangled states which do not fulfill such restrictions. Among them, a very special case leads to the highly symmetric Platonic Solid State \\cite{bjork2015stars,extremalPolarization2015,Bouchard2017}, which can resolve rotations around any axis equally well. In the Platonic picture, shown in Fig.~\\ref{fig:solid_states}, an $N$-photon state is mapped onto $N$ points on the Poincar\\'e sphere \\cite{majorana1932atomi}, offering a systematic way for visualization. This also relates to a long-lasting problem of distributing $N$ points on the Poincar\\'e sphere in a highly symmetric fashion, where one can have many different solutions based on the function one tries to optimize \\cite{conway1996packing,saff1997distributing}. Additionally, the concept of Platonic solids has also been used for fundamental investigations in quantum physics \\cite{Tavakoli2020platonicsolids,Pal2022platonicbell}. Apart from their symmetric elegance, there is plenty of room for applications of these states, for instance, in magnetometry, polarimetry, and metrology. Researchers have started investigating how to generate these Platonic solid state. In this part, we show the examples found by \\pytheus.\n\n\n \n\n\\paragraph{Tetrahedron --} Our first Platonic solid state is the tetrahedron \\cite{Grasslwebsite}, which is the unique optimal four-photon state for characterizing polarization rotations. The state written in the Fock basis reads as \n\\begin{equation}\n    \\ket{\\Psi^{(1)}} = \\frac{1}{\\sqrt{3}}(\\ket{4,0} + \\sqrt{2}\\ket{1,3}).\n\\end{equation}\nIt can be produced by the graph in Fig.~\\ref{fig:solid_states} (top panels), and has already been implemented \\cite{Hugothesis2022}. \n\nThe similarity between the graphs that produce the tetrahedron and the three-photon N00N state discovered by \\pytheus (see Fig.~\\ref{fig:noon_multimode_all} a) shows a nice pattern: to generate states in the Fock basis, we can add an arbitrary number of photons to any path. In this way, starting with a general state $\\ket{\\text{M,N}} \\pm \\ket{\\text{N,M}}$, we can obtain %The graph is very similar to the one from Fig.~\\ref{fig:noon_multimode_all}a, which produced the state $\\ket{03} + \\ket{30}$ with one ancilla. Here the weights are different (as are the contributions to each ket), but the topology is essentially the same, we only add an extra edge which connects to an additional ancilla connected with only one edge. These addition can be used in any graph that produces $\\ket{N,0} + \\ket{0,N}$, obtaining a new graph that $\\ket{N+x,0} + \\ket{x,N}$. We just need to add $x$ ancilla vertices, each connected with a single edge to the same mode. Moreover, we can simultaneously add $y$ vertices  of degree one, which connect with the other mode, which brings us \n\\begin{equation}\\label{eq:photon_addition}\n   \\ket{\\text{M,N}} \\pm \\ket{\\text{N,M}} \\Rightarrow \\ket{\\text{M+x,N+y}} \\pm \\ket{\\text{N+x,M+y}}.\n\\end{equation}\nWe only need to connect the first and second paths to $x$ and $y$ ancillary photons, respectively. This construction can be used for an arbitrary number of modes.\n\n\n\\begin{figure}[!t]\n    \\centering\n    \\subfloat[]{\\includegraphics[width=0.21\\textwidth]{Tetrahedrons.pdf}} \\!\\!\n    \\subfloat[]{\\includegraphics[width=0.25\\textwidth]{graph_tetrahedron.pdf}}\\vspace{-1cm}\n    \\\\\n    \\subfloat[]{\\includegraphics[width=0.21\\textwidth]{Octahedrons.pdf}} \\!\\!\n    \\subfloat[]{\\includegraphics[width=0.25\\textwidth]{graph_octahedron.pdf}}\\vspace{-1cm}\n    \\\\ \n    \\subfloat[]{\\includegraphics[width=0.21\\textwidth]{Cubes.pdf}}  \\!\\!\n    \\subfloat[]{\\includegraphics[width=0.25\\textwidth]{graph_cube.pdf}}\n    \n    \\caption{Graphs for producing tetrahedron, octahedron, and cube quantum states.}\n    \\label{fig:solid_states}\n\\end{figure}\n\n\\paragraph{Octahedron --}\nThe octahedron state reads\n\\begin{equation}\n    \\ket{\\Psi^{(2)}} = \\frac{1}{\\sqrt{2}}(\\ket{5,1} - \\ket{1,5}),\n\\end{equation}\nand was found by \\pytheus using only 4 ancillary detectors (see Fig.~\\ref{fig:solid_states}). Alternatively, we can apply the pattern described in Eq.~\\eqref{eq:photon_addition} to the graph that produces $\\ket{40} - \\ket{04}$, which is shown in Fig.~\\ref{fig:noon2m4ph} a).\n\n\\paragraph{Cube --}\nThe last platonic solid we are able to produce is the cube state, which reads \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/FockStates/cube]{experimentcounter}\n\\begin{equation}\n    \\ket{\\Psi^{(3)}} = \\frac{\\sqrt{3}}{12}(\\sqrt{10}\\ket{8,0} + 2\\sqrt{7}\\ket{4,4} + \\sqrt{10}\\ket{0,8}).\n\\end{equation}\nIn Fig.~\\ref{fig:solid_states}, we show the graph that can be used to generate the cube state. As we can see from the expression and Fig.~\\ref{fig:solid_states} (bottom), the graph cannot be obtained by modifying one of the previous graphs for a two-mode N00N state.\n\n\n\\subsection{Towards Quantum Simulation}\\label{sec:qsim}\nIn this section, we present quantum state generation for states from condensed matter physics which could be interesting for quantum simulation\\cite{aspuru2012photonic}. The quantum entangled states of few- or many-body systems can generally be expressed by the tensor network formulations~\\cite{Schollwock2011, Cirac2021}. One of the most successful members of this family with a vast application in condensed matter physics is the 1D matrix product state~(MPS). Here one represents the quantum state of a system with periodic boundary conditions and $N$ particles as\n\\begin{align}\n    \\ket{\\psi} = \\sum_{s} \\tr\\left[ A_{1}^{(s_{1})} A_{2}^{(s_{2})} \\ldots A_{N}^{(s_{N})}  \\right] \\ket{s_{1}\\ldots s_{N}},\n\\end{align}\nwhere $s_{i}=\\{0,\\ldots d-1\\}$ denotes the local state of the $i$th particle with local physical dimension $d$. Here $A_{i}^{(s_{i})}$ is a complex matrix with dimension $\\chi$, also known as the bond~(virtual) dimension. The matrix $A_{i}^{(s_{i})}$ can be viewed as a projector from a $\\chi$-dimensional virtual~(correlation) vector space into the physical $d$-dimensional space~\\cite{MiguelRamiro2020}. While in non-interacting systems, described by product states, the bond dimension $\\chi$ is one, this quantity grows exponentially with $N$ in most strongly correlated systems. This results in employing numerical techniques to (approximately) obtain the ground states of most many-body systems. Nevertheless, one can find multiple few- or many-body ground states with $\\chi>1$ but independent of the particle number. \nHere, we present a collection of these ground states with a concise description of their host Hamiltonian and their physical implication upon realization.\nWhile our focus is on zero-temperature ground states, we emphasize that the applicability of \\pytheus is not limited to these states. This is because both mixed states~\\ref{sec:mixed}, which describe open quantum states, and states constitute combinations of (various) Fock states~\\ref{fock_basis}, can be used to study the (grand) canonical ensemble, are treatable by \\pytheus.\n\n\\tocless\\subsubsection{Spin-1/2 Systems}\nDue to the simplicity of spin-1/2 systems and the surge of interest in qubit quantum computation, these many-body systems received ever-growing attention.\nThe local physical space of these systems spanned by $\\{ \\ket{\\uparrow}, \\ket{\\downarrow} \\}$, or equivalently $\\{ \\ket{0}, \\ket{1} \\}$, results in the local physical dimension $d=2$. Despite such a small physical dimension, the obtained ground states can be rich and exotic. In the following, we list some of these states.    \n\n\n\n\\paragraph{Spin-1/2 Wire --}\nA computational quantum spin-1/2 wire governed by nearest-neighbor interactions, associated with non-zero two-point correlation functions and arbitrary local entanglement, is described by~\\cite{Gross2010, MiguelRamiro2020}\n\\begin{align}\n    \\ket{\\psi} =\\sum_{s_i =0}^{1}\n    \\tr[ A (s_{n-1}) \\ldots A(s_1) ] \\ket{s_1 \\ldots s_n},\n\\end{align}\nwhere \n\\begin{align}\n    A(\\uparrow) &=\\frac{1}{\\sqrt{2}} G,\\quad G= \\exp (\\i \\pi \\sigma^{x}/\\tau) ,\\\\\n    A(\\downarrow) &= \\frac{1}{\\sqrt{2}} G T (\\phi), \\quad T=\n    \\begin{pmatrix}\n        e^{-\\i \\phi/2} & 0 \\\\\n        0 & e^{\\i \\phi /2}\n    \\end{pmatrix},\n\\end{align}\nwhere $\\phi$ and $\\tau$ denote the entanglement factor and period, respectively.\n\nFig.~\\ref{fig:spinhalf_wire} displays the associated graph for the ground state of the spin-1/2 wire for four particles with $\\phi= \\pi/2$. The state, up to normalization, reads ~\\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/CondensedMatter/oneDspinhalfwire4]{experimentcounter}\n\\begin{align}\n\\ket{\\psi} &= \\sqrt{2}\\ket{0000} + \\ket{0001} + \\ket{0010} + \\ket{0100} \\notag \\\\\n&- \\ket{0111} + \\ket{1000} - \\ket{1011} \\notag \\\\\n&- \\ket{1101} - \\ket{1110} - \\sqrt{2}\\ket{1111}.\n\\end{align}\n\n\\begin{figure}[!h]\n\t\\centering\n\t\\includegraphics[width=0.26\\textwidth]{graph_oneDspinhalfwire4.pdf}%{Graphs/CondensedMatter/spinhalf_wire_4.pdf}\n \\caption {The associated graph for the ground state of the spin-1/2 wire with four particles.}\n\t\\label{fig:spinhalf_wire}\n\\end{figure}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Spin-1/2 States with No Adjacent Spin-ups --}\nAside from the previous spin-1/2 state, one can compute entangled states where no two neighboring spin-ups appear in the ground state. One can expect to detect these states in spin systems with nearest-neighbor interactions. In the Rydberg-atom experiments, this situation occurs due to the Rydberg blockade~\\cite{Bernien2017}. The matrix product representation of these states reads \n\\begin{align}\n    \\ket{\\psi} =\\sum_{s_i =0}^{1}\n    \\tr[ A (s_{n-1}) \\ldots A(s_1) ] \\ket{s_1 \\ldots s_n},\n\\end{align}\nwhere\n\\begin{align}\n    A(\\uparrow) &=\\frac{1}{\\sqrt{2}} ({\\mathbb I} + \\sigma^{x} ),\\\\\n    A(\\downarrow) &= 2 \\sigma^{+},\n\\end{align}\nwith $\\sigma^{+}=\\sigma^{x}+ \\i \\sigma^{y}$.\n\nFig.~\\ref{fig:spinhalf_noadjup} displays the associated graphs for this system with various numbers of particles whose ground states read\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n\\item  \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/CondensedMatter/nbody3]{experimentcounter} Three particles with one ancillary particle:\n\\begin{align}\n\\ket{\\psi_3} &= \\ket{000} + \\ket{001} + \\ket{010} + \\ket{100}.\n\\end{align}\n\\item  \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/CondensedMatter/nbody4]{experimentcounter} Four particles:\n\\begin{align}\n\\ket{\\psi_4} &= \\ket{0000} + \\ket{0001} + \\ket{0010} \\notag \\\\\n&+ \\ket{0100} + \\ket{0101} + \\ket{1000} + \\ket{1010}.\n\\end{align}\n\\item  \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/CondensedMatter/nbody5]{experimentcounter} Five particles with one ancillary particle:\n\\begin{align}\n\\ket{\\psi_5} &= \\ket{00000} + \\ket{00001} + \\ket{00010} \\notag \\\\\n&+ \\ket{00100} + \\ket{00101} + \\ket{01000} \\notag \\\\\n&+ \\ket{01001} + \\ket{01010} + \\ket{10000} \\notag \\\\\n&+ \\ket{10010} + \\ket{10100}.\n\\end{align}\n\\item  \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/CondensedMatter/nbody6]{experimentcounter} Six particles:\n\\begin{align}\n\\ket{\\psi_6} &= \\ket{000000} + \\ket{000001} + \\ket{000010} \\notag \\\\\n&+ \\ket{000100} + \\ket{000101} + \\ket{001000} \\notag \\\\\n&+ \\ket{001001} + \\ket{001010} + \\ket{010000} \\notag \\\\\n&+ \\ket{010001} + \\ket{010010} + \\ket{010100} \\notag \\\\\n&+ \\ket{010101} + \\ket{100000} + \\ket{100010} \\notag \\\\\n&+ \\ket{100100} + \\ket{101000} + \\ket{101010}.\n\\end{align}\n\\end{itemize}\n \n\n\\begin{figure}[t]\n\t\\centering\n\t\\subfloat[3-body]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_nbody3.pdf}}\\!\\!%{Graphs/CondensedMatter/nbody3.pdf}}\\!\\!\n \\subfloat[4-body]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_nbody4.pdf}}%{Graphs/CondensedMatter/nbody4.pdf}}\n \\\\ \\vspace{-3mm}\n\\subfloat[5-body]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_nbody5.pdf}}\\!\\!%{Graphs/CondensedMatter/nbody5.pdf}}\\!\\!\n \\subfloat[6-body]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_nbody6.pdf}}%{Graphs/CondensedMatter/nbody6.pdf}} \n \\caption{Associated graphs for spin-1/2 states with no adjacent spin-ups for three, four, five, and six particles. One ancillary particle is included in states with an odd number of particles~(left column).\n }\n\t\\label{fig:spinhalf_noadjup}\n\\end{figure}\n\n\\paragraph{Majumdar-Gosh Model --}\nThe one-dimensional quantum Heisenberg spin model is known\nas the Majumdar-Gosh model when the value of\nthe next-nearest-neighbor interaction is half the value of the nearest-neighbor antiferromagnetic exchange interaction.\nThe Hamiltonian of this model casts~\\cite{Perez-Garcia2006}\n\\begin{align}\n    H= \\sum_{i} 2 \\overrightarrow{\\sigma}_{i} \\cdot\\overrightarrow{\\sigma}_{i+1} \n    +\n    \\overrightarrow{\\sigma}_{i} \\cdot\\overrightarrow{\\sigma}_{i+2},\n\\end{align}\nwhere $\\overrightarrow{\\sigma}_{i}=(\\sigma^{x}_{i}, \\sigma^{y}_{i}, \\sigma^{z}_{i})$.\n\n The ground states of this model Hamiltonian are dimerized states given by products of singlet configurations of spins on neighboring sites. The linear combination of these states reads~\\cite{Perez-Garcia2006}\n \\begin{align}\n    \\ket{\\psi} =\\sum_{s_i =0}^{1}\n    \\tr[ A (s_{n-1}) \\ldots A(s_1) ] \\ket{s_1 \\ldots s_n},\n\\end{align}\nwhere\n\\begin{align}\n    A^{\\uparrow} &=\n    \\begin{pmatrix}\n        0 & 1 & 0 \\\\\n        0 & 0 & 0 \\\\\n        \\frac{1}{\\sqrt{2}} & 0 & 0\n    \\end{pmatrix}\n    ,\\quad\n    A^{\\downarrow}=\n    \\begin{pmatrix}\n        0  & 0 & 1 \\\\\n        -\\frac{1}{\\sqrt{2}} & 0 & 0 \\\\\n        0  & 0 & 0\n    \\end{pmatrix}.\n\\end{align}\nThis ground state of the Majumdar-Gosh model is one of the simplest spin-1/2 valence-bond solids in one-dimensional systems.\n\n Fig.~\\ref{fig:majumdar} displays the associated graphs for the four- and six-particle systems whose ground states read\n\\begin{itemize}\n \\item \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/CondensedMatter/majumdar4]{experimentcounter} Four particles:\n\\begin{align}\n\\ket{\\psi^{(4)}} =&  \\ket{0011} -2 \\ket{0101} +\\ket{0110} \\nonumber \\\\\n +&\\ket{1100}-2\\ket{1010}+ \\ket{1001}.\n\\end{align}\n \\item \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/CondensedMatter/majumdar6]{experimentcounter} Six particles with two ancillary particles:\n \\begin{align}\n \\ket{\\psi^{(6)}} &=\n\\ket{001011}- \\ket{001101}\\nonumber \\\\\n& - \\ket{010011}+ \\ket{010110} \\nonumber \\\\\n& + \\ket{011001} - \\ket{011010} \\nonumber \\\\\n&\n+\n\\ket{100101}\n-\n\\ket{100110}\n\\nonumber \\\\\n&\n-\n\\ket{101001}\n+\n\\ket{101100}\n\\nonumber \\\\\n&\n+\n\\ket{110010}\n-\n\\ket{110100}.\n\\end{align}\n\\end{itemize}\n\\begin{figure}[!h]\n    \\centering\n    {\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_majumdar4.pdf}}\\!\\!%{Graphs/CondensedMatter/majumdar4.pdf}}\\!\\!\n\t{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_majumdar6.pdf}}%{Graphs/CondensedMatter/majumdar6.pdf}}\n    \\caption{Ground states of the Majumdar-Gosh model with four~(left panel) and six~(right) particles. Two ancillary particles are included in the right panel.}\n    \\label{fig:majumdar}\n\\end{figure}\n\n\\paragraph{Dyck Words --}\nThe Fredkin spin-1/2 model with a three-body interaction term reads~\\cite{Salberger2016, Movassagh2017, Caha2018, Adhikari2019}\n\\begin{align}\n    {\\cal H} =\\sum_{i} U_{i-1} P_{i,i+1} + P_{i-1,i} D_{i+1},\n\\end{align}\nwhere $U_{i} = \\ket{\\uparrow_{i}} \\bra{\\uparrow_{i}}$, $D_{i} = \\ket{\\downarrow_{i}}\\bra{\\downarrow_{i}}$ and the spin-singlet projector reads $P_{i,i+1}= \\ket{S_{i,i+1}} \\bra{S_{i,i+1}}$ with $\\ket{S_{i,j}}= (\\ket{\\uparrow_{i}} \\bra{\\downarrow_{j}}  - \\ket{\\downarrow_{i}} \\bra{\\uparrow_{j}})$. The ground state of this model is an equally weighted superposition of spin configurations forming Dyck words. Here one may use the notation $\\ket{\\uparrow} = \\ket{(}$ and $\\ket{\\downarrow} = \\ket{)}$ to translate the spin states into the Dyck words. In this notation, the ground state forms balanced strings whose segments contain equal numbers of open and closed parentheses. The ground states of the Fredkin model with six and eight particles cast\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/CondensedMatter/dyck6]{experimentcounter} Six particles:\n    \\begin{align}\n        \\ket{\\psi^{(6)}}\n        =\\frac{1}{\\sqrt{5}}\n        \\big[&\n\\ket{()()()}\n+\\ket{()(())}\n+\\ket{(())()} \n\\nonumber \\\\\n&\n+\\ket{(()())}\n+\\ket{((()))}\n        \\big].\n    \\end{align}\n\n\\item \\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/CondensedMatter/dyck8]{experimentcounter} Eight particles:\n\\begin{align}\n    \\ket{\\psi^{(6)}}\n    =\\frac{1}{\\sqrt{14}} \\big[&\n\\ket{(()())()} + \\ket{(()()())} \\notag \\\\\n+&\\ket{(()(()))} +\\ket{((()))()} \\notag \\\\\n+&\\ket{((())())} +\\ket{((()()))} \\notag \\\\\n+& \\ket{(((())))}+\\ket{()()()()} \\notag \\\\\n+&\\ket{()()(())}+\\ket{()(())()} \\notag \\\\\n+&\\ket{()(()())} +\\ket{()((()))} \\notag \\\\\n+&\\ket{(())()()} +\\ket{(())(())}\n    \\big].\n\\end{align}\n\\end{itemize}\nThe associated graphs for these states are shown in Fig.~\\ref{fig:dyck}.\n\n\\begin{figure}[!h]\n\t\\centering\n\\subfloat[Dyck Word with six letters]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_dyck6.pdf}}\\!\\!\n\\subfloat[Dyck Word with eight letters]{\\includegraphics[width=0.24\\textwidth]{graph_dyck8.pdf}}\n \\caption {The graphs corresponding to the creation of Dyck word states.}\n\t\\label{fig:dyck}\n\\end{figure}\n\n\\tocless\\subsubsection{Spin-1 Systems}\nThe quest to go beyond the two-level qubit systems in quantum computation put forward other proposals based on three-level qutrit quantum states~\\cite{Williams2011, Nisbet_Jones2013}. In spin systems, this inquiry is translated into exploring the $S=1$ space spanned by $\\{ \\ket{-1}, \\ket{0}, \\ket{1} \\}$ with physical dimension $d=3$. While spin-1 states can be realized experimentally in a controlled fashion~\\cite{Senko2015}, often, one may encounter these states as emergent phenomena in various spin-1/2 condensed matter systems, e.g., in describing the low-energy physics of chiral threefold fermions~\\cite{Bradlyn2016}. As a result, aside from technological implications, exploring the higher-spin systems may shed light on a better understanding of some emergent phenomena in other fields of physics.\n\n\n\\paragraph{Spin-1 Wire --}\nThe antiferromagnetic ground state of a spin-1 chain with nearest-neighbor interactions can be represented in the matrix product form as~\\cite{Klmper1993}\n\\begin{align}\n    \\ket{\\psi}\n    =\\tr(A_{1} A_{2} \\ldots A_{N}),\n\\end{align}\nwhere\n\\begin{align}\n    A_{i} =\\begin{pmatrix}\n        \\ket{0} & -\\sqrt{a} \\ket{+1} \\\\\n        \\sqrt{a} \\ket{-1} & -\\sigma \\ket{0}\n    \\end{pmatrix},\n\\end{align}\nwith nonvanishing $a$ and $\\sigma$.\n\nFig.~\\ref{fig:spin1} displays the associated graph with one ancilla, for the ground states of the spin-1 chain with three particles, which, up to normalization, reads ~\\numbering[https://github.com/artificial-scientist-lab/PyTheus/tree/main/pytheus/graphs/CondensedMatter/spin1]{experimentcounter}\n\\begin{align}\n\\ket{\\psi} &= 0.3(\\ket{012} + \\ket{120} + \\ket{201})   - 0.875\\ket{111} \\notag \\\\\n&- 0.15(\\ket{021} + \\ket{102} + \\ket{210}).\n\\end{align}\n\n\\begin{figure}[!h]\n\t\\centering\n\t\\includegraphics[width=0.26\\textwidth]{graph_spin1.pdf}\n \\caption {The associated graph for the ground states of the spin-1 chain with three particles.}\n\t\\label{fig:spin1}\n\\end{figure}\n\n\\paragraph{Affleck-Kennedy-Lieb-Tasaki Model --}\\label{par:alktspin1}\nA particular spin-1 bilinear biquadratic Hamiltonian introduced by Affleck, Kennedy, Lieb, and Tasaki~(AKLT) is given by~\\cite{Affleck1987, Affleck1988}\n\\begin{equation}\n    H=\\sum_{i} \\overrightarrow{S}_{i} \\cdot \\overrightarrow{S}_{i+1} + \\frac{1}{3} (\\overrightarrow{S}_{i} \\cdot \\overrightarrow{S}_{i+1})^2.\n\\end{equation}\nThe ground state of this solvable model, known as the AKLT state, is short-range entangled and classified in symmetry-protected-topological states~\\cite{Wierschem2016}. The MPS representation of this state reads~\\cite{Perez-Garcia2006, Schollwock2011}\n\\begin{equation}\n    \\ket{\\psi} =\\sum_{s_i =0}^{1} \\tr[ A (s_{n-1}) \\ldots A(s_1) ] \\ket{s_1 \\ldots s_n},\n\\end{equation}\nwhere $s_{i}  \\in  \\{0,1\\}$ and\n\\begin{equation}\n    \\{ A_{-1}, A_{0}, A_{+1} \\} = \\{ \\sqrt{\\frac{2}{3}} \\sigma^{+}, \\frac{1}{\\sqrt{3}} \\sigma^{z}, -\\sqrt{\\frac{2}{3}} \\sigma^{-} \\}.\n\\end{equation}\nHere $\\sigma^{\\pm}=\\sigma^{x} \\pm \\i \\sigma^{y}$.
